div.l: (base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle
(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
(base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde
(base) But o cours / with a sharp ygrounde spere
(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aftꝰer here degre
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
(base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon
(base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down
(base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede
(base) Out brest the blood / with sterne stremys rede
(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun
(base) And he hym hurteth / with his hors adoun
(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
(base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
(base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) They folowe the fauour of Fortune
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
(base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
(base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Some hadde saluys made for the nones
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght
(base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
(base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
(base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye

¶ The prologe of the myllers tale / /
Whan þat the knight hade thus his tale ytolde
In all the cumpany ne was there yong ne olde
That he ne seide yt was a noble storye
And worthy for to drawen to memorye
And namely the gentils euꝰerychone
Our host lough and swore as mote I gone
This goth aright vnbocled ys the male
Late se now who shall tellen an other tale
For truely this game is wele bygonne
Now telleth ye sire monke yf þat ye konne
Somwhat to quite wtith the knightes tale
The Miller þtat for dronken was of ale all pale
So that vnneth vp on his hors he sat
He nold avalen neyther hode ne hat
Ne abyden no man for his curtesye
But in pilates voys he gan to crye
And swore by armes and by blode and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
Wtith which I woll now quite the knightes tale
Our host saugh þat he was dronke of ale
And seide abide Robyn leue brother
Som bettꝰer man shall telle vs first an other
Abiden and late vs wirken threftely
By goddes soule qd he þtat woll nat I
For I woll speke or elles go my wey
Our host answered telle on a deuelwey
Thow art a fole thy wyt is ouꝰercome
Now herkeneth qd the Myller all and some
But first I make a protestaciou
That I am dronke I knowe yt by my sou
And therfore yf that I myspeke or sey
Wyteth yt the ale of Southwerk I paray
For I woll telle a legende or a lyf
Both of a Carpenter and of his wyf
How þat a Clerk hath set the wrightes cap
The Reve answered and seide stynt thy clap
Late be thy lewed dronken harlottrye
Yt ys a synne and eke a grete folye
To appeyren ony man of his defame
And eke to brynge Wyfes in soch name
Thow maist ynough of other thinges seyn
This dronken Myller spake full sone ageyn
And seide leve brother oswolde
Who hath no wyf he is no Cokwold
But I sey nat therfore þat þou art one
There be full gode wyves many one
Why art þou angry wtith my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑperde as wele as thow
Yit nolde I for the oxen in my plough
Take vp on me more then ynough
As demen on my self that I were one
I woll beleve wele þat I am none
An housbonde shall nat ben inquesityf
Of goddes priuitee ner of his wyf
So he may fynden goddes foysou there
Of the remenaunt nedeth nat enquere
What shold I more seyn but this Millere
He nold his wordes for no man forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in his manere
Me thinketh that I shall reherce yt here
And therfore euy gentyll wyght I pray
Demeth nat for goddes love that I sey
Of yuell entent but for I mot reherce
Her tales all / all be they bet or werce
Or elles falsen som of my matere
And therfore who so lyst yt nat to here
Turne ouꝰer the leef and chese an other tale
For he shall fynde ynow grete and smale
Of storiall thing that toucheth gentylnes
And eke moralite and holynes
Blameth nat me yf that ye chese amys
The Miller ys a cherle ye knowe wele this
So was the Reve eke and other mo
And harlottrye they tolden both two
Aviseth you and put me out of blame
And eke men shall nat maken ernest of game
¶ Here bygynneth the Millers prologe
Whilom there was dwellyng in Oxenford
A riche gnof that gestes held to borde
And of his craft he was a Carpentere
Wtith hym there was dwellyng a poure scolere
Hade lerned art but all his fantasye
Was turned for to lerne Astrologye
And koude a certein of conclusions
To demen by interrogacions
Yf þtat men asked hīn in certein houres
Whan þtat men shold haue drought or elles shoures
Or yf men axed hym what shold byfall
Of euꝰery thing I may nat reken hem all
This Clerke was cleped heende Nicholas
Of derne loue he kouth and of solas
And therto he was slye and full pryve
And like a meyde meke for to see
A Chambre hade he in that hostelrye
Alone wtithouten ony cumpany
Full fetisly dight wtith herbes swote
And he hym self as swete as ys the rote
Of licorys or ony setwale
His almageste and bokes grete and smale
His Astralabie langyng for his art
His Augrym stones layen feir apart
On shelves couched at his beddes hede
His presse couꝰered wtith a faldyng rede
And all aboue there lay a gay sautry
On which he made on nightes melodye
So swetely that all the chambre ronge
And angelus ad virginem he songe
And after that he songe the kynges note
Full often blissed was his mery throte
And thus this swete Clerk his tyme spent
After his frendes fyndyng and his rent
This Carpenter hade wedded newe a wyf
Which that he loued more than his lyf
Of xviij yere she was of age
Ielous he was and helde hir narow in cage
For she was wylde and yonge and he was old
And demed hym self to ben lyke a Cokwold
He knewe nat Catou for his wyt was rude
That bad men shold wed his similitude
Men shold wedden after her astate
For youth and age ben often at debate
But seth that he was fallen in the snare
He most enduren as other folk his care
Faire was this yong wyf and there wtith all
As ony wesyll hir body gent and small
A seynt she wered barred all of silke
A barme cloth as white as morne mylke
Vp on hir lendes full of many a gore
White was hir smok and broyded all before
And eke byhynde on hir coler aboute
Of cole blak sylke wtith in and eke wtith oute
The tapes of hir white volupere
Were of the same seute of hir colere
Hir filet brode of silk and set full hye
And sekerlye she hade a likerous yee
Full smale ypulled were hir browes two
And tho were bent and blak as is the slo
She was more blisfull on to se
Than ys the newe pere Ienet tre
And softꝰer than the woll ys of a wether
And by hir gurdell hing a purs of lether
Tasseld wtith sylk and perled wtith latou
In all this werld to seken vp and doun
There nys no man so wise þtat kouthe thenche
So gay a popelot or swich a wenche
Full bryght was the shinyng of hir hewe
Than in the toure þe noble yforged newe
But of hir song yt was as loude and yerne
As ony swalow sittyng on a berne
There to she koude skyp and make game
As ony calf or kydde folowyng his dame
Hir mouthe was swete as braket or the meth
Or horde of appuls leyde in hey or heth
Wynsyng she was as is a ioly colt
Longe as a mast and vp right as a bolt
A Broche she bare vp on hir loue coler
As brode as ys the boos of a bokeler
Hir shoees were laced on hir legges hie
She was a prymerole a pyggesnye
For ony lord to lyggen in his bed
Or yit for ony gode yoman to wed
Now sire and eft sire so byfell þe cas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fyll wtith this yong wyf to rage and pleye
While that hir housbonde was at Osneye
As clerkꝭes ben full sotell and full queynt
And preuely he caught hir by the queynt
And seide I wys but ych haue my wyll
For derne loue of the lemman I spyll
And held hir harde by the haunche bones
And seid leman loue me all at ones
Or I will dien also god me save
And she sprong as a colt doth in a taraue
And wtith hir hede she wryed fast a wey
She seid I will nat kys the by my fay
We late be qd ych late be Nicholas
Or I woll crie out harrow and allas
Do wey your handes for yorur curtesye
This Nicholas gan mꝰercy for to crye
And spoke so faire and ꝓprofred hym so fast
That she hir loue hym garaunted at þe laste
And swore hir othe by seint Thomas of kent
That she wolde be at his comaundement
Whan that she may hir leiser wele aspye
Myn housbond ys so full of ielousye
That but ye wayte and be preve
I wote right wele I nam but dede qd she
Ye most be full derne as in this cas
Nay there of care the nought qd Nicholas
A Clerk hade litherly byset his while
But yf he koude a Carpenter bygyle
And thus they ben accorded and ysworn
To wayte a tyme as I haue tolde byforn
Whan Nicholas hade done this euy dele
He thakked hir aboute the lendes wele
He kysseth hir swete and taketh his sautry
And pleyeth fast and maketh melodye
Than fyll yt thus that to the ꝑperissh chirch
Cristes owen werke for to wirche
This gode wyf went on an halyday
Hir forehede shone as bryght as ony day
So was yt wasshen whan she lete hir werk
Now was þꝰer of þtat chirch a paryssh clerke
The which þat was ycleped Absolon
Crull was his here / and as the gold it shone
And strotted as a fanne large and brode
Full streyte and even lay his ioly shode
His rodde was rede his yen gray as goos
Wtith poules wyndowes corven on his shoos
In hosen rede he went full fetysly
Yclad he was full small and ꝓproprely
All in a kyrtell of a light waget
Full feir and thik been the pointes set
And there vp on he hade a gay surplice
As white as ys the blosme on the ryce
A mery child he was so god me saue
Wele koude he leten blode and clyp and shaue
And make a chartre of londe or acquitaunce
In xxtiri maners kouth he tryp and daunce
After the scole of Oxenford tho
And wtith his legges casten to and fro
And plein song on a small ribible
Therto he song somtyme a loude quenyble
And as wele kouth he pley on a gitterne
In all the toun nas there brewehous ne Tauꝰerne
That he ne visited wtith his solace
There any gaylard tapster was
But to tell he was somdele squeymous
Of fertyng and of speche daungerous
This absolon that ioly was and gay
Goth wtith a sencer on the holy day
Sensyng the wyves of the ꝑperissh fast
And many a louely loke on hem he cast
And namely on this Carpentꝰers wyf
To loke on hir him thoght a mery lyf
She was so ꝓpropre and swete and likerous
I dare wele seyn yf she hade ben a mous
And he a cat he wold hir hent anone
This paryssh Clerk this ioly Absolou
Hath in his hert soch a loue longyng
That of no wyf toke he none offryng
For mone curtesye he seid he wold none
The mone whan yt was nyght full bryght shone
And Absolon his gyttern hath ytake
For ꝑperamours he thought for to wake
And forth he goth iolyf and amerous
Tyll he came to the Carpentꝰers hous
A litell after cokkes hade ycrowe
And dressed hym vp by a short wyndowe
Þat was vp on þe Carpentꝰers walle
He syngeth in his voys gentill and small
Now dere lady yf thy wyll be
I pray you that ye woll rewe on me
Full wele accordyng to his gittꝰernyng
This Carpentꝰer awoke and herde hi syng
And spake to his wyf and seide anone
What Alisou herest þou nat Absolou
That chaunteth thus vnder our bowres wall
And she answerd hym housbond þꝰere wtith all
Yis god wote Iohn I here yt euꝰerydele
This passeth forth what will ye bet þan wele
Fro day to day this ioly absolon
So woweth hir that hym ys wo bygon
He waketh all the nyght and all the day
And kembeth his lokkes brode and gay
He woweth hir by menes and brocage
And swore he wolde be hir owen page
He syngeth brokkyng as a nightyngale
He sent hir pyment meth and spiced ale
And wafres pipyng hote out of the glede
And for she was of toun he ꝓprofred mede
For som folk woll be wonien for riches
And som for strokes and som for gentilnes
Somtyme to shewen his lightnes and maistrye
He pleyeth heraudes vp on a scaffold hye
But what avayleth hi as in this cas
She loueth so this hende Nicholas
That Absolou may blowe þe bukkes horn
He ne hade for his labour but a skorn
And thus she maketh Absolon hir ape
And all his ernest turneth till a iape
Full soth is this ꝓprouꝰerbe yt ys no lye
Men seyn right thus all wey the nye slye
Maketh the ferre leef to be loth
For though that Absolon be wode or wroth
Bycause that he fer was from hir sight
This nye Nicholas stode in his lyght
Now bere the wele þou hende Nicholas
For Absolon may wayll and syng allas
And so befill yt that on a saterday
This Carpenter was gone till Osnay
And hende Nicholas and Alisou
Accorded ben to this conclusiou
That Nicholas shall shapen hem a wyle
The sely ielous housbond to begyle
And yf so be the game went aright
She shold slepe in his arme all night
For this was hir desire and his also
And right anone wtith out wordes mo
This Nicholas no lenger wold tarye
But doth full soft vn to his chambre carye
Both mete and drynke for a day or twey
And to hir housbond bade hir for to sey
Yf that he axed after Nicholas
She shold sey she nyst where he was
Of all þat day she saugh hi nat wtith ye
She trowed that he was in maladye
For no crye hir mayde kouth hi call
He nold answere for thing that might fall
This passeth forth all thyke saterday
That Nicholas styll in his chambre lay
And ete and slepte or did what hym lest
Till sonday that the sonne goth to rest
This sely Carpenter hath grete mꝰeruayle
Of Nicholas or what thing myght hi ayle
And seid I am adrad by seint Thomas
Yt stondeth nat aryght wtith Nicholas
God shelde that he dyed sodeinly
This werld ys now full tykell sekerly
I saw to day a corps yborn to chirche
That now on monday last I saw hi wirche
Go vp qd he vn to his knaue anone
Clepe at the dore and knok wtith a stone
Loke how yt ys and tell me boldely
This knaue goth hym vp full sturdely
And at the chambre dore while þtat he stode
He cryed and knokked as he were wode
What how what do ye maistꝰer Nicholay
How may ye slepen all the longe day
But all for nought he seide nat a worde
An hole he fonde full lowe vp on the borde
There as the cat was wont in for to crepe
And at þat hole he loked in full depe
And at the last he hade of hym a sight
This Nicholas sat euꝰer gapyng vp right
As he hade keked on the newe mone
Adoun he goth and telleth his maister sone
In what array he saugh this ylk man
This Carpenter to blessen hi began
And seide helpe vs seint Fredeswyde
A man wote litell what shall hi betide
This man is fallen wtith his Astronomy
In som wodenes or in som agony
I thought ay wele how þat yt sholde be
Men sholde nat knowe of goddes priuite
Ye blessed be alwey a lewde man
That nought but onely his byleue kan
So ferde an other clerk wtith his astronomye
He walked in the feldes for to prye
Vp on the sterres what there shold befall
Tyll þat he in a marle pyt was fall
He saweth nat þat but yit by seint Thomas
Me reweth sore of hende Nicholas
He shall be rated of his studeyng
Yf that I may by Ihc heven kyng
Gete me a staf þat I may vnder pore
While þat þou Robyn heuest of the dore
He shall out of his studeyng as I ges
And to the chambre dore he gan hi dres
His knave was strong carle for the nones
And by the haspe he haaf yt of at ones
In to the flore the dore fyll anone
This Nicholas sat ay as styll as ony stone
And euꝰer he gaped vpward in to the eyre
This Carpenter wende he were in despeyre
And hent hym by the sholdres mightely
And shoke hym harde and cried spitously
What Nicholay what how loke adoun
A wake and thinke on cristes passiou
I crouche þe from elves and from wightes
Therwtith the night spell seide he anone rightes
On foure halues of the hous aboute
And on the thresshfold at the dore wtithoute
Ihu crist and seint Benedyght
Blys this hous from euꝰery yuell wight
Fro the nightesmare the white patꝰer noster
Where wonest þow seint petres suster
And at the last this hende Nicholas
Gan for to sygh sore and seide allas
Shall all the werld be eftsones lost now
This Carpenter answered what seist þow
What think on god as we don men that swynke
This Nicholas answered fecche me drynke
And aftꝰer woll I speke in priuite
Of thing that toucheth the and me
I woll telle yt none other man certein
This Carpenter goth doun and comth ayein
And brought of mighty ale a large quarte
And whan þat eech of hem hade dronken his ꝑpert
This Nicholas his dore fast shete
And doun the Carpenter by hi he sete
And seid Iohn myn host lief and dere
Thow shalt vp on thy trewth swere me here
That to no wight thow shalt my counseill wrey
For it is cristes counseill þat I sey
Yf thow telle man þow art forlore
For this vengeaunce þou shalt haue therfore
That yf þou wrey me þou shalt be wode
Nay crist forbede yt for his holy blode
Koth þoo þis sely man I am no labbe
Ne though I sey I nam nat leef to gabbe
Sey what þou will I shall yt neuꝰer tell
To child ne wyf by hym þat harowed hell
Now Iohn qd this Nicholas I woll nat lye
I haue founden in myn Astrologye
As I haue loked in the mone bright
That now on monday next at quartꝰer night
Shall fall areyne and that so wylde and wode
That half so grete was neuꝰer Noes flode
This world he seide in las þan an houre
Shall be dreint so hidous is the shoure
Thus shall mankynde drenche and lese hir lyf
This Carpenter answered allas my wyf
And shall she drenche allas myn Alisou
For sorow of this he fell almost adou
And seide ys there no remedy in this cas
We yis for god qd hende Nicholas
Yf thow wolt werken after lore and rede
Thow maist nat werken after thine owen hede
For thus seith Salamou that was full trewe
Wyrk all by counsaill and þou shalt nat rewe
And if þou werken wolt by gode counsaill
I vndretake wtith out mast or saill
Yit shall I saue hir and the and me
Hast þou nat herde how saved was Noe
Whan that our lord hade warned hi byforn
That all the werld wtith water shold be lorn
Yis qd this Carpenter full yore ago
Hast þou nat herde qd Nicholas also
The sorow of Noe wtith his felawship
Er that he might gete his wyf to ship
Hym hade be lever I dare well vndretake
At thilke tyme þan all thise wethers blake
That she hade hade a ship hir self alone
And therfore wost þou what ys best to done
This asketh hast and of an hasty thing
Men may nat pꝰerche and maken tarying
Anone go gete vs fattes in to this Inne
A knedyng trough or elles a kemelyn
For ecch of vs but loke that they be large
In which we mowen swymme as in a barge
And haue there in vitayll suffisant
But for o day fy on the remenant
The water shall aslake and gon awey
About prime on the next day
But Robyn may nat wete of this thy knave
Ne eke thy mayde gylle I may nat save
Aske nat why for though þou ax me
I will nat telle goddes priuite
Suffiseth the but yf thy wyt is madde
To han as grete a grace as Noe hadde
Thy wyf shall I wele saven out of dout
Go now thy wey and spede the þꝰere about
But whan þou hast for hir and the and me
Ygeten vs thise knedyng tubbes iij .
Than shall þou hange he in the roof full hye
That noman of our purveaunce espie
And whan þou hast done as I haue seide
And hast our vitayle feire in hem leide
And eke an ax to smyte the corde a two
Whan that the water comth þtat we mow go
And breke an hole on hiegh vp on þe gable
Vn to the gardyn ward ouꝰer the stable
That we may frely passen forth our wey
Whan þat the grete shoure ys gon awey
Than shall þou swymme as mery I vndretake
As doth the white doke after hir drake
Than woll I clepe how Alisou how Iohn
Be mery for þe flode shall passe anone
And thow wolt seyn haill meister Nicholay
Gode morow I se the wele for it is day
And than shall we be lordes all our lyf
Of all the world as Noe and his wyf
But of o thing I warne the full right
Be we avised on that ilk nyght
That we ben entred in to shippes borde
That none of vs speke nat a worde
Ne clepe ne crye but ben in his parayer
For it is goddes owen hest dere
Thy wyf and þou mot hang fer a twynne
For þat bitwex þou shall be no synne
Namore in lokyng þan there shall be in dede
This ordinaunce ys seide go god þe spede
To morow at night whan men ben all slepe
In to our knedyng tubbes woll we crepe
And sitten there abidyng goddes garace
Go now thy wey I haue no lenger space
To maken of this no lenger sꝰermonynge
Men sein thus sende the wyse and sey no thing
Þou art so wys þat it nedeth the nought to teche
Go saue our lyf and þtat I the beseche
This sely Carpenter goth forth his wey
Full oft he seide alas and weleawey
And to his wyf he tolde his priuite
And she was ware and knewe it bet than he
What all this queynt case was for to sey
But natheles she ferde as she wold dey
And seide allas go forth thy wey anon
Help vs to skape or we be dede anon
I am thy trewe verray wedded wyf
Go dere spouse and helpe to saue our lyf
Lo which a grete thing ys affecciou
Men may dien of ymaginacou
So depe may impressiou be take
This sely Carpentꝰer bygenneth quake
Hym thinketh verraylych that he may se
Noes flode come walowyng as the se
To drenchen Alisou his hony dere
¶ He wepeth waylleth and maketh sory chere
He sygheth wtith full many a sory swogh
And goth and geteth hym a knedyng trough
And after a tubbe and a kemelyn
And priuely he sent he to his Inne
And hinge hem in the roof in priuite
His owen honde he made laddres thre
To clymben by the ronges and the stalkes
Vn to the Tubbes hangyng in the balkes
And hem vitayled both kemelyn trough and tubbe
Wtith brede and chese and gode ale in a Iubbe
Suffisyng ryght ynough as for a day
But er that he hade made all this aray
He sent his knave and eke his wenche also
Vp on his nede to londoūn for to go
And on the monday whan yt drough to night
He shete his dore wtith outen candell lyght
And dressed all thing as yt sholde be
And shortly vp they clymben all thre
They seten stille wele a forlong wey
Now pater noster clum seide Nicholay
And clum qd Iohn and clum seide Alisou
This Carpenter seide his deuociou
And still he sit and byddeth his prayere
Awaytyng on the reyne yf he yt here
The dede slepe for verray besynes
Fell on this Carpenter right as I ges
Aboute corfewe tyme or litell more
For travayll of his gost he groneth sore
And eft he routeth for his hede myslay
Doun on the laddre stalketh Nicholay
And Alisou full soft adoun she spedde
Wtith out wordes mo they gone to bedde
Where as this Carpenter ys wont to lye
There was the revell and the melodye
And thus lyen Alisou and Nicholas
In besynes of myrthe and in solas
To þat the bell of laudes gan to ryng
And freres in the chauncell gon synge
This paryssh Clerk this amerous Absolou
That is for loue all wey so wo bygon
Vp on the monday was at Osney
Wtith cumpany hym to disport and pley
And axed vp on cas a closterer
Full priuely after Iohn the Carpenter
And he drough hym aꝑpert out of þe chirch
I seid I not I saugh hym here nowth wirch
Seth satꝰerday I trowe þat he be went
For tymbre there our Abbot hath hi sent
For he is wont for tymbre for to go
And dwellen at þe graunge a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certein
Where that he be I kan nat sothly seyn
This Absolon full ioly was and light
And thought now ys tyme to wake all night
And sekerly I saugh hym nought steryng
About his dore senne day began to spryng
So mot I thryve I shall atte Cokkes crowe
Full priuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant full lowe on his bowres wall
To Alisou now will I telle all
My loue longyng for yit I shall nat mys
That at the last wey I shall hir kys
Som manꝰere comfort shall I haue ꝑperfay
My mouth hath ycched all this long day
This is a signe of kyssyng at the lest
All night me met eke that I was at a fest
Therfore I woll go slepe an houre or twey
And all the night than woll I wake and pley
Whan that the first kok hath crow anone
Vp ryst this ioly lover Absolou
And hym arayeth gay at poynt deuys
But first he cheweth grenys and lycorys
To smellen swete er he hade kemed his here
Vnder his rong a trewloue he bere
For there by wende he to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters hous
And still he stont vnder the short wyndowe
Vn to his brest yt raught yt was so lowe
And soft he coughed wtith a semy soun
What do ye honycombe swete Alisou
My feir bird my swete cinamome
A waketh leman myn and speketh to me
Wele litle thenken ye vp on my wo
That for your loue I swete there I go
No wonder ys though that I swelt and swete
I morne as doth a lambe after the tete
I wys leman I haue soch loue longyng
That lik a turtell trewe ys my morenyng
I may nat ete nomore than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iak fole she seyde
As helpe me god yt woll nat be compame
I loue an other and elles I were to blame
Wele bet than the by Ihu Absolou
Go forth thy wey or I wyll cast a stou
And lete me slepe a twenty deuell wey
Allas qd Absolou and wele away
That treweloue was euꝰer so yvell byset
Than kys me seth yt may be no bet
For Ihc loue and for the loue of me
Wyll thow þan go thy wey þꝰerwtith qd she
Ye certes leman qd this Absolou
Than make the redy qd she I com anone
This Absolou doun set hym on his knees
And seide I am a lorde at all degrees
For after this I hope there comth more
leman thy grace and swete bird thine ore
The wyndowe she vndoth and that in hast
Haue done qd she com of and spede the fast
Lest that our neighbours the espie
This Absolou gan wype his mouth full drye
Derke was the night as pycch or as the cole
And at the wyndowe out she put her hole
And Absolon hym fell no bet ne wers
But wtith his mouth he kist hir naked ers
Full saverly er he were ware of this
A bak he stert and þoght yt was amys
For wele he wist a womman hade no berde
He felt a thing all rough and long yhered
And seide fy allas what haue I do
Te he qd she and clapped the wyndowe to
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berde a berde seide hende Nicholas
By goddes corpus this goth feire and wele
This sely Absolou herde euy dele
And on his lip for anger he gan to bite
And to hym self he seide I shall the quyte
Who robbeth now who froteth now his lippes
Wtith dust wtith sonde wtith strawe wtith cloth with chippes
But Absolon þat seith full oft allas
My soule betake I vn to Sathanas
But me were leuer than all this toun qd he
Of this despite awreken for to be
Allas qd he allas I ne hade yblent
His hote loue was colde and all yqueynt
For fro that tyme that he hade kist hir ers
Of ꝑperamours ne rought he nat a kers
For he was heled of his maladye
Full oft ꝑperamours he gan defye
And wepe as doth a child þat ys ybete
A soft paas he went hym ouꝰer the strete
Vn to a Smyth men callen daun Gerveys
That in his forge smythed plough harneys
He sharpeth share and culter besely
This Absolon knokketh all esely
And seide vndo Gerveys and that anone
What who art þou yt am I Absolou
What Absolou what cristes swete tre
Why ryse ye so rathe ey benedicite
What ayleth you sōmme gay girle god yt wote
Hath brought you thus vp on the viritote
By seint Note ye wete what I mene /
This Absolou ne rought nat a bene
Of all his pley no word agein he yaf
He hade more thought on his distaf
Than Gerveys knewe and seide frende so dere
That hote culter in the chymney here
As lene yt me I haue there wtith to done
I will bryng yt the ageyn full sone
Gerveys answerd certes were yt golde
Or in a poke nobles all vn tolde
Thow sholdest haue yt as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes fo what woll ye do there wtith
There of qd Absolou be as be may
I shall wele telle yt the an other day
And caught the culter by the hote stele
Full soft out at the dore he gan to stele
And went vn to the Carpenters wall
He coughed first and knokketh there wtith all
Vp on the wyndowe right as he did ere
This Alisou answerd who ys there
That knokketh so I warant yt ys a thefe
Nay nay qd he god wote my swete lefe
I am thine Absolou thy derelyng
Of gold qd he I haue the brought a ryng
My modre yaf yt me so god me save
Full fyne yt ys and there to wele ygrave
This woll I yeve the yf þou me kysse
This Nicholas was rysen to pysse
He thought he wold amende all þe iape
He shold kys his ers er that he skape
And vp þe wyndowe he did hastelye
And out his ers he putteth priuely
Ouꝰer the buttok to the haunche bon
And þꝰere wtith spak this Clerk this Absolou
Speke swete bird I note where þou art
This Nicholas anone lete fle a fart
As grete as yt hade ben a thundre dynt
That wtith the stroke he was almost yblynt
And he was redy wtith his yren hote
And Nicholas in the ers he smote
Of goth the skynne an hanbrede aboute
The hote culter brent so his toute
That for the smert he wende for to dye
As were wode for wo he gan to crye
Help water water help for goddes hert
This Carpentꝰer out of his slomer stert
And herd one crye watꝰer as he were wode
And thought allas now comth Noes flode
He set hym vp wtithout wordes mo
And with his ax he smote the cord a two
And doun goth all he fonde neyther to sell
Ne brede ne ale tyll he cam to the celle
Vp on þe flore and there a swowne he lay
Vp stirt hir Alisou and Nicholay
And criden out and harow in þe strete
The neigheborurs both smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawen on this man
That in swownyng lay both pale and wan
For wtith the fall he broken hade his arme
But stonde he most vn to his owen harme
For whan he spake he was anone borne dou
Wtith hende Nicholas and Alisou
They tolden euꝰery man þat he was wode
He was agast so of Noes flode
Thurgh fantasye that of his vanite
He hade bought hym knedyng tubbes iij
And hade hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he prayde hem for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof ꝑper cumpany
The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
In to the roof they kekyn and they gape
And turned all his harme vn to a iape
For what so þat þis Carpentꝰer answerd
Yt was for nought no man his resou herd
Wtith othes grete he was so sworn adou
That he was holden wode in all þe tou
For euꝰery clerk anone helde wtith other
He seide the man was woode my leef brother
And euꝰery wyght gan laughen of þis stryf
Thus swyved was the Carpenters wyf
For all his kepyng and his ielousye
And Absolon hath kyst hir nether yee
And Nicholas is scalded in the tout
This tale is done and god save all þe rout
(base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale

(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth

(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng

div.l: (base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete

(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose

(base) The person of the toun hir fader was

(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame

(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo

div.l: (base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so

(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was

div.l: (base) He craked boost and swoor it was noght so

div.l: (base) For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort

div.l: (base) Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa

div.l: Of a ꝓproverbe that seith this same woord
Wele better is roten Apple out of hoord

And for there is no theef wtithout a lowke

(base) Now goode fader mercy I yow crye
(base) Seend me namoore vnto noon hethenesse
(base) But thonke my lord heere of his kyndenesse
(base) Who kan the pitous Ioye tellen al
(base) Bitwix hem thre syn they be thus ymette
(base) But of my tale make an ende I shal
(base) The day goth faste I wol no lenger lette
(base) This glade folk to dyner they hem sette

(base) A thousand fold wel moore than I kan telle
(base) This child Maurice was sithen Emperour

(base) With his Custaunce his holy wif so swete
(base) To Engelond been they come the righte way
(base) Wher as they lyue in ioye and in quiete
(base) But litel while it lasteth I yow heete
(base) Ioye of this world for tyme wol nat abyde
(base) Fro day to nyght it chaungeth as the tyde
(base) Who lyued euere in swich delit a day
(base) That hym ne moeued outher Conscience
(base) Or Ire or talent or som kyn affray
(base) Enuye or pryde or passion or offence
(base) I ne seye but for this ende this sentence
(base) That litel while in ioye or in plesaunce
(base) Lasteth the blisse of Alla with Custaunce
(base) For deeth that taketh of heigh and logh his rente
(base) Whan passed was a yeer euene as I gesse

(base) And whan that she hir fader hath yfownde

(base) Wepynge for tendrenesse in herte blythe
(base) She herieth god an hondred thousand sythe
(base) In vertue and holy almus dede
