Hic finitur legis periti ⁊ incipit Prologus vxoris de Bathe
Exꝑperience though noon auctoritee
Were in this world / is right ynough for me .
To speken of woo that is in mariage .
But lordynges sen I .xii. wynter was of age .
Thanked be god that is eterne on lyve .
Husbondes atte chirch dore haue I hade .v.
Yf I so often myght haue wedded be .
And al weren worthy men in her degree
But me was told nat long agon is
That crist ne went never but ones
To weddyng in the caan of Galilee .
That by the same ensaumple taught he me .
That I ne wedded shold be but ones
Lo herken which a sharp worde for the nones
Beside a welle Ihc god and man .
Spake in repreef of the Samaritan
Þu hast hade .v. housbondes koth he .
And that ilk man / that now hath the
Is nat thyn housbond / þus he seid certeyn
What that he ment there by / I can nat seyn
But I aske why the .v.th man .
Was nat housbond to þe Samaritan .
How many myght she haue in mariage
But herd I neuer tellen in myn age .
Of this nombre diffiniciou
Men may deme / and glosen up and doun
But wele I wote expresse wtithouten lye .
God bade us wex and multiplye .
That gentle text can I wele vnderstonde .
For wele I wote that myn housbonde .
Shold lete fader and moder and take to me .
But of no numbre menciou made he .
Of bygame / or of Octogamye .
Why shold men speke of it velanye
Lo here the wise kyng Salamon
I trowe he hade wifes mo than oon
As wold god . it liefful were to me .
To be refresshed half so oft as he
Which a yifte . of god had he / for al his wyfes
No man hath soch that now on lyve is .
God wote this noble kyng as to my witte
The first nyght hade many a mery fitte
With ecch of hem / so wele was hym on lyve .
Blessed be god that I haue wedded .v.
Of which I haue pikked out the best
Both of her nether purs / and of her chest.
Diuers scoles maketh diuers clerkes
And diuꝰers practyk / in many a sonder werkes
Maketh the ꝑperfite man sekerly
Of .v. husbondes scolyng am I .
Welcom the . sext whan þat ever he shal
I wol hym nat forsake no thing at al
Whan that my husbond is from þe werld gon
Som cristen man shal wedde me anon
For the postle seith that I am free .
To wedde a goddeshalf where it liketh me
He seith to be wedded is no synne ;
Bette is to be wedded than to brynne .
What rekketh me / þough men sey velanye
Of shrewed lameth / and of his bigamye
I wote wele Abraham was an holy man .
And eke Iacob / as fer as heren I can .
And ecch of hem hade wyues mo than two
And many another man also
Where can ye sey in ony maner age
That hie god diffended mariage
By expresse wordes I pray you telleth me
Or where commaunded he virginite
I wote as wele as ye / it is no drede
The Apostle whan he speketh of maydenhede
He seith that pꝰercept there of hade he noon
Men may counseil a womman to be oon
But counseil is no cōmmaundement
He putteth it / in our owen Iugement
For hade god cōmmaunded maydenhede
Than hade he dampned weddyng out of drede
And certes yf there were no sede ysowe
Virginitee þan / whereof shold it growe
Poule durst nat commaund atte leest.
A thyng of which his maister yaaf none heest
The dart is sette vp for virginitee ;
Caccheth who so may who renneth best let se
But this worde is nat take of euꝰery wight
But there that god wol yeve it of his myght
I wote wele the Apostle was a meide .
But natheles though he wrote and seide .
He wold that euꝰery wight were as he
Al nys but counceil to virginitee .
And for to ben a wyf he yave me leve .
Of Indulgence so it is nat to repreve .
To wedde me / yf that my make dye .
Wtithout excepciou of bygamye .
Al were it gode / no womman for to touch
He ment in his bedde / or on his couch
For ꝑperil is / fire and towe to assemble
Ye knowe what þis saumple may resemble .
This al and som / he heeld virginitee .
More ꝓprofite / þan weddyng in frealtee
Frealte clepe I / but yf that he and she .
Wold leden her lyf in chastitee .
I graunt / it / wele / I haue noon envie .
Though maydenhede pꝰerferr bigamye .
It liketh hem to be cleen in body and goost /
Of myn astate I wol make no bost
Ful wele ye knowe a lord in his houshold .
Hath nat euery vessel / al of gold .
Som ben of tree / and doon her lord ꝸseruyse
God klepeth to hym folk / in sondrye wise ;
And euꝰerycch hath of god a ꝓpropre yifte ;
Som this / som þat / as hym list to shifte .
Virginitee is grete ꝑperfecciou
And continence eke wtith deuocou
But Crist that of ꝑperfecciou is wel
Bade nat euery wight he shold go sel
Al that he hade / and yeve it to þe pore
And in soch wise folow hym and his fore
He spake to hem þat wold lyve ꝑperfitely
And lordyngs by your leve / þat am nat I
I wol bestowe the flour of al myn age .
In the actes and in fruyt of mariage .
Tel me also to what conclusiou
Were membres made of genꝰeracou
And of so ꝑperfite wise a wyght ywrought
Trust right wele / þey were nat made for nought
Glose who so wol and sey both vp and doun
That they were made / for purgaciou
Of vryn and other thinges smale
Was eke to knowe a female from a male
And for noon other cause seye ye noo
The exꝑperience wote wele / it is nat soo
So that the clerkes / be nat wtith me wroth
I sey thus that they maked been for both
That is to seyn for office and for ease ;
Of engendrure / there we nat god displese
Why shold men elles in her bokes sette
That man shal yeld to his wyf hir dette .
Now where wtith shold he make his payement
Yf he ne vsed his sely instrument
Than were they made / vpon a creature .
To pourge vryn / and eke for engendrure
But I sey nat euꝰery wight is hold .
Þat hath soch hneys / as I you told .
To gon and vse hem in engendrure
Than shold men take of chastitee no cure .
Crist was a maide / and shapen as a man
And many an holy seint setth þe world bygan
Yitte lyved þey ever in ꝑperfite chastitee .
I nyl envie no virginitee
Let hem be bredde of pured whete seed
And let vs wyfes hote / Barly brede ;
And yitte wtith barly brede / marke tel can
Our lord Ihu refresshed many a man
In soch a state as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑpersever I am nat precious
In wyfhode wol I vse myn Instrument
As frely as my maker hath it sent
Yf I be daungerous / god yeve me sorow
Myn husbond shal it haue both eve and morow
Whan that hym list com forth and paie his dette
An husbond wol I haue / I wol nat lette .
Which shal be both my dettour and my thral.
And haue his tribulacou wtith al
Vp on his flessh while þat I am his wyf.
I haue þe power duryng al my lyf.
Vp on his propre body / and nat he
Right thus the Appostle told it vn to me
And bade our husbondes / for to love vs wele
Al this sentence / me liketh euꝰery dele .
Vp stert the pardoner / and that anoon
Now dame koth he by god and by seint Iohn
Ye ben a noble prechour in this caas
I was about to wedde a wyf allas
What / shold I bye it on my flessh so dere .
Yitte hade I lever wedde no wyf to yere .
Abide koth she / my tale is nat bygon
Nay þu shalt drynk of another ton
Or that I go / shal savorur wors than ale
And whan that I haue toold forth my tale
Of tribulacou þat is in mariage
Of which I am expert in al myn age
This is to sey / my self hath ben the whip
Than maist þu chese whether þtat þu wolt skip
Of thyk ton / that I shal abroche
Be ware of it / or þu to nye approche .
For I shal tel ensaumples mo þan . x .
Who so þtat nyl be ware by other men .
By hym shal other men / corrected be .
Thise same wordes writeth ꝓprotholome
Rede in his Almagest and take it there
Dame I wol pray you / yf your wil were .
Seid this ꝑperdoner / as ye bygan
Telleth forth yorur tale / spareth for no man
And techeth vs yong men of your practyke
Gladly koth she / sen þat it may you like
But þat I pray to al this companye .
If that I speke after my fantasye
As taketh it nat a greef of that I sey
For myn entent is / but for to pley /
Now sires than I wol tel you forth my tale
As ever mot I drynk wyn or ale
I shal sey soth / thos husbondes þat I hade ;
As .iij . of hem were gode and . ij . were bade
The .iij. men were gode riche and olde
Vnneth myght þey the statuyt holde .
In which they were bounden vn to me
Ye wote wele what I mene of þis ꝑperde
As help me god I laugh whan I thynk
How pitouly a nyght I made hem swynk
And by my fey I told of it no store .
Þey hade me yeven her londe / and her tresore
Me neded nat do lenger diligence
To wyn her love / or don hem reuꝰerence .
They loued me so wele by god aboue .
That I ne told no deyntee of her loue
A wise wōmman wol besye hir ever in on
To gete hir loue / there she hath noon
But seth I hade hem holy in myn hond .
And after þey haden yeve me her lond .
What shold I take kepe hem for to plese .
But yf it were / for my ꝓprofite and myn ese .
I sette hem so a werk be my fey
That many a nyght þey syngen weleawey
The bacou was nat fette for hem I trowe
That som men hath in Essex at Dunmowe
I gouꝰerned hem so wele after my lawe .
That ecch of hem ful blisful were and fawe .
To bryng me gaye thynges from the feir
Þey were ful feyn whan I spake to hem feir
For god it wote / I chid hem spitously
Now herkeneth how I bare me ꝓproprely
Ye wise wyfes / þat can vnderstonde
Þus shold ye speke and bere hem on honde .
For half so boldely can there no man
Swere and lye / as a womman can .
I sey nat this by wyfes þat ben wise
But yf it be / whan they hem mysavise
A wise wyf / yf that she can hir gode
Shal bere hym on honde the kowe is wode .
And take witnes of hir owen meid .
Of hir assent but herkeneth how I seid .
Sire old kaynard is this thyn array
Why is my neighborurs wyf so gay
She is honoured / ouꝰer al ther she goth
I sit at home I haue no thrifty cloth
What dost þu at my neighbours hous / .
Is she so feir art þu . so amarous
What roun ye wtith our maid benedicite .
Sir old lechour let thy iapes be
And yf that I haue a gossyp or a frend .
Wtith out gilt ye chide as a fend .
Yf þat I walk and pley to his hous
Thow comst home as drunk as a mous
Þu prechest on thy benche wtith euyl preef
Þu seist to me it is a grete myschief
To wedde a poure wōmman for costage
And yf she be riche of hie ꝑperage
Than seist þu / þat it is a turmentrie
To suffre hir pride / and hir malyncolie .
And yf she be feir / þu verray knave .
Thow seist / that euꝰery holour wol hir haue .
She may no while in chastitee abide .
That is assailed vp on ecch a side .
Thow seist som folk desire vs for ricchesse .
Som for our shap and som for our fairenesse .
And som for outher she can syng or daunce
And som for gentilnes and daliaunce
Som for hir armes / and hir hondes smale .
Thus goth al to þe deuyl be thy tale .
Þu seist men may kepe a castel wal
It may so long asseiled be ouꝰeral
And yf þat she be foule þu seist þat she
Coueiteth euꝰery man þat she may se
For as a spanyel she wol on hym lepe .
Til that she fynd som man hir to chepe
Ne noon so gray goos goth þere in þe lake
As seist þu wol be wtithout a make
And seist it is an harde þyng for to weld
A thyng þat no man wold his thankes held
Þu seist þu lorel whan þu gost to bed
And þat no wise man nedeth for to wed
Ne no man þat entendeth vn to heuen
Wtith wild fire / and thunder leuen .
Mot thy wykked nek / be to broke
Þu seist that the droppyng hous and eke smoke
And chidyng wyfes / maken men for to flee
Out of her owen houses / a benedicite ;
What ayleth soch an old man forto chide
Þu seist we wyfes wol our vices hide
Til we ben fast and than we wol hem shewe
Wele may that be a proverbe of a shrewe .
Þu seist that Oxen Asses hors and houndes
They ben assaied at diuꝰers stoundes
Basyns lauours / or that men hem bye .
Spones stoles / and al soch husbondrye .
And so ben pottes clothes and array
But folk of wyfes maken noon assay
Til þey be wedded old dotard shrewe
And þan seist þu / we wol our vices shewe
Thow seist also / that it displeseth me
But yf þat þu wolt preise my beaute
And but þu poure al wey vp on my face
And clep faire dame in every place .
And but þu make a fest vp on thyk day
That I was born / and make me fressh and gay
And but þu do to my norissh honour
And to my chambre wtith in my bour
And to my fadres folk and his alies
Thus seist þu old barel ful of lies
And yitte for our Appꝰerntice Ianekyn
For his krips here / shinyng as gold fyn
And for he squyerth me both vp and doun
Yitte hast þu caught fals suspeciou
I wol hym nat / þough þu were dede to morow
But tel me this why hidest þu wtith sorow
The keyes of thy chest al wey from me
It is myn gode / aswele as thyn ꝑperde
What wenes þu to make an ydeot of our dame
Now by þat lord þat cleped is seint Iame
þu shalt nat both / þough þtat þu were wode
Be maister of my body / and of my gode .
That one þu shalt forgon maugre thyn eyen
What nedeth the of me / to enquere and spien
I trowe þu woldest lok me in thy chest
þu sholdest sey gode wyf go where þu lest
Taketh your desport I wol leue no tales .
I knowe you for a true wyf dame Alice
We loue no man that taketh kepe or charge
Where þat we gon / we wol be at our large
Of al men blessed mot / he be
þe wise Astrologien Daune ꝓprotholomee
That seith this ꝓproverbe in his almgeest
Of al men his wisdom is the best
That rekketh nat / whoo hath the world in honde
By this ꝓproverbe þu shalt vnderstond .
Haue ye ynough / what dare ye rek or kare .
How merely that other folkes fare
For certes old dotard by yorur leve
Ye shul haue queynt ynough at eve
He is to grete a nygard þtat wol wern
A man to lighten a candel at his lantern
He shal haue never þe lesse light ꝑperdee
Haue þu ynough / þu darst nat pleyn thee
Þu seist also / yf we make vs gay
Wtith clothyng or wtith pꝰercious array
That it is ꝑperel of our chastitee
And yitte wtith sorow þu most enforcen the
And seyn thise wordes in þe aposteles name
In habit made in chastitee / and shame
Yee women shold aꝑperꝑperel you koth he
And nought in tressed here and riche perre
As perles ne wtith gold ne clothes riche
After þy text / ne after þe ruberiche
I wol nat werche as moch / as is a gnat .
Þu seist þus / I walk out like a cat .
But who so wol senge þe cattes skyn
Þan wold þe cat wel dwellen in his yn
And yf þat þe cattes skyn be sleght and gay
She wol nat dwel in hous half a day
But forth she wol or ony daie be dawed .
To shewe hir skyn and goon a caterwawed .
This is to sey / yf I be gay sire shrewe ;
I wol ren out my berel for to shewe ;
Sire old fole / what helpeth þe to aspien
Þough þu preis Argus wtith his .C. yien
To be my warde coors as he may best
In feith he shal nat kepe me but me lest
Yitte coude I make his berd so mot I the
Þu seist eke / þat ther ben thynges .iij.
The which thinges troublen al þis erth
And that no wight / may endure the ferth
O leue sir shrewe / Ihc short thy lyve .
Yitte pꝰerchest þu an seist / an hateful wyve
Rekned is / for one of thise meschaunces
Beth ther noon other resemblaunces
That ye may lykken your ꝑperables to
But yf a sely wyf / be one of thoo
Þu lykkenest wōmmans loue eke to hel
To baren lond / there water may nat dwel
Þu lykenest vs eke to wild fire
The more it brenneth þe more it hath desire
To consume euꝰery thyng that brent wol be
Thow seist right as wormes shenden a tree .
Right so a wyf destroieth hir husbond .
This knowen they þat ben to wyfes bond .
Lordyns right thus as ye vnderstond
Bare I stifly myn old husbondes on hond
That thus þey seiden in her dronkonnes
And al was fals but as I toke witnes
Of Iankyn / and of my nece also
O lord the peyn þat I did hem and þe woo
Ful giltles by goddes swete pyn
For as an hors I coude byte and swyn
I coude pleyn / þough I were in þe gilt
Or els often tyme I hade ben spilt
Who þtat comth first to the myl / first he grynt
I pleyned first / and so was our werr ystynt .
They were ful glad to excuse hem belyve .
Of thyng which þey never gilt her lyve
Of wenches wold I bere hem on honde
Whan þat for seek vnneth myght þey stonde
Yitte tykeled I his hert for that he
Wend þat I of hym hade so grete chierte
I swore that al my walkyng out by nyght
Was for to spie wenches that he dight
Vnder þat colour had I many a mirth
For al soch thyng was yoven vs in our birth
Disceite / wepyng / spynnyng / god hath yeve
To wōmmen kyndely while þat þey may lyve
And thus of oo thyng I auaunt me
At þe ende I hade the better in ecch degree
By sleight or force / or by som maner thyng
As by contynuel murmur or grucchyng
And namely a bed haden they meschaunce
There wold I chide and do hem no plesaunce .
I wold no lenger in the bed abide
Yf that I felt his arme over my side
Til he hade made his raunsom vn to me
Than wold I suffre hym / do his necessitee .
And therfore this tale euꝰery man I tel
Wyn who so may / for al is for to sel
Wtith empty hondes men may noon haukes lure
For wynnyg / wold I al his lust endure
And make me a feyned appetite
And yitte in bacou hade I neuꝰere delite ;
That made me / that ever I wold hem chide .
For though þe pope hade seten hem beside
I wold nat spare hem at her owen borde
For by my trouth I quytte hem euꝰery worde
As help me verray god ompnypotent
Though I right now shold make my testament
I owe hem nat a worde þat it nys quytte
I brought it so about by my witte
That they most yeve it vp / as for þe best
Or els hade we never ben in rest
For though he loked as wode as a lyou
Yitte shold he faile of his conclusiou
Than wold I sey gode leef take kepe
How mekely loketh wilkyn our shepe .
Com nere my spouse let me ba thy cheke
Ye shold be al pacient and meke
And han a swete spiced conscience
Seth yee so preche of Ioobes pacience .
Suffreth al wey setth ye so wele can pꝰerche .
And but ye do / certeyn we wol you teche
That it is fair a man to haue a wyf in pees
One of vs two most bow doutlees
And seth a man is more resonable .
Than womman is ye most ben suffrable
What ayeleth you thus to grucche and grone
It is for ye wold haue my queynte allone
We take it al lo haue it eueridele
Peter I shrewe you / but ye loue it wele
For yf I wold sel my beal chose
I coude walk as fressh as ys a rose
But I wol kepe it for yorur owen toth
Ye be to blame / by god I sey you soth
Soch maner wordes hade we on honde
Now wol I speke of my first housbonde .
My first housbond was a reuelour
This is to sey he hade a ꝑperamour
And I was yong and ful of ragerie .
Styborurne and strong and ioly as a pye
Wele couth I daunce and harp smale
And syng ywys as ony Nyghtyngale .
Whan I hade drunk a draught of swete wyn
Metellius the foule cherle the swyn
That wtith a staf / byraft his wyf / hir lyf
For she drank wyn / though I hade ben his wyf
He shold nat haue daunted me from drynk
And after wyn on venus most I thynk .
For also syker / as cold engendreth hail
A likerous mouth / most haue a likerous tail
In wommen vynolent / is no diffence
This knowen lechours by exꝑperience .
But lord crist whan than it remembreth me .
Vp on my youth / and on my Iolitee .
It tekeleth me / about myn hert rote
Vn to this day / it doth myn hert bote
That I haue hade my werld as in my tyme .
But age allas that al wol envenyme .
Hath me byraft my beaute and my pyth
Let go fare wele / the devel go ther wyth
The flour is goon / there is no more to tel
The bran as I best may now mot I sel
Now yitte to be right mery / wol I fond
Now wol I tel of my .ij. housbond .
I sey I hade in hert grete despite .
That he of ony other hade delite
But he was quytte by god and by seint Ioce .
I made hym of the same wode a croce
Nat of my body in no foule manere
But certeynly I made folk soch chere .
That in his owen grees I made hīn frie
For angre / and for verray Ielousie .
By god in erth I was his purgatorie .
For which I hope / his soule be in glorie
For god it wote / he sate ful oft and song
Whan that his sho ful / bitterly hym wrong.
There was no wight save god / and he / þtat wist
In many wise how sore I hym twist .
He seid whan I cam from Ierlm
And lyth in grave / vnder the rode beem
Al is his toumbe nought so curious
As was the sepulcre of hym Darius
Which that Apelles / wrought subtelly .
It nys but waast to bery hym pꝰerciously .
Let hym fare wele / god yeve his soule gode rest /
He is now in grave / and dede in his chest /
Now of my .iijde . housbond wol I tel
God let his soule never com in hel
And yitte was he to me the most shrewe
That fele I on my ribbes al by rewe ;
And euer shal vn to myn endyng day
But in our bed / he was ful fressh and gay
And ther wtith al / so wele kouth he glose
Whan that he wold haue my beal chose
That though he hade me bette on euꝰery bone
He couth wynne ageyn / my love anoon
I trowe I loued hym best / for that he .
Was of his love so daungerous to me
We wommen han yf that I shal nat lye
In this mater a queynt fantasye /.
Wayte what thyng / we may nat lightly haue
There after wol we krie / and al day craue .
Forbede vs thyng and that desiren we .
Prees on vs and than wol we flee
Wtith daunger vttre we al our chaffare .
Greet prees at market maketh dere ware
And to grete chepe / is hold at litle prys
This knoweth euꝰery womman þtat is wis
My .iiij. housbond / god his soule blys
Which I toke for loue / and no riches
He som tyme was a clerk of Oxenford .
And hade left scole / and went at hoom to borde
Wtith my gossyb dwellyng in our toun
God haue hir soule / hir name was Alisou
She knewe myn hert and eke my piriuetee
Bet than our ꝑperissh preest so mot I the
To hir bewried I my counseil al
For hade myn housbond pissed on a wal
Or don a thyng / þat shold han cost his lyf
To hir and to another worthy wyf
And to my nece / which that I loued wele .
I wold haue told his counseil euꝰery dele .
And so I did ful often god it wote
That made his face / ful often rede and hote
For verray shame / and blamed hym self þat he .
Hade told to me / so grete a pryvetee ;
And so befel that ones in a lent
So oft tymes / I to my gossyb went
For ever yitte I loued to be gaye
And for to walk in Marche April and Maye
From hous to hous / to here sondrie tales
That Ienkyn Clerk / and my gossyp dame Ales
And I my self in to the feldes went
Myn housbond was at londou al þat lent
I hade the better leiser for / to pleye
And for to se / and eke for to be seye
Of lusty folk what wost I where my grace
Was shapen for to be / and in what place
Therfore I made my visitacoūns
To vigiles / and to ꝓprocessions .
To pꝰerchyng eke / and to thise pilgrymages .
To pleyes of myracles / and to mariages .
And wered vp on my gay scarlet gites
Thise wormes ne thise motthes / ne thise mytes
Vp on my ꝑperail frette hem never a dele
And wost þu why / for they were vsed so wele
Now wol I tel forth what happened me .
I sey þat in the feldes walked we
Til truely we hade soch daliaunce
This Clerk and I . what of my purveaunce .
I spake to hym / and seid how that he
Yf I were widow he shold wed me .
For certeyn I sey for none auaunce
Yitte was I never wtithout purveaunce
Of mariage ne of other thynges eke
I hold a mous hert nat worth aleke
That hath but one hole for to stirt to
And yf that faile / than is al ydoo
I bare hym on honde he hade enchaunted me
My dame taught me that sotiltee .
And eke I seid I met of hym al nyght
He wold haue slayn me / as I lay vpright
And al my bed was ful of verray blode
But yitte I hope / þat ye shal do me gode
For blode betokeneth gold as me was taught
And al was fals / I dremed of hym right naught
But as I folowed ay my dames lore
As wele of that as of other thynges more
And now sir / let me se / what shold I seyn
A ha by god / I haue my tale ageyn
Whan that my .iiijth. housbond was on bere .
I wepte al gate / and made sory chere .
As wyfes moten / for it is vsage .
And wtith my kerchif I coverd my visage
But for that I was / purveied of a make
I wept / but smal I vndertake
To chirche was myn housbond born amorowe
Wtith neighbours that for hym maden sorowe
And Iankyn our clerk / was one of tho
As help me god / whan that I sawe hym go
After the bere / me thought he hade a peir
Of legges and of fete / so clene and so feir
That al myn hert I yave vn to his holde
He was I trowe a .xxtiri. wynter old .
And I was .xl. yf I shal sey the soth
But yitte I hade al wey a coltissh tooth
Gaptothed I was / and þat / bycam me wele
I hade the preent of Seint Venus sele .
As help me god I was a lustione .
And feir and riche / and yong / and wele begone
And truely as myn housbondes toold me
I hade the best quoniam þtat myght be .
For certes I am al venerien
In felyng and myn hert is Marcien
Venus me yaaf my lust / my lykerousnesse
And Mars yave me my sturdy hardynesse
Myn ascendent was Taur / and Mars ther in
Allas allas þat ever love was sin
I folowed ay myn Inclynacou
By vꝰertue of my constellaciou
That made me I coude nat wtithdrawe
My chambre of Venus from a gode felawe
Yitte haue I Mars mark vp on my face
And also in another pryve place
For god so wise be my savacou
I loued never by no discrecou
But ever folowed myn appetite .
Al were he short long blak or white
I toke no kepe / so that he liked me
How poure he was / ne eke of what degre .
What shold I sey / but atte monethes ende
This ioly Clerk Iankyn / þtat was so hende
Hath wedded me wtith grete solempnytee
And to hym yave I / al þe lond and fee
Þat ever was me yoven there to fore
But aftꝰerward me repented ful sore
He nold suffre no thyng of my list
By god he smote ones wtith his fist
On þe cheke / for I rent out / of his boke a leef
That of þe stroke / myn ere wex al deef / .
Styborurne I was / as ys a leonesse
And of my tung a verray Iangeleresse .
And walk I wold as I hade don byforn
From hous to hous / al though he hade it sworn
For which he often tyme wold preche .
And me of old romans gestes teche .
How he symplicius / Gallus left his wyf.
And hir forsoke for tꝰerme of al his lyf.
Nought but for open hede he hir say
Lokyng out at his dore vp on a day
A nother Roman / told he me by name .
That for his wyf was at a somꝰers game
Wtith outen his wetyng he forsoke hir eke .
And than wold he vp on his bible seke
Thaylk ꝓprouerbe of ecclesiaste
Where he cōmmaunded and forbedeth /fast.
Man shal nat suffre his wyf go roile /about.
Than wold he sey thus wtithouten dout.
¶ Who so beildeth his hous al of Salowes
And prykketh his blynd hors over þe falowes
And suffreth his wyf / to go seken halowes
Is worthy to be hanged vp on the galowes
But al for nought I set nat an hawe
Of al his ꝓproverbes / ne of his old sawe .
Ne I wold nat of hym corrected be .
I hate hym that my vices telleth me
And so don mo god wote of vs than .I.
This made hym wtith me wode al vtterly
I nold nat for bere hym in no caas
Now I wol sey you soth / by seint Thomas
Why that I rent out of his boke a leef.
For which he smote me so / þat I was deef.
He hade a boke / that gladly nyght and day /
For his desport he wold rede al way
He cleped it Valerie and Theofaste
At which boke / he lough al wey ful fast
And eke there was a clerk som tyme of Rome
A Cardenal / that hight som tyme seint Ierome /
That made a book ageyn Iovinian .
In which boke eke / there was Tertulan .
Crispus Trotula and Helowes
That was Abbas nat fer from Paryes
And eke the ꝑperables of Salamon
Ouydes art and bokes many on
And al thise were bound in a volume
And euꝰery nyght and day was his custume .
Whan he hade leiser and vacacou
From other worldly occupacou
To reden on this boke of wikked wyues
He knewe of hem mo legendes and lyves .
Than ben of gode wyfes in the bible
For trusteth wele / it is an inpossible .
That ony Clerk wol speke gode of wyues
But yf it be of holy seintes lyves
Ne of noon other wommen never the mo
Who paynted þe lyou / tel me whoo
By god yf wommen had writen stories
As Clerkes han wtith in her oratories
They wold haue writ of men more wykkednesse
Than al the Marke of Adam may redresse
The children of Mercurie and venus
Been in her werkyng ful contrarious /
Mercurie loueth wisdom and science .
And venus / loueth riot and dispence .
And for her diuꝰers disposicou
Ecch falleth in others exaltacou
And thus god wote / Mercurie is dissolate
In pisses / whan venus is exaltate .
And venus falleth / there Mercurie is reised
Therfore no womman / of no clerk is preised .
The Clerk whan he is old and may nat do
Of venus werkes / worth his old shoo
Than sit he doun / and writeth in his dotage
That wommen can nat kepe her mariage
But now to purpoos why I told þe
That I was beten for a boke ꝑperde
Vp on a nyght Iankyn þat was our sire
Red on his boke / as he sat by þe fire .
Of Eve first / þat for hir wykkednes
Was al mankynd brought to wrecchednes /
ffor which that Ihu Crist hym self was slayn
That bought vs wtith his hert blode agayn
Lo here expresse of women may ye fynd.
That womman was the losse of al mankynd
Tho redde he me how Sampsou lost his /heres
Slepyng his lemman kit it wtith hir sheres
Thurgh which tresou lost he both his yien
Tho redde he me / yf þat I shal nat lien
Of Hercules and of Dyanyre .
That caused hym / to set hym self a fire .
No thyng forgate he / the sorow and the woo
That Socrates hade wtith his wyfes .ij.
How exantyppa cast pys vp on his hede .
This sely man sate stil / as he were dede
He wipte his hede no more durst he seyn
But or that the thunder stynt comth reyn
Of Phisippa / þat was the quene of Crete
For shrewednes / hym thought þe tale swete .
Fy speke no more / it is a grisly thyng
Of hir orrible lust / and hir likyng
Of Clytermistra / for hir lecherie
That falsly made hir housbond for to die .
He red it wtith ful gode deuociou
He told me eke for what occasiou
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his lyf / .
Myn housbond had a legend of his wyf .
Eriphilem / that for an ouch of gold .
Hath pꝰervely vn to the grekes told .
Wher that hir housbond hid hym in a place .
For which he hade at Thebes a sory grace
Of lyuia told he me / and of lucye
They both made her housbondes for to deye
That one for loue / that other was for hate
Lyuia hir housbond vp on an even late
Enpoisened hath for þat she was his fo
Lucia hir housbond likerous loued so
For that he shold al wey vp on hir thynk
She yave hym soch a maner loue drynk
That he was dede / or it were by þe morow
And thus algates husbondes han sorow .
Than told he me / how that one Latumeus /
Compleyned vn to his felaw Arryus
That in his gardyn growed soch a tree .
On which he seid how þat his wyfes .iij.
Hanged hem self for hertes dispitous
O leue brother koth this Arryus
Yeve me a plant / of that blessed tre
And in my gardyn planted shal it be
Of latter date of wyfes hath he rede
Thatt som han sley her husbondes in her bede
And let hir lechour dyght hir al þe nyght
Whan þat þe cors lay in the flore vpright
And som han dryven nailes in her brayn
While that they slept / and þus þey haue ben slayn
Som haue yeven hem poisou in her drynk.
He spake more harme þan hert may thynk
And there wtith al he knewe of mo ꝓproverbes
Than in þis world / there growen gras or herbes
Bet it is qd he thyn habitacou
Be wtith a liou or a foule dragou
Than wtith a womman vsyng for to chide
Bet is koth he hie in þe roof abide .
Than wtith an angry wyf / in þe hous
They ben so wikked and so contrarious
They haten þat her housbondes loven ay
He seid a womman kast hir shame away
Whan she cast of hir smok / and ferther mo
A faire womman but she be chaast also
Is like a gold ryng in a sowes nose
Whoo wold leue / or whoo wold suppose .
The wo þat in myn hert was and pyn
And whan I saugh he wold never fyn
To rede on this cursed boke al nyght
And sodenly .iij. leves haue I plight
Out of his boke right as he redde / and eke
I wtith my fist so toke hym on þe cheke
That in our fire he fel bakward doun
And he vp stert / as doth a wode lyou
And wtith his fyst he smote me on þe hede .
That in the flour I lay as I were dede .
And whan he sawe how stil that I lay
He was a gast / and wold haue fled his way
Til atte last out of my swough I breid.
O hast þu slayn me fals theef I seid .
And for myn land þus hast þu murtherd me;
Or I be dede yitte wol I kis the .
And nere he cam and kneled feir adoun
And seid dere suster Alisoun
As help me god I shal þe never smyte
That I haue doon / it is thy self to wyte .
Foryeve it me / and that I þe beseke
And yitte eftsones I hitte on þe cheke
And seid thief / thus moch am I awreke
Now wol I die I may no lenger speke ;
But at the last / wtith moch care and woo
We fel accorded by our seluen twoo .
He yaue me / al the bridel in myn honde
To han the gouꝰernaunce / of hous and londe .
And of his tung / and his honde also
And made hym brenne his boke anon right tho
And whan þat I hade geten vn to me
By maistrie al the souꝰerayntee .
And that he seid / myn owen true wyf
Do as the lust the tꝰerme of al thy lyf
Kepe thyn honour and kepe eke myn estate
And after that day we hade never debate
God help me so / I was to hym as kynd
As ony wyf from Denmark vn to Ind .
And also true / and so was he to me
I praye to god that sitteth in magestee .
So blys his soule / for his mꝰercy dere
Now wol I sey my tale yf ye wol here .
The frere lough whan he hade herd al this
Now dame koth he / so haue I ioye or blys
This is a long preamble / of a tale
And whan þe Sompnorur herd þe frere gale
Lo koth the Sompnour / by goddes armes two
A frere wol entermete hym euꝰermo
Lo gode men / a flie and eke a freer
Wol fal in euꝰery dissh and mater
What spekest þu of pꝰerambulaciou
What aumble or trotte / or pisse or go sitte doun
Thow lettest our desport in this maner
Yee wol þu so sompnour koth þe freer
Now by my feith I shal or that I go
Tel of a Sompnour soch a tale or two
That al folk shal lawghen in þis place .
Now elles frere I beshrewe thy face
Koth this Sompnour and I beshrewe me
But yf I tel tales .ij. or .iij.
Of frerers or that I com to Sidyngborurne .
That I shal make thyn hert for to morurne
For wele I wote thy pacience is goon
Our hoost cried pees / and þat anoon
And seid let the womman tel hir tale
Ye fare as folk / that dronken ben of ale .
Do dame tel forth / your tale / and þtat is best / .
Al redy sire koth she / right as you. lest.
Yf I haue licence of this worthy frere
Yis dame koth he / tel forth and I wol here /
Hic definit prologus vxoris de Bath Et incipit fabula eiusdem vxoris

(base) Of which that Britons speken greet honour

(base) The Elf queene with hir ioly compaignye
(base) Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede

(base) That serchen euery lond and euery streem
(base) As thikke as motes in the sonne beem

div.l: (base) This maketh that ther been no fairyes
(base) For ther as wont to walken was an Elf
(base) Ther walketh now the lymytour hymself
(base) In vndermelys and in morwenynges
(base) And seith his matyns and his holy thynges
(base) As he gooth in his lymytacioun
(base) Wommen may go saufly vp and down
(base) In euery bussh or vnder euery tree
(base) Ther is noon oother Incubus but he
(base) And he ne wol doon hem but dishonour
(base) And so bifel that this kyng Arthour
(base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
(base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
(base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace

div.l: (base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
(base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce
(base) For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle
(base) That we nyl kike for he seith vs sooth
(base) Assay and he shal fynde it that so dooth
(base) For be we neuer so vicious with Inne
(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne
(base) And somme seyn that greet delit han we
(base) For to be holden stable and eek secree
(base) And in o purpos stedefastly to dwelle
(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle
(base) But that tale is nat worth a Rake stele
(base) Pardee we wommen konne no thyng hele
(base) Witnesse on Mida wol ye heere the tale

div.l: (base) Ouyde amonges othere thynges smale
(base) Seyde Mida hadde vnder his longe herys
(base) Growynge vpon his heed two Asses erys
(base) The which vice he hidde as he best myghte
(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte
(base) That saue his wyf ther wiste of it na mo
(base) He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
(base) He preyed hire that to no creature
(base) She sholde tellen of his disfigure
(base) She swoor hym nay for al this world to wynne
(base) She nolde do that vileynye or syn
(base) To make hir housbonde han so foul a name
(base) She nolde nat telle it for hir owene shame
(base) But nathelees hir thoughte that she dyde
(base) That she so longe sholde a conseil hyde
(base) Hir thoughte it swal so soore aboute hir herte
(base) That nedely som word hir moste asterte
(base) And sith she dorste nat telle it to no man
(base) Doun to a Marys faste by she ran
(base) Til she cam there hir herte was a fyre
(base) And as a Bitore bombleth in the Myre
(base) She leyde hir mouth vnto the water down
(base) Biwrey me nat thow water with thy sown
(base) Quod she to thee I telle it and namo
(base) Myn housbonde hath longe Asses erys two
(base) Now is myn herte al hool now it is oute
(base) I myghte no lenger kepe it out of doute
(base) Heere may ye see thogh we a tyme abyde
(base) Yet out it moot we kan no conseil hyde
(base) The remenant of the tale if ye wol heere
(base) Redeth Ouyde and ther ye may it leere

This sꝰergeaunt cam / vn to his lord ageyn
And of Grisildes wordes and hir chere
He told hym poynt for poynt in short and pleyn
And hym pꝰersenteth wtith his doughter dere
Som what this lord hath reuth in his manere
But natheles his purpos helde he stil
As lordes don / whan þey wol haue her wil
And bade his sꝰergeaunt / þtat he prively
Shold this child . soft wynden and wrap
Wtith al þe circumstaunce tenderly
And carie it in a coffer or in a lap
But vp on peyn / his hede of forto swap
That no man shold knowe of this intent
Ne whens it cam / ne whider þat it went
But at Boloygne to his suster dere
That thylk tyme of Pavyk was Countesse
He shold it take / and shewe hir this matere
Besechyng hir to don hir besynesse
This child to fustre / in al gentilnesse
And whoos child þat it was he bade hym hide
From euꝰery wight / for ought þat may betide
The sꝰergeaunt gooth and hath fulfilled this thyng
But to this Markes / now retourne we
For now goth he / ful fast ymagenyng
Yf by his wyfes chere / he myght se
Or by hir worde / ꝑperceyue þat she
Were chaunged / but neuꝰere koud he fynd
But euꝰere in one elyke / sadde and kynd .
As glad as humble / as bisye in sꝰeruyce
And eke in loue / as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in euꝰery maner wise
Ne of hir doughter / nought a word spake she
Noon accident / for noon aduꝰersitee
Was seen in hir / ne neuer hir doughter name
Ne nemmed she / in ernest ne in game
In this estate there passed ben .iiij. yere
Or she wtith child was but as god wold .
A knave child she bare / by this waltere
Ful gracious and feir for to behold .
And whan þtat folk it to his fader told
Nat onely he / but al his cuntree mery
Was for this child / and god þey þanked and herie
Whan it was .ij. yere old and from the brest
Deꝑperted of his Norice / vp on a day
This Markes kaught yitte another lest
To tempt his wyf / yitte ofter yf he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynd / a pacient creature
Wyf koth this Markes / ye haue herd þis
My peple sekerly / bereth our mariage
And namely seth my son yborn is /
Now is it were / þan euer in al our age
The murmur sleeth myn hert and my corage
For to myn eres comth þe voys so smert
That it welnye destroyed hath / myn hert .
Now seyn they thus / whan waulter is goon
Than shal the blode / of Ianycle succede
And bene our lord for other haue we noon
Soth wordes seyn my peple / out of drede
Wele ought I / of soch murmur take hede
For certeynly / I drede soch sentence
Þough þey nought pleyn / and speke in myn audience
I wold lyve in pees yf þat I myght
Therfore I am disposed outtrely
As I his suster sꝰerued by nyght
Right so thynk .I. to sꝰerue hym pꝰervely
This warn I you / þat ye nat sodenly
Out of your self for no woo / shold outrey
Beth pacient / and þere of I you prey
I haue koth she seid þus / and euꝰere shal
I wol no thyng / ne nyl no þyng certeyn
But as you list / nought greueth me at al
Though þat my doughter / and my son be sleyn
At your commaundement / þis is to seyn
I haue nought hade no ꝑpert of children tweyn
But first sekenes / and after wo and peyn
Ye ben our lord / doth wtith your owen þyng
Right as you list / asketh no rede at me
For as I left at home / al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to you / right so koth she
Left I my wil / and al my libertee
And toke yorur clothyng / wherfore I you prey
Doth yorur plesaunce / I wol your lust obey
And certes yf I hade pꝰerscience
Your wil to knowe / or ye / yorur lust me told .
I wold it don / wtithout necligence
But now I wote yorur lust and what ye wold
Al your plesaunce / ferme and stable I hold
For wist I / þat my deth / wold do you ease
Right gladly wold I deye / you to please
Deth may nat make no comꝑperisoūn
Vn to your love / and whan this Markes say
The Constaunce of his wyf / he cast a doun
His yien ij. / and wondreth þat she may
In pacience suffre al / this array
And forth he goth / wtith drery countenaunce
But to his hert / it was ful grete plesaunce
This vgly sꝰergeant / in the same wise
That hir doughter caught / right so he
Or wors / yf men wors / can devise
Hath hent hir son / þtat ful was of beautee
And euer in one so pacient was she
That she no chere / made of heuynesse
But kist hir son and after gan it blesse
Save this she praied hym / þat yf he myght
Hir litle son / he wold in erthe graue
His tendre lymmes / delicate to sight
For foules and for bestes / it to save
But she noon other answere / of hym myght have
He went his wey / as hym no thyng rought
But to Boloigne he it / tenderly brought
This Markes wondred / euer lenger þe more
Vp on hir pacience / and yf that he
Ne hade sothly / knowen þere byfore
That ꝑperfitely / hir children loued she
He wold haue wend / þtat of som soteltee
And of malice / or for cruel corage
That she hade suffred þis / wtith sad visage /
But wele he knewe / þtat next hīn self certayn
She loued hir children best / in euꝰery wise
But now of wommen / wold I aske fayn
Yf thise assayes myght nat suffise
What koude a sturdy housbond more devise
To preve hir wyfhode / or hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuyng / euer in stourdynesse
But there ben folk / of soch condicioūn
That whan þey haue / a certeyn purpoos take
They can nat stynt of her intencioūn
But right as they were / bounden vn to a stake
They wol nat / of þat first purpos slake
Right so this Markes / fully hath prraposed
To tempt his wyf / as he was first disposed
He waiteth / yf by worde or countenaunce
That she to hym / was chaunged of corage
But neuer koude he fynd variaunce
She was ay one in hert / and in visage
And ay the ferther / þat she was in age
The more true / yf þtat it were possible
She was to hym in loue / and more penyble
For which it semed thus þat of hem two
The nas but o wil for as walter lest
The same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god bethanked al fel for the best
She shewed wele / for no worldly vnrest
A wyf as of hir self / no thyng ne shold .
Wol in effect / but as hir housbond wold .
The sclaunder of walter oft and wide sprad .
That of cruel hert / he wykkedly
For he / a poure womman wedded had
Hath murthred / both his children prevely
Soch murmur / was among hem cōmmonly
No wondre is for to the peples ere
There cam no worde / but þtat þey murtherd were
For which / there as his peple þer byfore
Hade loved hym wele / þe sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem / þat they hym hated therfore
To ben a murtherer is an hateful name
But natheles / for ernest / or for game
He of his cruel purpos nold stynt
To tempt his wyf / was set al his intent
Whan that his doughter / .xij. yere was of age
He to the Court of Rome / in subtel wise
Enforurmed of his wil / sent his message
Commaundyng hem soch bulles to devise
As to his cruel purpos / may suffise
How that the pope / as for his peples rest
Bad hym to wed / another yf hym lest
I sey he bad they shold countrefayt
The Popes bulles makyng mencioūn
That he hath leue / his first wyf to lete
As by the popes dispensacoūn
To stynt rancour and discencioūn
Bitwen hym and his peple / thus seid þe bul
The which / þey han puplisshed at þe ful
The rude peple / as it no wonder is .
Wend ful wele / þat it hade be right so
But whan þise tidynges cam to Grisildes
I deme that hir hert was ful wo
But she elike sad / for euꝰermoo
Disposed was / þis humble creature
The aduꝰersite of Fortune / al to endure
Abidyng euer his lust / and his plesaunce
To whom þat she was youen hert and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisaunce
But shortly / yf I this storie I tellen shal
This Markes writen hath / in special
A le in which he sheweth his intent
And secretely he it to Boloigne sent
To the Erle of Pavyk which þtat had tho
Wedded his suster / prayed he specially
To bryngen home ageyn / his children two
In honorurable astate / al openly
But o thyng / he prayed hym vttrely
That he no wight / þough men wold enquere
Shold nat tel / whos children þat they were
But sey the Maiden shold wedded be
Vn to the Markes of Saluce anoon
And as this Erle was praied so did he
For at þe day set / he on his wey is gon
And forth he rode ful fast / and þtat anon
Toward Saluce þis maide for to gide
Hir yong brother ridyng hir beside
Arraied was toward hir mariage
This fressh may ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which þat .vij. yere was of age
Arraied eke ful fressh in his manere
And thus in grete noblesse / and wtith glad chere
Toward Saluces shapyng her iourney
From day to day / þey riden in hir wey
Among al this / after his wyk vsage
This Markes / yit his wyf to tempt more
To þe outrest preve / of hir corage
Fully to haue exꝑperience and lore
Yf þat she were as stedfast as byfore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boistously hath seid hir this sentence
Certes Grisild / I hade ynough plesaunce
To haue you to my wyf / for yorur godenes
As for your trouth / and for your obeisaunce
Nought for your lynage / ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in grete lordship / yf I me wele avise
There is grete sꝰeruitute / in sondry wise
I may nat do as euꝰery plough man may
My peple constreyneth me to take
An other wyf and crien day by day
And eke the popes rancour / for to slake
Consenteth it / that dare I vndretake
And truly / þus moch I wol you sey
My newe wyf is cōmmyng by þe wey
Be strong of hert / and voide anoon hir place
And þat dower / þat ye brought me
Take it ageyn / I graunt of my grace
Returneth to yorur faders hous / koth he
No man may al wey haue ꝓprosꝑperitee
Wtith euen hert / I rede you to endure
The stroke of Fortune / or of auenture
And she ageyn answerd / in pacience
My lord koth she / I wote and wost al wey
How þat bitwene your magnificence
And my pouꝰertee / no wight ne can nor may
Maken comꝑperisoūn / it is no nay
I ne held me / neuꝰere digne in no manere
To be your wyf / nor your chamberere
And in this hous / þere ye me lady made
The hie god take I for my witnes
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuer held me lady / ne maistresse
But humble sꝰeruaunt / to your worthynesse
And euer shal / while þat my lif may dure
Aboue euery worldly creature
That ye so long of yorur benignitee
Han holden me in honour and nobley
Where as I was nat worthy for to be
That thank I god / and you to whom I pray
For yeld it you / there is no more to sey
Vn to my fader / gladly wol I wend
And wtith hym dwel / vn to my lyfes end
There I was fustred / of a child ful smal
Tyl I be dede / my lyf there wol I lede
A widow clene / in body hert and al
For seth I yaaf to you my maydenhede
And am your true wyf / it is no drede
God shield soch a lordes wyf to take
Another man / to housbond or to make
And of your newe wyf god of his grace
So graunt you welth and ꝓprosꝑperitee
For I wol gladly / yelden hir / my place
In which þtat I blisful was wont to be
For seth it liketh you my lord koth she
That whilom / weren al my hertes rest
That I shal goon / I wol go whan you lest
But there as ye me ꝓprofre / soch doware
As I first brought it is wele in my mynd
It were my wrecched clothes no þyng faire
The which to me / were harde now for to fynd
O gode god how gentle / and how kynd
Ye semed by your speche / and yorur visage
The day þat maked was our mariage
But soth is seid / al gate I fynd it true
For in effect it pꝰerued is on me
Loue is nat old / as whan þtat it is newe
But certes lord / for noon aduꝰersitee
To die in this caas / it shal nat be
That euꝰere in worde / or werk I shal repent
That I you yaaf myn hert / in hole intent
My lord ye wote / þat in my faders place
Ye did me stripe / out of my poure wede
And richely me clad / of your grace
To you brought I nat elles / out of drede
But filth / and nakednes of maydenhede
And here ageyn my clothyng I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng / for euꝰermore
The remenaunt of your Iewels redy be
Wtithin your chambre / I dare it safely seyn
Naked out of my faders hous / koth she
I cam and naked / mot I turne ageyn
Al your plesaunce / wold I folow feyn
But yitte I hope / it be nat your intent
That I smokles / out of your paleys went
Ye koude nat do / so dishonest a thyng /
That thilk wombe / in which your children lay
Shold byfore the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare / wherfore I you pray
Let me nat like a worme / go by þe way
Remembre you myn owen lord / so dere
I was your wyf þough I vnworthy were
Wherfore in guerdou / of my maydenhede
Which that I brought / and nought ageyn I bere
As vouche save / to yeve me to my mede
But soch a smok / as I was wont to were
That I there wtith may wrie þe wombe of heere
That was your wyf / and here I take my leve
Of you myn owen lord / lest I you greve /
The smok / koth he / þat þu haast on þy bak
Let it be stil / and bere it forth wtith the
But wele vnnethes this word he spak
But went his wey / for ruthe and for pitee
Byfore þe folk hir self / stripeth she
And in hir smok / wtith fote and hede al bare
Toward hir fader hous / forth is she fare
The folk hir folowen / wepyng in hir wey
And fortune ay / þey cursen as þey goon
But she from wepyng / kepeth hir yen drey
Ne in this tyme / word ne spake she noon
Hir fader / þat this tidyng herd anoon
Cursed þe day / and tyme þat nature
Shoop hym to ben a lyves creature
For out of dout / þis old poure man
Was euꝰere in suspect / of hir mariage
For euer he demed / seth þtat it began
That whan þe lord fulfilled hade his corage
Hym wold thynk it were a disꝑperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his astate / so lowe / for to light
And voiden hir / as sone as euꝰere he myght
Ageyn his doughter / hastely goth he
For he by noise of peple / knewe hir cōmmyng
And wtith hir old cote as it myght be
He couerd hir ful sorowfully wepyng
But on hir body / myght he it nat bryng
For rude was the cloth / and she more of age
By dayes fele / þan at hir mariage
Thus wtith hir fader / for a certeyn space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neither by her wordes ne by hir face
Byfore the folk ne eke in her absence
Ne shewed she / þat hir was don offence
Ne of hir hie astate / no remembraunce
Ne hade she / as by hir countenaunce
No wonder is / for in hir grete astate
Hir goost was euer in pleyn humilite
No tendre mouth / non hert delicate
No pompe / no semblant of Roialte
But ful of pacient benignytee
Discrete and prideles / ay honourable
And to hir housbond ay meke and stable
Men speke of Iob / and most for his humblesse
As Clerkes whan hem list / kon wele endite
Namely of men / but as in sothenes
Though Clerkes preise wommen but a lite
There can no man / in humblesse hym acquyte
As wommen kan / ne kan be half so true
As wommen ben / but it befal of newe
From Boloigne / is this Erle of Pavyk com
Of which þe fame / vp sprong to ore and lasse
And in the peples eres / al an som
Was couth eke þat a newe Markesesse
He wtith hym brought / in soch pompe and richesse
That neuer was there seen / wtith mannes yie
So noble arraie / in al Westlombardie
The Markes / which þtat shope / and knew al þis
Or þat þis Erle was com / sent his message
For thilk sely poure Grisildis
And she wtith humble hert / and glad visage
Nat wtith no swollen / þought / in hir corage
Cam at his heest and on hir knees hir set
And reuꝰerently and wisely / she hym grete
Grisild koth he / my wil is vttrely
This maiden / þat shal wedded be to me
Resceyued be to morn / as rially
As it possible is / in myn hous to be
And eke þat euꝰery wight in his degree
Haue his sittyng in estate / in sittyng and in sꝰeruyce
And high plesaunce / as I can best deuyce
I haue no womman / sufficiant certeyn
The Chambres to array in ordinaunce
After my lust and therfore wold I feyn
That thyn were al soch gouꝰernaunce
Thow knowest eke of old al my plesaunce
Though þyn array be bade / and euyl besey
Do þu thy devoir atte leest / wey
Nat onely lord þat I am glad koth she
To do your lust but I desire also
You for to sꝰerue and plese in my degree
Wtithouten feyntyng and shal euꝰermo
Ne neuer for no wele / ne for no wo
Ne shal þe gost wtith in myn hert stent
To loue you best wtith al my true intent /
And wtith þtat word / she gan þe hous to dight
And tables for to sette / and beddes for to make
And peyned hir to don al / þat she myght
Praying the Chamberers / for goddes sake
To hasten hem and fast swepe and shake
And she the most sꝰeruysable / of al
Hath euꝰery chambre arraied and his hal
About the vndern / gan þis Erle alight
That wtith hym brought þise noble children twey
For which þe peple / ran to se the sight
Of her array so richely besey
And þan at erst / amonges hem þey sey
That Walter was no fole / þough þtat hīn lest
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his best
For she is feirer as þey deme al
Than is Grisild / and more tendre of age
A feirer fruyt / bitwene hem shold fal
And more plesant / for her hie linage
Hir brother eke so feir was of visage
That hem to seen / þe peple caght plesaunce
Cōmmendyng now / þe Markes gouꝰernaunce
O sturne peple vnsad and euer vntrue
Ay vndescrete and chaungyng as a fane
Delityng euꝰere in rumbel / þtat is newe
For like the mone / þtat ay wexeth and wane
Ay ful of clappyng / dere ynough a Iane
Your dome is fals / your constaunce euyl pꝰerveth
A ful grete fole is he þtat on you leveth
Thus seiden sad folk / in that Citee
Whan þat þe peple gazed vp and doun
For þey were glad right for þe nouelte
To han a newe lady of her toun
No more of this make I nowe mensioūn
But to Grisild agayn I wol me dresse
And tel hir constaunce and hir besynesse
Ful besy was Grisild in euꝰery thyng
That to þe fest / was ꝑpertinent /
Right nought was she / abassht of hir clothyng
Though it were rude / and somdele eke to rent /
But wtith glad chere / to þe yate is she went /
Wtith other folk to grete þe Markesesse
And after þtat / doth forth her besynesse
Wtith so glad chere / his gestes she resceyued
And so kunnyngly / ecch in his degree
That no defaute / no man ꝑperceyued
But ay þey wondren / what she be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koud soch honour / and reuꝰerence
And worthely / þey preisen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stynt
This maid and eke hir brother to cōmmend
Wtith al hir hert / in ful benigne intent
So wele þtat no man coude hir preise amend .
But atte last / whan þat þise lordes wend
To sitten doun to mete / he gan to cal
Grisild as she was besy in the hal
Grisild koth he / as it were in his pley
How liketh the my wyf and hir beaute
Right wele koth she my lord / for in gode fey
A feirer sawe I neuer noon þan she
I pray to god yeve hir prosꝑperitee
And so hope I þtat he wol to you send
Plesaunce ynough / vn to your lyves ende
O thyng beseche I you / and warn also
That ye ne pryk / wtith no turmentyng
This tendre maide as ye haue don mo
For she is fusterd in hir norisshyng
More tenderly / and to my supposyng
She koude nat aduꝰersitee / endure
As coude a poure fustred creature
And whan this walter saugh hir pacience
Hir glad chere / and no malice at al /
And he so oft / hade don to hir offence
And she ay sad / and constant as a wal
Contynuyng euer hir Innocence ouer al /
This sturdy Markes / gan his hert dresse
To rue vp on / hir wyfly stedfastnesse
This is ynough Grisild myn koth he
Be now no more agast / ne euyl appayed
I haue þy feith / and thy benygnitee
As wele as euer / wōmman was assaied
In grete astate / and pourely arraied
Now knowe I dere wyf þy stedfastnesse
And hir in armes toke / and gan hir kys
And she for wonder / toke of it no kepe
She herd nat / what þyng he to hir seid
She ferd as she hade stirt / out of a slepe
Til she out of hir masednes obbreid
Grisild koth he by god / þat for vs deid
Thow art my wyf / none other I haue
Ne neuꝰere had / as god my soule saue
This is thy doughter / which þu hast supposed
To be my wyf / þat other feithfully
Shal be myn heir / as I haue disposed
Thow bare hym / in thy body truely
At Boloigne / haue I kept hem pꝰeruely
Take hem agayn / for now maist þu nat sey
That þu hast lorn / ony of thy children twey
And folk þat other wise / han seid on me
I warn hem wele / þat I haue don þis dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for to assaye in the / þy wommanhede
And nat to sle my children / god forbede
But for to kepe hem / prively and stil
Til I thy purpoos knewe / and al þy wil
Whan she this herd / in swowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye / and after hir swownyng /
She both hir yong children / vn to hir calleth
And in her armes / pitously wepyng
Embraced hem / and tenderly kissyng
Ful like a moder / wtith hir salt teres
She bathed both hir visage / and hir heres
O which a pitous thyng / it was to se
Hir swownyng / and hir humble vois to here
Graunt mercy lord / god þank it you / koth she
That ye han saved me / my children dere
Now rek I neuꝰere to be dede / right here
Seth I stond in your loue and grace
No force of deth ne whan my sꝑperit pace
O tendre / o dere / o yong children myn
Your woful moder / went stedfastly
That cruel houndes / or som foule venym
Hade eten you / but god of his mꝰercy
And your benigne fader / tenderly
Hath don you kepe / and in þtat same stound
Al sodenly / she swapp adoun to ground
And in hir swough / so sadly holdeth she
Hir children .ij. whan she gan hem enbrace
That wtith grete sleight / and grete difficultee
The children from hir arme þey gon race
O many a teer / many a pitous pace
Doun ran of hem / þtat stoden hir beside
Vnneth about hir / myght þey abide
Walter hir gladeth / and hir sorow slaketh
She riseth vp abasshed / from hir traunce
