To lede in ese / and holines his lyf
And þank god / þtat he myht haue hir al
That no wight / his blis ꝑperten shal
And praid hem / to labour in this nede
And shaap / þtat he fail nat to spede
For þan he seid / his sꝑperit was at ese
Than is koth he / no thyng may me displese
Saue / o . thyng prikketh in my conscience
The which I wol reherce / in your pꝰersence
I haue koth he herd sey / ful yore agoo
There may no man / haue ꝑperfite blisses . ij .
This is to seyn in erth / and eke in heuen
For þough he kepe hym / from þe synnes . vij .
And eke from euꝰery braunche of that tre
Yitte is there so ꝑperfite felicite
And so grete ese and lust in mariage
That euer I am agast now in myn age
That I shal lede now / so mery a lyf
So delicate / wtithout woo and stryf
That I shal haue myn heuen in erth here
For seth þtat verray heuen is bought so dere
Wtith tribulacoūns / and grete penaunce
How shold I than / þat lyue in soch plesaunce
As al wedded men / doth wtith her wyfes
Com to þe blys / the blys / there crist etꝰerne on lyve is
This is my drede / and / ye my brethern twey
Assoileth me this questiou I you prey
Iustinus / which þat hated his foly
Answerd anon / right in his rapery
And for he wold his long tale abregge
He wold none auctoritee allegge
But seid sir / so þere be non abstacle
Other than this / god of his hye myracle
And of his hie mꝰercy may so for you wirche
That or ye han yorur rightꝭes of holy chirche
Ye may repent of wedded mannes lyf
In which ye sey / þere is no woo ne stryf
And elles god forbede / but he sent
A wedded man / hym grace to repent
Wele oft rather / than a sengle man /
And therfore sir / þe best rede I can
Dispeire you nat but haue in yorur memorie
ꝐPerauenture / she may be / yorur purgatorie
She may be goddes mene / and goddes whipp
Than shal your soule vp to heuen skypp
Swyfter / þan an arow / doth out of a bowe
I hope to god / here after shul ye knowe
That there nys noon so grete felicitee
In mariage / ne neuer more shal be
That you shal let of your saluacoūn
So þat ye vse / as skil is and resoūn
The lustes of your wyf attemprely
Take hem nat oft but mesurably
And þat ye kepe you / eke from other syn
My tale is don / for my witte is thyn
Beth nat agast / here of my brother dere /
But laten vs / waden out of þis matere
The wyf of Bath / yf ye haue vnderstond
Of mariage / which we haue on hond .
Declared hath ful / wele / in litle space
Fareth now wele / god haue you in his grace
And wtith þtat word / þis Iustyn and his brother
Han tan her leve / and ecch of hem / of other
For whan þey sawe / it most nedes be /
They wroughten so / by slye and wise tretee
That she this maid / which þtat Mayus hight
As hastely / as euer that she myght
Shal wedded be to þis Ianuarie
I trowe it were / to long you to tarie
Yf I you told of euꝰery script and bonde
By which þat she was feffed in his lond.
Or for to rekken / of hir riche array
But finally / ycōmmen is that day
That to þe chirch / both be þey went
For to resceyue / þe holy sacrament
Forth comth þe prest / wtith stole about his nek
And bade hir belike / Sarra and rebek
In wisdom and in trouth / of mariage
And seid his orisons / as is vsage
And crouched hem / and bad god shold hem blys
And made al siker ynough / wtith holynes
Thus ben they wedded wtith solempnytee
And atte fest sitteth he and she
Wtith other worthy folk / vpon the deys
Al ful of ioye and blis / ys the paleys
And ful of instrumentes / and of vitaile
The most deynteuous of al Itail
Byfore hem / were þere Instrumentes of soch soun
That Orpheus nor thebes Amphyoun
Ne maden neuer soch / a melodye
At euꝰery cours / þan cam loude mynstralcye
Þat neuer trumped Ioab for to here
Ne he Theodomas / half so clere
At Thebes whan þe Citee was in dout
Bacus þe wyn / hem shynketh al about
And venus laugheth / vp on euꝰery wight
For Ianuar was bycom hir knyght
And wold both assaye his corage
In libtee / and eke in mariage
And wtith hir firibrond in hir hond about
Daunceth byfore þe bride / and al þe rout
And certenly / I dare wele seyen this
That Ymeneus which god of weddyng is
Sawe neuer his lyf so mery a wedded man
Hold þu thy pees þu Poet Marcian
That writest vs / þtat ilk weddyng mery
Of hir Philozophye / and hym Merkurye
And of þe songes / þat the Muses song
To smal is both thy penne / and eke þy tong
For to descryuen / of this mariage
Whan tendre youth hath wedded stoupyng age
There is soch merth / þat it may nat be writen
Assayeth it your self þan may ye weten
Yf þat I lie or none / in this matere
Mayvs þat sit / wtith so benigne a chere
Hir to be hold / it semed feyrye
Quene Ester / loked neuer wtith soch an Iye
On Assure / so meke a loke hath she
I may you nat devise / al hir beautee
But þus moch / of hir beaute tel I may
That she was like / þe bright morow of May
Fulfilled of al beautee / and plesaunce
This Ianuar is rauysshed in a traunce
At euꝰery tyme / he loked in hir face
But in his hert / he gan hir to manace
That he þat nyght in armes wold hir streyn
Harder þan euer Parys dyd Eleyn
But natheles yitte had he grete pitee
That thylk nyght offend hir most he
And thought Allas / o tendre creature
Now wold god / ye myght wel endure
Al my corage / it is so sharp and kene
I am a gast ye shul / it nat sustene
But god forbede / þtat I did al my myght
Now wold god / it were woxen nyght
And þat þe nyght wold lasten euꝰermo
I wold þat al this peple / were agoo
And fynally / he doth al his labour
As he best myght / savyng his honour
To haste hem / from þe mete in subtle wise
The tyme cam / þat resou was to rise
And after þat / men daunce and drynk fast
And spices al about þe hous / þey cast
And ful of ioye and blys is euꝰery man
Al but a Squyer / hight Damyan
Which carf byfore þe knyght ful many a day
He was so rauysshed / on his lady May
That for þe verray peyn he was nye wode
Al most he swelt and swowned as he stode
So sore hath venus / hurt hym wtith hir brond
As that she bare it daunsyng in hir hond .
And to his bed / he went hym hastely
No more at this tyme / of hym speke I .
But there I lete hīn wepe ynough / and pleyn
Til fressh May wol rue on his peyn
O ꝑperlious fire þat in þe bed strawe bredeth
O famuler foo / þtat his sꝰeruyce bedeth
O sꝰeruaunt traytorur / fals homly hewe
Lyke to þe Nadder / in bosom ful vntrewe
God sheld vs al / from yorur acqueyntaunce
O Ianuar drunken in plesaunce
In mariage / se how þy Damyan
Thyn owen Squyer / and þy born man
Entendeth / for to do the velanye
God graunt þe / thyn homely fo to spye
For in this world / nys wers pestelence
Than homely foo / al day in thy pꝰersence
ꝐPerforurmed hath þe son / his arke diurne
No lenger may þe body of hym soiorurne
On þe orisou as in þat latitude
Nyght wtith his mantel þtat is derk and rude
Gan ouꝰersprede / the Emesperie about
For which / deꝑperted is this lusty rout
Fro Ianuar wtith thank on euꝰery side .
Home to her hous lustely þey ride
Where as þey don her þynges / as hem lest
And whan þey sawe her tyme go to rest
Sone after þat this hasty Ianuarie
Wol go to bed he wol no lenger tarie
He drynketh / Ypocras / Clarry / and vernage
Of spices hote / to encrece his corage
And many a letuarie / hade he ful fyn
Soch as þe cursed Monk domp Costantyn
Hath writen in his boke / de Coitue.
To ete hem al / he was no thyng eschue
And to his pꝰervee / frendes / þus seid he
For goddes loue / as sone / as it may be
Let voiden al þis hous / in curteis wise
And þey haue don / right as he wol devise
Men drynken / and þe travers / drawen anon
The bride was brought a bed / as stil as a stoon
And whan þe bed / was wtith þe prest yblessed .
Out of þe chambre / hath euꝰery wight hym dressed
And Ianuar hath fast in armes take
His fressh May / his ꝑperadys / his make
He lulleth hir / he kisseth hir ful oft
Wtith thyk bristles / of his berd vnsoft
Lyke to þe skyn of houndes fyssh / sharp as a brere
For he was shaue al newe in his manere
He rubbeth hir about hir tendre face
And seid þus allas / I mot trespace
To you my spouse / and gretely offende
Or tyme com þat I wol doun discende
But natheles considereth þis koth he
There is no werkman / what so euer he be
That may werk wele / and hastely
This wol be don / at leiser ꝑperfitely
It is no force / how long þat we pley
In true wedlok coupled be we twey
And blissed be þe yok þtat we ben in /
For in actes we mow do no syn
A man may do no syn wtith his wyf
Ne hurte hym self / wtith his owen knyf
For we han leve to pley / as by þe lawe
Thus laboureh he / til þe day gan dawe
And than he taketh / a sop in fyn Clarre
And vp right in his bed / þan sate he
And after þtat he song / ful loude and clere
And kyst his wyf and made wantou chere
He was al Coltyssh / ful of ragerie
And ful of gergou / as a flekked pye
The slak skyn / about his nek shaketh
While þtat he song so chaunteth he / and craketh
And god wote / what þtat May / þought in hir hert
Whan she hym sawe / vpsittyng in his shert
In his nyght cap / and wtith his nek lene
She preiseth nat his playing worth a bene
Than seid he þus / my rest wol I take
Now day is com / I may no lenger wake
And doun he leid his hede / and slept til pryme
And after ward whan that he sawe his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuar but fressh May
Helde hir chambr / vn to þe iiij . day
As vsage is of wyfes for þe best
For euꝰery laborur / som tyme mot haue rest
Or els long may he nat endure
This is to seyn no lyues creature
Be it of fissh or brede or best or man
Now wol I speke / of woful Damyan
That langwissheth / for loue as ye shul here
Therfore I speke to hym in this manere
I seid o sely Damyan allas
Answere to my demaund as in this caas
How shalt þu to þy lady fressh May
Tel thy woo / she wol al wey sey nay
Eke yf þu speke / she wol þy wo be wrey
God be thyn help I can no better sey
This sike Damyan in Venus fire
So brenneth / þtat he deieth for desire
For which / he put his lyf in auenture
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But priuely a penner gan he borow
And in a lre wrote / he al his sorow
In maner of a compleynt or a lay
Vn to this feir fressh May
And in a purs of sylk hyng on his shert
He hath it put and leid it at his hert
The mone that at Noon / was þtat ilk day
That Ianuar hath wedded fressh May
Þe signe of taur / was in to Cancre gliden
So long hath Mayus / in hir chambre abiden
As custume is / vn to thise nobles al
A bride shal nat / eten in the hal
Til dayes . iiij . / or . iij . at the leest /
Passed been / than let hir go to fest
The iiijth day complete / from noon to noon
Whan þtat þe / hie mas was ydoon
In hal sat þis Ianuarie and May
As fressh as is / þe bright somꝰers day
And so byfel / how þat þis gode man
Remembred hym / vp on þis Damyan
And seid Seint Marie / how may it be
That Damyan entendeth nat to me
Is he ay syke / or how may it betide
His squyers / which þtat stoden þere beside
Excused hym by cause of his sekenes
Which letted hym / to don his besynes
Noon other cause / myght make hym tarie
That me forthynketh / koth þis Ianuarie
He is a gentle Squyer / by my treuth
Yf þtat he died / it were harme and reuth
He is as wise / discrete / and as secree
As ony man I knowe / of his degree
And therto manly / and eke sꝰeruyzable
And for to be a man / thrifty and able
But after mete / as sone / as euꝰere I may
I wol my self visite hym / and eke May
To don hym al the confort þat I can
And for þat word / hym blessed euꝰery man
That of his bountee / and his gentilnesse
He wold so comfort in sekenesse
His Squyer for his gentil dede
Dame koth this Ianuar / take gode hede
At after mete / ye wtith your wōmmen al
Whan ye haue ben / in chambre out of þis hal /
That al ye gon / to se þis Damyan
Doth hym desport / he is a gentle man
And telleth hym / þtat I wol hym visite
Haue I no þyng / but rested me a lite
And spede you fast for I wol abide
Til þtat ye slepe fast by my side
And wtith þtat word he gan to hym cal
A Squyer that was / Marschal of his al
And told hym certeyn thynges þtat he wold .
This fressh May / hath streight hir way holde
Wtith al hir wommen / vn to Damyan
Doun by his beddes side / sitte she than
Comfortyng hym / as godely as she may
This Damyan / whan he his tyme say
In secrete wise / his purs and eke his bil
In which that he writen had his wil /
Hath put it in hir hond / wtithout more
Saue þat he sighed / wonder depe and sore
And softly to hir / right thus seid he
Mꝰercy / and þat ye nought / bewreie me
For I am dede / yf þat þing be kydde
This purs / she wtithin hir bosom hydde
And went hir wey ye gete / no more of me
But vn to Ianuar / agayn cōmmen is she
That on his bed side / sate ful soft
And taketh hir / and kisseth hir ful oft
And leid hym doun to slepe / and þtat anoon
She feyned hir / as þough / she most goon
There as ye wote / euꝰery wight most nede
And whan she of this bil / hath taken hede
She rent it al to peces / atte last
And in þe pꝰervee / softly it cast
Who stodieth now / but feir fressh May
A doun / by old Ianuar she lay
That slepe / til þe kough hath hym waked
Anoon / he praied hir / to strepe hir al naked
He wold of hir he seid / haue som plesaunce
And seid hir clothes / did hym combraunce
And she obeieth hym / be hir lief or loth
But lest þat pꝰercious folk / wtith me be wroth
How þtat he wrought I dare nat to you tel
Or whether hir þought it ꝐPeradys or hel
But here I lete hem werk in her wise
Til euensong rong þtat þey most arise
Were it by destenye or by auenture
Were it by enfluence / or by nature
Or constellacou þat in soch astate
The heuen stode in þtat tyme fortunate
Wat for to put / a bil of nus werkes
For al þyng hath tyme / seith thise clerkes
To euꝰery womman / for to gete hir loue
I can nat sey / but grete god aboue
That knoweth / þtat none acte is causeles
He deme of al / for I wol hold my pees
But soth is this / how þat þis fressh May
Hath take soch impꝰerssiou / that day
Of pitee / of this sike Damyan
That from hir hert she ne dryue can
The remembraunce / for to don hīn ease
Certein thought she / whom that þis þyng displese
I rek nought for here I hym assure
To loue hym best of ony creature
Though he no more had / þan his shert /
Lo pitee renneth sone in gentle hert
Here may ye se / how exellent fraunchise
In womman is / whan þey hem narow avise
Som tyraunt is / as ther be many one
That hath an hert as hard as ony stone
Which wold haue let hym sterue in þe plaas
Wele rather / than haue graunt hym her graas
And hem reioisen in her cruel pride
And rek nat to ben / an homecide
This gentle May / fulfilled of pitee
Right of hir honde / a lre maketh she
In which / she graunted hym hir verray grace
There lakketh nat onely / but day and space
There as she myght / vn to his lust suffice
For it shal / be / right as he wol devise
And whan she saugh hir tyme vp on a day
To visite this Damyan / goth this May
And softly this lre / doun she threst
Vnder his pilow / rede it yf hym lest /
She taketh hym by þe honde / and hard hym twist
So secretely / þat no wight it wist
And bad hym be al hole / and forth she went /
To Ianuar / whan þtat he / for hir sent
Vp riseth Damyan / þe next morow
Al passed is his sekenes / and his sorow
He kembeth / he proyneth hym and pyketh
He doth / al that his lady / lust and liketh
And eke to Ianuarie / he goth as lowe
As euꝰere did a dog for the bowe
He is so plesaunt / to euꝰery man
For craft is al / who so þat do it can
That euꝰery wight / is feyn to speke hym gode
And fully in his ladies grace he stode
Thus lete I Damyan / about his nede
Som Clerkes holden / that felicite
Stant in delite / and therfore certeyn he
This noble Ianuar / wtith al his myght
In honest wise / as longeth to a knyght
Shope hym to lyue / ful deliciously
His housyng is arraied / as honestly
To his degree was maked / as a kynges /
Amonges other / of his honest thynges /
He made a gardyn / walled al wtith stone
A fairer gardyn / wote I nougher none
For out of dout I verraly suppose
That he that wote / þe Romaunce of þe Rose
Ne couth of it / þe beautee wele deuyse
Ne Priapus / myght nought suffyse
Though he be god / of gardyns for to tel
The beaute of þe gardyn / and þe wel
That stode vnder a laurel / al wey grene
Ful oft tyme he Pluto / and his quene
Proserpina / and al her feyree
Disporten hem and maken melodee
About þat wel / and daunsyng as men told .
This noble knyght / Ianuar þe old .
Soch deynte hath / in it to walk and pley
That he wol suffre no wight kepe þe key
But he hym self of þe smal wyket
He bare al weye / of siluer a clyket
Wtith which whan þat hym list he it vnshete
And whan he wold paye / his wyfes det
In somer sesou / þeder wold he go
And May his wyf and no wight but þey two
And thynges / þat were nat doon abed
He in the gardyn ꝑperforurmed hem / and sped
And in this wise ful many a mery day
Lyueth this Ianuarie / and this fressh May
But worldly Ioye / may nat al wey endure
To Ianuarie / ne to . no creature
O sodeyn hap / o þu fortune vnstable
Lyke to þe Scorpiou / so disceyuable
That flatꝰerest wtith thyn hede / whan þu wolt stigne
Thy tail is deth / þurgh þyn envemenyng
O brotle Ioye / o venym queynt
O monstre / þat so sotelly canst peynt
Thy yiftes / vnder hewe of stedfastnes
That þu disceyuest / both more and les
Why hast þu Ianuar / thus disceyued .
That hadest / hym for thy ful frend resceyued
And now þu hast byraft hym both his yen
For sorow of which / he desireth to dyen
Allas / this noble / Ianuar the free
Amyd his lust and his ꝓprosꝑperitee
Ys wexen blynd / and þat al sodenly
He wepeth / he waileth as pitously
And there wtith al / þe fire of ielousy
Lest that his wyf / shold falle in som foly
So brent his hert þat he wold feyn
That som man / both hir and hym had sleyn
For nouther / after his deth ne in his lyf .
Ne wold he þtat she were no loue ne wyf
But euꝰere lyve / as a widow in clothes blake
Shold as þe turtle / þat hath lost hir make
But at the last after a moneth or twey
His sorow gan to swage / soth to sey
For whan he wist it myght noon other be
He paciently toke / his aduersitee
Saue out of dout / he may nat forgon
That he nas ielous euꝰermore in one
Which ielousye / it was so outrageous
That neither in hal / ne in no other hous
Ne in noon other place / neuer þe moo
He nold suffre hir / for to ride ne goo
But yf þat he / hade hond on hir al wey
For which ful oft wepeth fressh May
That loueth Damyan / so benignely
That she mot / outher deien sodenly
Or els she most han hym / as hir lest
She waiteth / whan hir hert wold brest
Vp on that other side / Damyan
By com is the sorowfullest man
That euer was for neither nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a word to fressh May
As to his purpoos of no soch matere
But yf þtat Ianuar most it here
That hade an hond vp on hir euer mo /
But natheles by writyng to and fro /
And pꝰerve signes wist he / what she ment
And she knewe eke / the fyn of his intent
O Ianuar / what myght it þe avail
Though þu myght se / as fer as shippes sail /
For as gode is blynd disceyued be
As ben disceyued whan a man may se
Lo Argus which þtat hade an . C . yien
For al that ever he coude poure or prien
Yitte was he blynt as god wote so ben mo
That wenen wisely / þat it be nat so
Passe ouꝰere is an ese / I sey no more
This fressh May that I spake of byfore
In warm wex / hath pꝰernted þe clykket
That Ianuar bare of the smal wyket
By which in to his gardyn oft he went
And Damyan that knew al hir intent
The cleket countrefaited pꝰeruely
There is no more to sey but hastely
Som wonder by þis clyket shal betyde
Which ye shul here / yf ye wol abide
O noble Ovide ful soth seist þu god wote
What sleght is it though it be long and hote
That loue nyl fynd it out in som manere
By Pyramus and Tysbee may ye lere
Though þey were kept ful long and streight ouꝰer al
They ben accorded ronnyng þurgh a wal
There no wight koud han found out soch a sleight
But now to purpos or that daies . viij .
Were passed or that þe moneth of Iuyl byfel
That Ianuar hath caught so grete a wil
Thurgh eggyng of his wyf hym for to pley
In his gardyn / and no wight but they twey
That in a morow vn to this May seith he
Rise vp my wyf my love / my lady free
The turtles vois is herd / my dove so swete
The wynter is gone wtith his reynes wete
Com forth now / wtith þyn yien columbyne
How moch feirer / ben þy brestes þan is wyne
The gardyn is enclosed al about
Com forth my swete spouce / for out of dout
Thow hast me wounded in my hert o wyf
No spot / ne knowe I in the in al my lyf
Com forth and let vs taken our desport
I chaas þe for my wyf and my comfort
Soch old leude wordes vsed he
On Damyan / a signe made she
That he shold go byfore / wtith his clyket
This Damyan þan hath / opened þe weket
And in he stert and þtat in soch manere
That no wight / myght hym se nor here
And stil he sate vnder a bussh anone
This Ianuar as blynd as ony stone
Wtith Mayus in his honde and no wight mo /
In to this fressh gardyn / is a goo /
And clapt to þe wyket sodenly

In feith Squyer / þu hast þe wele yquytte
And gentilly / I preise wele thy witte
Koth þe Frankeleyn / consideryng þy youthee
So felyngly þu spekest / sir I the alough þe
As to my dome / þere is none that is here
Of elloquence / þat shall be þy pere
Yf þat þu lyve / god yeve þe gode chaunce
And in vꝰertue / send the contynuaunce
For of thy speche / I haue grete deynte
I haue a son / and by þe Trinitee
I hade lever / þan . xx . i . worth lond .
Though it right now / were fall in myn hond .
He were a man / of soch discrecou
As þat ye ben / fye on possessiou
But yf a man / be vꝰertuous wtith all /
I haue my son snbbed / and yitte shall
For he to vꝰertue / listeth nat to entende
But for to pley at dys / and dispende
And lese all þat he hath / is his vsage
And he hath leuer / talken wtith a page
Than to commou / wtith ony gentle wight /
Where he myght lern / gentilnes aright /
Strawe for gentilnes / koth our hoost /
What Frankeleyn / ꝑperde sir wele þu wost /
That ecch of you / mot tellen atte leest /
A tale or two / or breke his heest /
That knowe I wele sir / koth þe Frankeleyn
I pray you haueth me nat in disdeyn
Though to this man / I speke a word or two
Tell on thy tale wtithout / wordes mo /
Gladly sir hoost koth he / I woll obeye
Vn to yorur will / now herkeneth what I seye
I woll you nat contarie in no wise
As fer þat / all my wittes wollen suffise
I pray to god / þtat it may plesen you
Than wote I wele / þtat it is gode ynow
Hic desinit prologus de Frankeleyne et
Incipit fabula sua de Rokkes de Bretayn
Thise old gentle Bretons / in her dayes
Of diuers auentures / maden layes
Romaunced in her first bretons tung
Which laies wtith her Instrumentz þey song
Orels reden hem / for her plesaunce
And one of hem / haue I. in remembunace
Which I shall seyn / wtith gode will / as I can
But sires / by cause I am a borell man
At my begynnyng first I you beseche
Haue me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neuer retoryk certeyn
Thyng þat I speke / mot be bare and pleyn
I slepe neuꝰere on the mount of ꝑpernaso
Ne lerned neuer Marcus Tullyus Sythero
Colours ne knowe I noon / wtithout drede
But soch colorurs / þtat growen in the mede
Orels soch as men dye / or peynt
Colours of Rethoryk ben to me queynt
My sꝑperit feleth nat of soch matere
But yf you list / my tale shull ye here
IN Amoryk / þtat called is Bretayn
There was a knyght þtat loued and did his peyn
To sꝰerue a lady / in his best wise
And many a labour / many a grete emprise
He for his lady wrought / or she were won
For she was one / þe fairest vnder son
And eke þere to com of so high kynrede
That well vnethes durst þis knyght for drede
Tell hir his wo / his peyn / and his distresse
But at þe last / she for his worthynesse
And namely / for his meke obeysaunce
Hath soch a pite caught of his penaunce
That priuely / she fell of his accorde
To take hym / for hir housbond and hir lord
Of soch lordship / as men / han of her wyfes
And for to lede the more in blys / her lyfes
Of his free will / he swore hir / as a knyght
That neuer in all his lyve / he day ne nyght
Ne shold vp on hym take / no maistrie
Ageyn hir will ne kithe hir ielousye
But hir obeye / and folow hir will / in all
As ony louer vn to his lady shall
Saue þat þe name of souꝰeraintee
That wold he haue / for shame of his degree
She thanked hym / and wtith full grete humblesse
She seid sir seth of yorur gentilnesse
Ye ꝓprofre me to haue / so large a reyne
Ne wold neuꝰere god / bitwene vs tweyne
As in my gilt were either werre or stryf
Sir I woll be / your humble true wyf
Haue here my trouth / tyll þat myn hert brest
Thus ben þey bothe / in quyete / and in rest
For o thyng / sires / saafly dare I sey
That frendes / either other mot obey
Yf þey woll long holden company
Loue woll nat be constreyned by maistry
Whan maistrie comth / god of loue anone
Beteth his wynges / and fare wele / he is gone
Loue is a thyng as ony sꝑperit free
Wommen of kynd / desiren libertee
And nat to be constreyned as a thrall
And so dou men / yf I soth seyn shall
Loke who þat is most pacient in loue
He is at his auauntage / all aboue
Pacience is a hie vꝰertue / certeyn
For it venquysseth all / þise Clerkes seyn
Thynges that rigour / shold neuer atteyn
For euꝰery woorde / men mow nat chide or pleyn
Lerneth to suffre / orels so mot I goon
Ye shull it lerne / whether ye woll or noon
For in this world certeyn / þere no wight is
That he ne doth / or seith som tyme amys
Ire sekenesse / or constellacou
Wyn woo / or chaungyng of complexiou
Causeth full oft to dou amys or speken
On euꝰery wrong a man may nat be wreken
After the tyme most be / temꝑperaunce
To euꝰery wight / þat can on gouꝰernaunce
And therfore / hath this wise worthy knyght
To lyve in ease / suffraunce hir behight
And she to hym / full wisely gan to swere
That neuer shold there be / defaute in hire
Her mow men se / an humble wise accorde
Thus hath she take hir sꝰeruaunt and hir lord
Seruant in loue / and lord in mariage
Than was he / both in lordship and seruage
Seruage nay but in lordship aboue
Seth he hath / both his lady / and his loue
His lady sertes / and his wyf also
To which þat lawe of loue accordeth so
And whan he was / in this ꝓprosꝑperitee
Home wtith his wyf / he goth to his cuntree
Nat fer from Pedmark / þere his dwellyng was
Where as he lyueth / in blys / and in solas
Who coude tell / but he hade wedded be
The ioye / the ease / and the ꝓprosꝑperitee
That is bitwene / an housbond and his wyf
A yere and more / lasteth / þis blisfull lyf /
Tyll þtat þe knyght of which I speke of thus
That of kayrud / was cleped Arueragus
Shoop hym to gon / and dwell a yere or tweyn
In Engelond / þat cleped was eke Bretayn
To seke in armes / worship and honour
For all his lust / he sette / in soch labour
And dwelled þere .ij. yere / þe boke seith thus
Now woll I stynt of this Arureragus
And speken I woll of Dorigen his wyf
That loueth hir housbond / as hir hertes lyf
For his absence / wepeth she / and syketh
As don thise noble / wyfes whan hem lyketh
She morurneth / waketh / waileth / fasteth pleyneth
Desire of his pꝰersence / hir so distreyneth
That all this wide world she set at nought
Her frendes / which þtat knewe hir heuy þought
Comforten hir / in all þtat euꝰere they may
They pꝰerchen hir / þey tell hir nyght and day
That causeles / she sleeth hir self Allas
And euꝰery comfort / possible in þis caas
They don to hir / wtith all her besynesse
All for to make hir leve / hir heuynesse
By ꝓprocesse as ye knowen / euꝰerychone
Men mow so long grauen in a stone
Tyll som figure / þere in emprynted be
So long han þey comforted hir / till she
Resceyued hath / by hope and by resoūn
The empryntyng of hir consolacioūn
Thurgh which / hir grete sorow / gan aswage
She may nat all wey / duren / in soch rage
And eke Arueragus in all this care
Hath sent hir lres home of his welefare
And þat he wold com hastely agayn
Orels hade this sorow / hir hert slayn
Hir frendes sawe / her sorow gan to slake
And praied hir on knees / for goddes sake
To com and rome hir / in compaignye
Awey to dryve hir derk fantasye
And finally / she graunted þat request
For wele she saugh / it was for þe best
Now stode hir castell / fast by þe see
And often wtith hir frendes walketh she
Hir to desporte / vp on the bank on hie
Where she many a ship and barge sye
Seilyng her cours / where hem lust to go
But than was that a ꝑpercell of her woo
For to hir self full oft allas seith she
Is there no ship / of so many / as I se
Woll bryng home my lord þan / were myn hert
All verisshed of hise bitter peynes smert
Another tyme / þere wold she sit and thynk
And cast her yien / dounward from þe brynk
But whan she sawe / þe grisly Rokkes blake
For verray fere so wold / hir hert quake
Than on hir fete / she myght hir nought sustene
Than wold she sitte / adoun vp on þe grene
And pitously in to the see byhold
And sey right thus wtith sorowfull / sighes cold
Eterne god þat þurgh þy purveaunce
Ledest / þe world / by etꝰerne gouernaunce
In ydle as men seyn / ye no thyng make
But lord þise grisely fendly Rokkes blake
That semen rather / a foule confusiou
Of werk / þan ony feir creaciou
Of soch a ꝑperfite wise god and a stable
Why han ye wroght þis werk vnresonable
For by þis werk South / North West ne Est
There nys yfostred no man / by brede ne beste
It doth no gode to my witte / but annoyeth
Se ye nat lord / how mankynd / it destroyeth
An C. thousand bodies / of mankynd.
Han Rokkes slayn / all be þey nought in mynd
Which mankynd / is so fair []aa part / of thy werk
Þat þu it madest it like / to thyn owen merk
Than semed it ye hade a grete chiertee
Toward mankynd / but how þan may it be
That ye soch menes make / it to destroyen
Which menes do no gode / but euꝰere annoyen
I wote wele / clerkes woll seyn / as hem lest
By argumentes / þtat all is / for the best
Though I ne can þe causes / nat yknowe
But thylk god / þat made wynd for to blowe
As kepe my lord / this is the conclusioūn
To clerkes lete I . all disputacoūn
But wold god / þat all þise Rokkes blake
Were sonk in to hell / for his sake
Thise Rokkes sleen my hert / for þe fere
Thus she seid wtith many a pitous tere
Hir frendes saugh / þat it was no disport
To romen by the see / but discomforte
And shopen for to pley / som where elles
They ledden hir / by Ryvers / and by welles
And eke in other places dilectables
They dauncen and pleyn at chesse and tables
So on a day right on þe morowtide
Vn to a gardyn / þat was there beside
In which þey had made / her ordenaunce
Of vitaill / and other purveaunce
They goon / and pley hem / all the long day
And this was on þe .vjte. morow of May
Which May / had peynted wtith his sharp shoures
This gardyn / full of leves / and of floures
And craft of mannes hond / so curiously
Arrayed had this gardyn truely
That neuer was there gardyn / of soch aprys
But yf it were / þe verray ꝑperadys / .
The odour of floures / and þe fressh sight
Wold haue maked ony hert light
That euer was born / but yf to grete sekenes
Or to grete sorow / hold it in distresse
So full it was of beautee / wtith plesaunce
At after dyner gon / they to daunce
And syng also saue Dorigen allone
Which made all wey / hir compleynt and mone
For she ne saugh hym / on þe daunce go
That was hir housbond and hir loue also
For which she was in thought and in woo
And she wost nat what was best to doo //
But natheles she most a tyme abide
And wtith gode hope / let hir sorow slide
Vp on this daunce / amonges other men
Daunced a Squyer / byfore Dorigen
That fressher was and iolyer of array
As to my dome / þan is þe moneth of May
He syngeth and daunceth / passyng ony man
That is or was / seth the world began
There wtith he was / yf men shold hym discryve
One of the best faryng men / on lyve /
Yong strong right vꝰertuous / and riche and wise
And welebeloued / and holden in grete prise
And shortly / yf the soth / I tell shall
Vnwetyng of þis / Dorigen at all
This lusty Squyer / sꝰeruaunt to Venus
Which þat ycleped was / Aurelius
Hade loued hir best of ony creature
Two yere and more / as was his auenture
But neuer durst he tellen hir / his greuaunce
Wtithout cup / he drank all his penaunce
He was dispeired / no thing durst he sey
Saue in his songes / somwhat wold he wrey
His woo / as in a gentill compleynyng
He seid he loued / and was by loued no thing
Of which mater / made he many layes
Songes / compleyntes / roundels virelayes
How þat he durst nat his sorow tell
But languyssheth / as a fire doth in hell
And dey he most he seid / as did Ekko
For Narcisus þat durst nat tell hir wo
IN other maner than ye here me sey
Ne durst he nat to hir his woo bewrey
Save þat ꝑperauenture / som tyme / at daunces
There yong folk kepen her obseruaunces
It may wele be / he loked on hir face
In soch a wise / as man þat asketh grace
But no thing wist she / of his intent
Natheles it happed / or þey thens went
By cause that he was / hir neighbour
And was a man of worship and honour
And yknowen hym / had she / of tyme yore
They fell in speche / and forth more and more
Vn to that purpos / drough Aurelius
And whan he saugh his tyme / he seid thus
Madame koth he / by god þat this world made
Yf that I wist it myght yorur hert glade
I wold þat day / þat your Arueragus
Went ouer the see / þat I Aurelius
Hade went / there neuer I shold haue com agayn
For wele I wote / my sꝰeruyce / is in veyn
My guerdou is / but brestyng of myn hert
Madame / rueth on my peynes smert
For wtith a worde / ye mow me sle / or save
Here at your fete / god wold þtat I were grave
I ne haue as now / no leiser more to sey
Haue mꝰercy swete / or ye woll do me dey
She gan to loke vp / on Aurelius
Is this your will koth she / and seye ye thus
Never erst koth she / ne wist I what ye ment
But now Aurelye / I knowe yorur intent
By that god / þat yave me soule and lyf
Ne shall I neuer be / an vntrue wyf
In worde ne werk as for / as I haue witte
I woll ben his to whom þat I am knytte
Take this / for finall answere / as of me
But after that in pley thus seid she
Aurely koth she / by high god aboue
Yitte wold I graunt you / to ben yorur loue
Sen I you se / so pitously compleyne
Loke what daye / endelong Bretayne
Ye remeve / all the Rokkes / stone by stone
That they ne let ship / ne bote to gone
I sey whan ye han made / þe coost so clene
Of Rokkes / that þere is no stone ysene
Than woll I love you best / of ony man
Haue here my trouth / in all þtat euꝰere I can
Is there noon other grace / in you koth he
No by þat lord koth she / þtat maked me
For wele I wote / þat it shall neuer betide
Let soch sorowes / from your hert slide
What deyntee / shold a man haue in his lyf
For to go loue / anoter mannes wyf
That hath hir body / whan so hym lyketh
Aurelius full ofte / sore syketh
Woo was Aurelius / whan þat he this herd
And wtith a sorowfull answere / he þus answerd
Madame koth he / this were an impossible
Than mot I deye / of soden deth possible
And wtith that worde / he turned hym anone
Tho com her other frendes manyone
And in the Aleyes / romed vp and doun
And no thing wisten / of this conclusioūn
But sodenly bygon / to reuell newe
Tyll that the bright son / hath lost his hewe
The orisount hath reft / þe son his light
This is as moch to sey / as it was nyght
And home þey gon / in Ioye and solace
Saue onely / wrecched Aurelius Allas
He to his hous is gone wtith sorowfull hert
He seith he may nat / from his deth astert
Hym semed þat he felt by his hert cold.
Vp to þe heuen / his hondes he gan hold.
And on his knees / bare / he set hym doun
And in his ravyng seid his orisoun
For verray woo / out of his wit he breid.
He nyst / what he spake / but þus he seid.
Wtith pitous hert his pleynt hath he bygon
Vn to þe goddes / and first to þe son
He seid Appollo / god and gouꝰernour
Of euꝰery plaunt / herbe / tree and flour
That yeuest / after thy declynacou
To ecch of hem his tyme / and his sesou
As thyn herber chaungeth / lowe or hye
Lord Phebus cast thy mꝰerciable yie
On wrecched Aurelius / which þtat am but lorn
Lo lord / my lady hath my deth ysworn /
Wtithouten gilt thy benignytee
Vp on my dedely hert / haue som pitee
For wele I wote lord Phebus yf ye lest /
Ye mow me help / save my lady best
Now vouche saufe / þat I may you devise
How þat I may be holpen / and in what wise
Your blisfull suster / lucyna the shene
That of the See / is chief goddes and quene
Though Neptunus / haue deitee in the see
Yitte Emꝑperice aboue hym / is she
Ye knowen wele lord þat right / as hir desire
Is to be quykked and lighted of your fire
For which / she foloweth you / full besely
Right so / the see desireth naturely
To folowen hir as she that is goddes /
Both in the see / and ryvers more and lesse
Wherfore lord Phebus / þis is my request
Do this myracle / or do myn hert brest
That now next / at this apposissioūn
Which in the signe shall be of þe lyou
As prayeth hir / so grete a flode to bryng
That . v . fadom / at þe lest / it ouerspryng
The hiest Rok in Amorik Bretayn
And let this flode endure / yeres . ij .
Lord Phebus do this myracle for me
Pray hir she go / no faster cours þan ye
I sey prayeth your suster that she go
No faster cours / þan þe þise yeres two
Than shall she be even at þe full all wey
And spryng flode lastyng both nyght and dey
And but she vouchesauf in soch manere
To graunt me my souꝰerain lady dere
Pray hir to synk / euꝰery Rok adoun
In to hir owen derk regioun
Vnder þe ground / there Pluto dwelleth in
Or neuer mo / shall I my lady wyn
Thy temple of Delphos / woll I barefote seke
Lord Phebus se the teres on my cheke
And of my peyn / haue som compassiou
And wtith that word / in sorow he fell doun
And long tyme he lay / forth in a traunce
His brother / which that knewe / of his penaunce
Vp caught hym / and to bed he hath hym brought
Dispeired in this turment and this thought
Late I this wofull creature lye
Chese he for me / whether he woll lyve or deye
Arueragus wtith hele and grete honour
As he þat was / of Chiualrye the flour
Is com home / and other worthy men
O blithefull / art þu now / þu Doregen
That hast thy lusty husbond in þyn armes
The fressh knght / þe worthy men of Armes
That loueth the / as his owen hertes lyf
No thyng lust hym / to ben ymagenatyf
Yf ony wight hade spoke / while he was out
To hir of loue / he ne hade of it / no dout
He nought entendeth / to no soch matere
But daunceth Iusteth / and maketh hir gode chere
And thus in ioye and blys / I lete hem dwell
And of the seke / Aurelius woll I tell
In langour / and in turment furious
Two yere and more lay wrecched Aurelius
Or ony fote on erthe / he myght gone
Ne comforte in this tyme / hath he none
Save of his brother / which þat was a clerk
He knewe of all this woo / and all þis werk
For to none other creature certeyn
Of this mater he durst no word seyn
Vnder his brest he bare it more secree
Than euer did Pamphilus / for Galathee
His brest was hole / wtithout for to seen
But in his hert / ay was þe arrow keen
And wele ye knowe / þat of Sursanure
In Surgerie is ꝑperlious the cure /
But men myght touche / þe arow / or com there by
His brother wepe / and weiled priuely
Tyll atte last hym fell in remembraunce
That whiles he was at Orliance in Fraunce
As yong clerkes / that ben lykerous
To reden artes / that ben curious
Seken in euꝰery halke / and euꝰery herne
Particuler sciences / for to lerne
He hym remembred / vp on a day
At Orliaunce in / studie a boke he say
Of Magyk naturell / which his felawe
That was that tyme / a bacheler of lawe
All were he there to lerne another craft.
Had priuely / vp on his desk ylaft
Which boke / spake mochell of þe oꝑperacōmns
Touchyng the .xxviijtiri. mansions
That longeth to the mone / and soch folie
As in our daies / is nat worth a flie
For holy chirche seith in our byleve
Ne suffreth noon illusiou vs to greve
And whan this boke was in his remembraunce
Anone for Ioye / his hert gan to daunce
And to hym self he seid priuelye
My brother shall be warisshed hastely
For I am siker / þat there ben sciences
By which men maken / diuꝰers apparences
Soch as thise / sotle tregetours pley
For oft / at festes / haue I wele herd sey
That Tregetours wtithin / an hall large
Han made com in water and a barge
And in the hall / rowen vp and doun
Som tyme hath semed com / a wode lyoun
And som tyme floures / spryng as in a mede
A vynte somtyme and grapes white and rede
Som tyme a Castell of lyme / and stone
And whan hym lyked / voide it anone
Thus semed it / to euꝰery mannes sight
Now than conclude I thus / þat yf I myght
At Orliaunce som old felawe / I fynd.
That hade thise mones mansions / in mynd
Or other Magyk naturell aboue
He shold wele make / my brother haue his love
For wtith an apparence / a clerk may make
To mannes sight / þat all þe Rokkes blake
Of Bretayn / were voided euꝰerychone
And shippes / by the brynk com and gone
And in soch fourme / endure a day or two
Than were my brother / warisshed of his wo
Than most she nedes / hold hir byheste
Orels he shall shame hir / at the leste
What shold I make / a lenger tale of this
Vn to his brothers bed / he cōmmen is
And soch comforte he yave hym for to goon
To Orliaunce / þat he vp stert anoon
And on his waye / forward þan is he fare
In hope to be lissed of his care
Whan they were com / all most to the Citee
But yif it were a .ij. furlong or .iij.
A yong Clerk romyng by hym selue þey met
Which that in latyn / hem thriftely gret
And after þat / he seid / a wonder thyng
I knowe koth he / the cause of yorur commyng
And or they ferther / ony fote went
He told hem all þat was / in her intent
This bretoūn clerk hym asked of felawes
The which that he hade knowe / in old dawes
And he answerd hym þat / þey dede were
For which he wept full oft full many a tere
Doun of his hors / Aurelius light anoon
And wtith þis Magicien / forth he is goūn
Home to his hous / and made hem wele at ese
Hem lakked no vitail / þat myght hem plese
So wele arraied hous / as þer was one
Aurelius in his lyf sawe neuer none
He shewed hym / or he went to soupere
Forestes parkes / full of wild dere
There sawe he hertes / wtith her hornes hie
The grettest / þtat euer / were seen wtith yie
He sawe of hem / an hundred slayn wtith houndes
And som wtith arowes blede / of bitter woundes
He sawe whan voided were þe wild dere
Thise Fauconers / vp on a fayre Ryvere
That wtith her faucons / han the heroūn slayn
Tho sawe he knyghtes iustyng on a playn
And after this / he dyd hym soch plesaunce
That he hym shewed his lady / on a daunce
On which hym self / daunced / as hym thought
And whan this maister that þis magyk wrought
Sawe it was tyme / he clapt his handes to
And fare wele / all our revell was agoo
And remeved þey neuer / out of the hous
While they sawe / all this sight mꝰervelous
But in his stodie / there as his bokes be
They sitten still / but no wight / but þey .iij
To hym þis maister / called his squyere
And seid hym thus / is redy our soupere
All most an houre it is / yvndre take /
Seth I you bad oure soper for to make
Whan that thise worthy men / wenten wtith me
In to my stodye / there as my bokes be
Sir koth this Squyer / whan þat it liketh you
It is all redy / þough ye woll right now
Go we than soupe koth he / for the best
Thise amerous folk / somtyme mot haue her rest
At after souper / fell they in tretee
What some shold this / maisters guerdou be
To remeve all þe Rokkes / of Bretayn
And eke from Geround / to þe mount of Sayn
He made it straunge / and swore so god hym save
Lesse þan a . Ml . pound / he wold nat haue
Ne gladly for þe som / he wold nat gone
Aurelius / wtith blisfull hert anone
Answerd thus / fy on a . Ml . pound
This wide world / which þtat men seyn is so round
I wold it yeve / yf I were lord of it
This bargayn is full dryve / for we ben knytt
Ye shull be payed truely / by my trouth
But loketh now / for no necligence or slouth
Ye tarie vs here / no lenger þan to morow
Nay koth this clerk haue here my feith to borow
To bed is gone Aurelius whan hym lest
An well nye all þat nyght he hade his rest
What for his labour / and his hope of blys /
His wofull hert of penaunce / hade a lys /
Vp on the morow / whan it was day
To Britayn toke they / the right way
Aurelius / and this Magicien beside
And ben discended there þey wold abide
And this was / as þise bokes me remembre
The cold frosty sesou of Decembre
Phebus wax old / and hewed like latoun
That in his hote declinacou
Shone / as the burned gold / wtith stremes bright
But now in Capricorn / adoun he light
Where as he shoon full pale / I dare wele seyn
The bitter frostes / wtith þe sleet and reyn
Destroyed hath þe grene in euꝰery yerd.
Ianus sit by the fire / wtith double berd.
And drynketh of his bugle horn þe wyn
Byfore hym stant braun / of þe tusked swyn
And no well / krieth / euꝰery lusty man
Aurelius in all that ever he can
Doth to this maister / chier and reuꝰerence
And prayeth hym / to do his diligence
To bryng hym out / of his peynes smert
Or wtith a swerd / he wold slit his hert
This subtle clerk soch routh / had of this man
That nyght and day / he sped hym þtat he can
To waiten a tyme / of his conclusiou
This is to sey / to make illusiou
By soch an apparence / or iogelerye
I ne can no tꝰermes / of Astrologye
That she and euꝰery wight shold wene and seye
That of Bretayn / þe Rokkes / were awey
Orels þey were sunken vnder ground
So at the last / he hath his tyme yfound.
To make his Iapes / and his wrecchednes
Of soch a suꝑpersticies cursednesse
His tables tolletanes / forth he brought
Full wele corrected / ne there lakked nought
Neither his collect ne his expans yeres
Ne his rotes / ne his other geres
As ben his sentres / and his argumentes
And his ꝓproporcionels / conuenientz
For his equacions / in euꝰery thyng
And by his .viij spere / in his werkyng
He knewe full wele how fer Alnath was shoue
From the hede / of thilk fix Aries above
That in þe .ix. spere considered is
Full stotelly he calcled all this
Whan he hade found / his first mansioūn
He knewe þe remenaunt by ꝓproporcioūn
And knew the arisyng / of his mone wele
And in whoos face / and tꝰerme euꝰerydele
And knewe full wele / þe mones mansioūn
Accordaunt to his oꝑperacou
And knew also / his other obꝸseruaunces
For which illusions / and soch myschaunces
As hethen folk vseden in tho dayes
For which no lenger / maketh / he delayes
But þurgh his Magyk / for a weke or twey
It semed þat all þe Rokkes / were awey
Aurelius / which þat yitt dispaired is
Whether he shall haue his lyf or fare amys
Awaiteth nyght / and day on this myracle
And whan he knewe / þat þere was none obstacle
That voided were þise Rokkes euꝰerychone
Doun to this maistres / fete he fell anone
And seid I wofull / wrecched Aurelius
Thank you lord / and lady myn Venus
That me han holpen / from my cares cold
And to þe temple his wey forth / hath he hold
Where as he knewe / he shold his lady se
And whan he saugh his tyme / anone right he
Wtith dredefull hert / and wtith humble chere
Salued hath / his souꝰerayn lady dere
My rightfull lady / koth þis wofull man
Whom I most drede / and love / as I best can
And lothest were / of all þis world displese
Nere it that I for you / haue soch disese
That I mot dyen at your fote anoon
Nought wold I tell how me is woo begoon
But certes / either most I dey or pleyn
Ye slee me giltles for verray peyn
But of my deth / þough þat ye haue no routh
Aviseth you or þat ye breke your trouth
Repenteth you / for þat ylk god aboue
Or ye me slee / bicause / þat I you loue
For madame / wele ye wote þat ye han hight /
Nat that I chalange ony þyng of right
Of you my souꝰerayn lady / but your grace
But in a gardyn / yonder at soch a place
Ye wote right wele / what ye behight me
And in myn honde / your treuth plight ye
To loue me best god wote ye seid so
All be / þat I vn worthy / am there to /
Madame I speke it / for the honour of you
More than to save / myn hertes lyf right now
I haue doon so / as ye cōmmaunded me
And yf ye vouchesauf / ye may go se
Doth as you lest haue yorur byhest in mynd
For quyk or dede / right there ye shull me fynd
In you lyeth all / to do me lyve or deye
But wele I wote / þe Rokkes ben aweye
He taketh his leve / and she astonyed stode
In all hir face / nas a drop of blode
She wend neuer haue com in soch a trap
Allas koth she / þat euer this shold hap
For wend I neuꝰere / by possibilitee
That soch a moastre / or mꝰeruail myght be
It is ayeinst þe ꝓprocesse of nature
And home she goth / a sorowfull creature
For verray fere / vnneth may she go
She wepeth an waileth / all a day or twoo
And swowneth / þat it ruth was for to se
But why it was / to no wight told she
For out of toun / was goon Arueragus
But to hir self she spake and seid thus
Wtith face pale / and wtith full sorowfull chiere
In hir compleynt / as ye shull after here
Allas koth she / on the fortune I pleyn
That vnware / hast wrapped me in thy cheyn
From which to escape / wote I no socour
Saue onely deth / or elles dishonour
One of þise two / by houeth me to chese
But natheles / yitte haue I leuer to lese
My lyf / þan of my body haue a shame
Or knowe my self / fals / or lese my name
And wtith my deth / I may be quyt ywis
Hath there nat many a noble wyf or this
And many a maid slayn hir self allas
Rather þan wtith hir body / do trespas
Yis certes / lo thise stories beren wtithnes
Whan .xxxtiri Tirauntz / full of cursednes
Had slayn Phidou / in Athenes at þe fest
They commaunded his doughtren / for to arest
And hem bryng bifore hem / in despite
All naked / to full fill her foule delite
And in her faders blode / þey made hem daunce
Vp on the pament god yeve hem myschaunce
For which thise wofull maydyns / full of drede
Rather than they / wold lese her maydenhede
They priuely ben stert in to a well
And dreynt hem seluen / as bokes vs tell
They of Metene lete enquere / and seke
Of lacedomy fifty maidens eke /
On which þey wolden do her lecherie
But was there none / of all þat compaignye
That she nas slayn / and wtith a gode intent
Chaas rather for to deye / þan assent
To ben oppꝰerssed / of her maydenhede
Why shold I than to deye / ben in drede
Lo eke þe tyraunt / Aristoclides
That loued a maiden þtat hight / Stymphalides
Whan that hir fader / slayn was on a nyght
Vn to Dianes temple / goth she right
And hent þe ymage / in her hondes twoo
From which / ymage / wold she neuꝰere go
No wight ne myght her hondes of it arrace
Tyll she was slayn / in þe self place
Now seth þat maydens / haden soch despit
To ben defouled / wtith mannes foule delit /
Wele ought I a wyf rather my seluen slee
Than be defouled / as it thynketh me
What shall I sey / of Hasternbales wyf
That at Cartage / byraft hir self / hir lyf
For whan she sawe / þat Romaynes wan þe toun
She toke hir children all / and skypt adoun
In to the fire / and chaas rather to deye
Than ony Romayn did hir velanye
Hath nat lucresse / yslayn hir self allas
At Rome whan she opꝰerssed was
Of Tarquyn / for hir thought it was a shame
To lyven whan she hade lost / hir name
The .vij. maydens of Melesye also
Han slayn hem self / for verray drede and wo
Rather than folk of sawle / hem shold oppresse
Mo than a Thousand stories / as I gesse
Coude I now tell / as touchyng þis matere
Whan Abradace was slayn / his wyf so dere
Hir selven slough / and lete hir blode to glide
In habradeces woundes / depe and wide
And seid my body / atte lest wey
There shall no wight defoule / yf I may
What shold I mo ensaumples / here of seyn
Sen that so many / han hem selven sleyn
Wele rather / than they wold defouled be
I woll conclude / þat it is best for me
To sle my self / than be defouled thus
I woll be true / vn to Arueragus
Or rather sle my self / in som manere
As did Democicius doughter dere
By cause / þat she wold nat defouled be
O Cedasus / it is full grete pitee
To reden / how thy doughtren / dyden allas
That slowen hem self / for soch manꝰere cas
As grete pitee / was it / or wele more
The Theban mayden / þat for Nichamore
Hir seluen slough / right for soch manꝰere wo
Another Theban mayden / did right so
For one of Macedoyn / hade hir opressed
She wtith hir deth / hir maydenhode redressed
What shall I seyn / of Nicerates wyf
That for soch caas / byraft hir self hir lyf
How true eke was / Alcebiades
His loue / þat rather for to die chees
Than for to suffre / his body vnburied be
Lo which a wyf / was Alceste koth she
What seith Omere / of gode Penolopee
All Grece knoweth / of hir chastitee
ꝐPerde of laodomiA is writen thus
That whan at Troy / was slayn ꝒProtheselus
No lenger wold she lyve / after his day
The same of Noble Porcia tell I may
Wtithout brutus / coude she nat lyve
To whom she hade / all hole hir hert yeve
The ꝑperfite wyfhode / of Arthemesye
Honoured is / thurght all the barbarie
O Theuta quene / thy wyfly chastitee
To all wyfes / may / a Myrrour be
Thus pleyned Dorigen / a day or twey
Purposyng ever / þat she wold dey
But nathes vp on the iijde. nyght
Home cam Arueragus / þis worthy knyght
And axed hir / why she wepe so sore
Allas koth she / þat euer I was bore
And faster wept she / þan she did to forn
Thus haue I seid koth she / þus have I sworn
And told hym all / as ye haue herd to fore
It nedeth nat / reherce it you no more
This housbond wtith glad chere / and frendly wise
Answerd and seid / as I shall you devise
Is there ought elles / Dorigen but this
Nay nay koth she / god help me so as wis
This is to moch / and it were goddes will
Ye wyf koth he / let slepen that is still
It may be wele / ꝑperauenture yitte to day
Ye shull your trouth hold / by my fay
For god so wisly / haue mꝰercy vp on me
I hade wele leuer / stikked for to be /
For verray loue / which that I to you haue
But yf / ye shold / your trouth / kepe and save
Trouth is the hiest thyng þat man may kepe
But wtith þat word he brast anon to wepe
And seid / I you forbede vp on peyn of deth
That neuer while you lasteth lyf or breth
To no wight / tell þu of this auenture
As I may best I woll my wo endure
Ne make no countenaunce of hevynes
That folk of you / mow deme harme orgesse
And forth he cleped a squyer and a meid
Goth forth anon / wtith Dorigen he seid
And bryng hir to soch a place anoon
They take her leve / and on her wey þey gon
But þey ne wist why she theder went
He nold no wight tell his intent
This Squyer / which þat hight Aurelius
On Dorigen / that was so amerus
Of auenture / happed hir to mete
Amyd þe toun right in þe quykkest strete
As she was boun to go the wey forth right
Toward the gardyn there as she hade hight
And he was to þe / gardynward also
For wele he spied whan she wold go
Out of hir hous to ony maner place
But þus þey mette / of auenture or grace
And he salueth hir / wtith gode intent
And axed of hir whider ward she went
And she answerd / half as she were mad
Vn to the gardyn as myn housbond bad
My trouth for to hold / Allas Allas
Aurelius gan wonder on þis caas
And in his hert hade grete compassiou
Of hir / and hir lamentacou
And of Arueragus / þe worthy knyght
That bade hir hold / all þtat she hade hight
So loth hym was his wif / shold breke hir treuth
And in his hert he caught of þis grete reuth
Consideryng þe best on euꝰery side
That from his lust yitte leuer were hym bide
Than dou so heigh a cherlyssh wrecchednes
Ayeinst fraunchise / and all gentilles
For which in fewe wordes seid he þus
Madame seith to your lord / Arueragus
That seth I se / his grete gentilles
To you / and eke I se wele / your distres
That hym were leuer haue shame / and þat were reuth
Than ye to me / shold breke þus your treuth
I haue wele lever ever to suffre wo
Than I deꝑpert the love / bitwene you two
I you relese madame / in to your honde
Quyte euꝰery surement and euꝰery bonde
That ye han made / to me / as here byforn
Seth thylk tyme / which þat ye were born
My trouth I plight I shall you neuer repꝰerue
Of no byhest and here I take my leue
As of þe truest / and þe best wyf
That euer yitte / I knew in all my lyf
But euꝰery wyf be ware / of hir byhest
On Dorigen / remembreth atte lest
Thus can a Squyer dou a gentle dede
As wele as can a knyght wtithout drede
She thanketh hym / vp on her knees bare
And home to hir housbond / is she fare
And told hym all / as ye han herd me seid
And be ye siker / he was so wele appeid
That it were impossible / me to write
What shold I lenger / of þis caas endite
Arueragus / and dorigen his wyf
In souꝰerayn blys / leden forth her lyf
Neuer eft / was þere angre / hem bitwene
He cherissheth hir / right as she were a quene
And she was to hym true / for euꝰermore
Of thise .ij. folk ye gete of me no more
Aurelius / þat his cost hath all forlorn
Curseth the tyme / þat euer he was born
Allas koth he / allas that I behight
Of pured gold a Ml. pound of wight
Vn to this Philosophre / how shall I do
I sey no more / but þat I am fordo
Myn heritage mot I nedes sell
And ben a begger / here may I nat dwell
And shame all my kynrede in þis place
But I of hym / myght gete better grace
But natheles / I woll of hym assaie
At certein dayes / yere by yere to paye
And thank hym / of his grete curtesye
My trouth woll I kepe / I woll nat lye
Wtith hert sore / he goth vn to his coffre
And brought gold / vn to þis filisoffre
The value of .C pound I gesse
And hym besecheth / of his gentillesse
To graunt hym dayes / of þe remenaunt
And seid maister / I dare wele make auaunt
I failed neuer of my trouth as yitte
For sekerly / my det / shall be quytte
Towardes you / how ever þat I fare
To gon a beggyng in my kirtle bare
But wold ye vouchesauf vp on seurtee
Two yere or iij. for to respiten me
Than were I wele / for elles mot I sell
Myn heritage / þere nys no more to tell
This Philisophre / soberly answerd
And seid thus / whan he þise wordes herd
Haue I nat hold couenaunt vn to the
Yis certes / wele and truely koth he
Hast þu nat hade / thy lady as þe lyketh
No no koth he / and sorowfully he siketh
What was þe cause / tell me / yf þu can
Aurelius his tale / anone bygan
And told hym all / as ye han herd byfore
It nedeth nat to you / reherce it no more
He seid Arueragus / of gentilnesse
Had lever dye in sorow / and distresse
Than that his wyf / were of hir treuth fals
The sorow of Dorigen / he told hemals
How loth hir was / to ben a wykked wyf
And þat she lost hade leuer / þtat day hir lyf
And þat hir trouth / she swo of Innocence
She neuer erst / hade herd speke of Apparence
That made hym haue of hir so grete pite
And right / as frely as he sent hir me
As frely / sent I hir / to hym ageyn
This is all and som / þere is no more to seyn
This Philisophre answerd / leue brother
Euꝰery of you did gentilly / till other
Thow art a Squyer / and he is a knyght
But god forbede / for his blisfull myght
But yf a clerk / coude don a gentle dede
As wele / as ony of you / wtithout drede
Sir I reles the / thy thousand pound
As þu right now / were crope out of þe ground
Ne neuer or now / ne hadest þu knowen me
For sir I woll nat take / a peny of the
For all my craft / ne nought / for my trauaill
Thow hast ypaied well / for my vitaill
It is ynough / and fare wele haue gode day
And toke his hors / and forth he goth his way
Lordyngs this questiou / þan woll I aske
Which was the most free / as thynketh you
Now telleth me / or þat ye ferther wend
I can no more / my tale is / at an end.
Sic desinit fabula de Frankelayn /
(base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature

div.l: (base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
