div.l: (base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
⁊ incipit ꝓprologus De le Pardoner
Oure hoste bigan to swere / as he were wode
Harrowe koth he / by nayles and by blode
This was a fals cherll / a fals Iustise
As shamefull deth / as hert can devise
Com to thise Iuges / and her aduocates
Allas this sely maid is slayn algates
Allas to dere / a bought she hir beautee
Wherfore I seye all day / þat men mow se
That yiftes of fortune / and of nature
Ben cause of deth / of many a creature
Of both yiftes / þat I speke of now
Men han full oft more for harme þan prow
But truely myn owen maister dere
This is a pitous tale / for to here
But natheles / passe ouer is no force
I pray to god / so save þy gentill corce
And eke þy orynals / and þy Iurdones
Thyn Ypocras / and thy galiones
And euꝰery boist full of letuarie
God blys hem / and our lady Seint Marie
So mot I theen / þu art a ꝓpropre man
And like a pꝰerlat / by Seint Ronyan
Seid I nat wele / I can nat speke in t ꝰerme
But wele I wote / þu dost myn hert to erme
That I all most haue caught a cardynacle
By Corpus bones / but I haue triacle
Orels a draught of moist and corny ale
Or but I here anoon / a mery tale
Myn hert is lost / for pitee of this maid
Thow beall Amy / þu ꝐPerdoner he said
Tell vs som merth of iapes right anoon
It shall be don koth he / by god and by seint Iohn
But first koth he / here at þis ale stake
I woll both drynk / and ete of a cake
But right anon / thise ientiles gan to krie
Nay let hym nat tell vs / no ribaudye
Tell vs som morall thing þat we may lere
Som wit and þan woll we gladly here
I graunt ywis koth he / but I most thynk
Vp on som honest þing while þat I drynk
Sic desinit ꝓprologus

⁊ incipit fabula de Radix
Omniu malorum est Cupiditas ~~
Lordyngs koth he / in chirches whan I preche
I peyn me to haue / an hauten speche
And ryng out as loude / as doth a bell
For I can all by rote / that I tell /
First I ꝓpronounce / from whens þat I com /
And þan myn bulles shewe I all and som
Our lieges lord seal / on my patent
I shewe first / my body to warent
That no man be so bold nor prest ne clerk
Me to destourbe / of cristes holy werk
And after that / þan tell I forth my tales
Bulles of Popes / and of cardynales
Of Patriarkes / and of bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn speke I wordes fewe
To saver wtith my pꝰerdicaciou
In euꝰery village / and in euꝰery toun
This is my teme and shall / and euꝰere was
Radix omniu malorum est cupiditas
Than shewe I forth / my long cristall stones
Ycrammed full of cloutes / and of bones
Relykkes ben they / as wene they ecchone
Than haue I a latou / a sholder bone
Which þat was of an holy Iewes shepe
Gode men I sey / take of my wordes kepe
Yf þat this bon be wassh in ony well
Yf Cow or Calf / Oxe or shepe swell
That ony worme hath ete / or worme ystong
Take water of þat well / and wassh his tong
And it is hole anone / and yitte ferthermore
Of pokkes of scabbes / and of euꝰery sore
Shall euꝰery shepe / be hole / þat of this well
Drynketh a draught / take kepe eke what I tell
Yf þat þe gode man þat þe bestes oweth
Woll euꝰery weke / or þat þe cok hym croweth
Fastyng drynken / of þe well a draught
As thilk holy Iewes / our elders taught
His bestes / and his store shall multeplie
And sir also / it heleth ielousye
For though a man befall in ielous rage
Let make wtith this water / his potage
And never shall he more his wyf mystrust
Though he the soth / of hir defaute wost
All hade she take prestes / ij . or . iij .
Here is a metayn eke / þat ye may se
He that his honde woll put in this mitayn
He shall haue multipliyng / of his grayn
Whan he hath sowe / be it whete or otes
So that he offre pens / or elles grotes
Gode men and wommen o thyng warn I you
If ony wight / be in this chirche now
That hath do syn / so horrible þat he
Dare nat for shame / of it yshriven be
Or ony womman / be she yong or old
That hath maked hir housbond cokold
Soch folk shall haue no power / ne no grace
To offre to my relikkes / in this place
And who so fyndeth him out of soch blame
They woll com vp / and offre a goddes name
And I assoile hym / by the auctoritee
Which that by bull / ygraunted was to me
By this gaude / haue I won by yere
An hundred mark / seth I was ꝑperdonere
I stode like a clerk / in my pulpit
And whan the leud peple is doun set
I preche so / as ye han herd byfore
And tell an hundred fals Iapes more
Than peyn I forth / to strecche forth þe nek
And est and west vp on peple I bek
As doth a dove / sittyng on a bern
Myn handes / and my tung gone so yern
That it is Ioye / to se my besynesse
Of Auarice / and of soch cursednesse
Is all my pꝰerchyng / for to make hem fre
To yeve her pens / and namely vn to me
For myn entent is nat but for to wyn
And no thing for correccou of syn
I rek never / whan þat þey ben buried
Though þat her soules / gon a blakberied
For certes many a pꝰerdicaciou
Comth oft / of euyll intencou
Som for plesaunce of folk / and flaterie
To ben avaunced / by Ipocrisie
And som for veyn glorie / and som for hate
For whan I dare non / otherwise debade
Than woll I styng hym / wtith my tung smert
In pꝰerchyng / so that he shall nat astert
To ben defamed falsly / yf that he
Haue trespased to my brethern or to me
For though I tell nat his ꝓpropre name
Men shull wele knowe / þat it is þe same
By signes / and by other circumstaunces
Thus quyte I folk þat don vs displesaunces
Thus spitte I out my venym / vnder hewe
Of holynesse / to seme holy / and true
But shortly myn entent I woll devise
I preche of no thyng / but for Covetise
Therfore my teme is yitte / and euꝰere was
Radix malorum est Cupiditas
Thus can I pꝰerche / ayeinst þe same vice
Which þat I vse / and þat is Avarice
But þough my self be gilty in þat syn
Yitte kan I make / other folk to wyn
From Avarice / and sore to repent
But þat is nat my principall intent
I preche no thing / but for Couetise
Of this mater it ought / ynough suffise
Than tell I hem ensaumples many one
Of old stories / long tyme agone
For leud peple loven tales old
Soch þynges con þey wele reporte and hold
What trowe ye / þat whiles I may pꝰerche
And wyn gold and siluꝰere / for I teche
That I woll lyve / in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neuer truely
For I woll pꝰerche and beg / in sondry londes
I woll nat do no labour / wtith myn hondes
Ne make baskettes / and lyve þere by
By cause I woll nat beg Idely
I woll non of thapposteles countrefete
I woll haue maney / woull / chese and whete
All were it yeve / of þe pourest page
Or of the porest widow / in a village
All shold hir children sterue for myn
Nay I woll drynk licour / of the vyn
And haue a ioly wenche in euꝰery toun
But herkeneth lordyngs / as in conclusioun
Your likyng is / that I shall tell a tale
Now haue I drunk / a draught of cornyale
By god I hope / I shall you tell a thing
That shall by resou be / at your likyng
For þough my self be a full vicious man
A morall tale yitte / I you tell can
Which I am wont to pꝰerche for to wyn
Now hold your pes / my tale I woll begyn
IN Flaundres whilom / was a companye
Of yong folk / þat haunteden folye
As Riot hasard / Stewes / and Tavernes
Where as wtith harpes / lutes / and giterns
They daunce and pleye at dys / both day and nyght
And eten also / and drunk ouer her myght /
Thurgh which þey done / þe devill sacrifice
Wtithin þat deuels temple / in cursed wise
By suꝑperfluytee abhominable
Her othes ben so grete / and so dampnable
That it is grisly to here hem swere
Our blessed lordes body / þey to tere
Hem thought þat Iewes / rent hym nat ynough
And ecch of hem / at others syn lough
And right anon cam / Tombesters
Fetise and smale / and yong frustesters
Syngers wtith harpes / baudes / and waifrers
Which ben the vꝰerray deuels officers
To kyndell and blowe þe fire of lecherie
That is annexed vn to Glotonye
The holy writ take I to my witnes
That luxury is in wyn and drunkennes
Lo how þat drunken loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doughters two / vnwetyngly
So drunk he was / he nyst what he wrought
Herodes / who / so wele þe stories sought
Whan he of wyn / was replete at his fest
Right / at his owen table / he yaf his hest
To slen þe Baptist Iohn full giltles
Senek seith a gode worde / doutles
He seith he can / no diffrence fynd
Bitwene a man þat is / out of his mynd
And a man which þat is drunklewe
But that wodenes / yfallen in a shrewe
ꝐPerseuereth lenger / þan doth drunkennesse
O glotonye full of cursednesse
O cause first / of our confusiou
O originall / of our dampnasiou
Tyll crist hade bought vs / wtith his blode ageyn
Lo how dere / shortly for to seyn
Abought was / thilk cursed velanye
Corupte was all this world for glotonye
Adam our fader / and his wif also
From ꝐPeradys / to labour and to wo
Were dryven / for þat vice / it is no drede
For while þtat Adam fasted / as I rede
He was in ꝐPeradys / and whan þat he
Ete of the fruyt / defended on a tree
Anoon he was outcast / to wo and peyn
O glotonye / on the wele ought vs pleyn
O wist a man / how many maladies
Folowen of excesse / and of glotonyes
He wold ben / þe more mesurable
Of his diete / sittyng at his table
Allas the short throte / þe tendre mouth
Maketh þat Est and West / North and South
In erthe / in eire / in water / man to swynk
To gete a glotou / deynte mete and drynk
Of this mater / o poule wele canst þu trete
Mete vn to wombe / and wombe eke vn to mete
Shall god destroyen both / as Paulus seith
Allas a foule þyng / it is by my feith
To sey this worde / and fouler is þe dede
Whan man so drynketh / of þe white and rede
That of his throte / he maketh his pꝰeruee
Thurgh thilk cursed suꝑperfluytee
The Apostle wepyng seith full pitously
There walk many of which you told haue I
I sey it now wepyng / wtith pitous voys
There ben enemyes / of cristes croys
Of which þe ende is deth / wombe is her god
O wombe / o bely / o stynkyng cod
Fulfilled þe tung / and of corrupcou
At either ende of þe / foule is þe soun
How grete laborur / and cost is þe to fynd
Thise Cokes / how þey stamp / streyne and grynd
To turnen substaunce / in to accident
To fulfill / all thy likerous talent
Out of the harde bones knokke they
The marye / for þey cast nat awey
That may go / thurgh þe golet / soft and sote
Of spicerie / of leef / of bark / and rote
Shall ben his sauce / ymaked by delite
To maken hem yitte / a newer appetite
But certes / he þat haunteth soch delices
Is dede / while þat he lyueth in tho vices
A lecherous thyng is wyn / and drunkennes
Is full of stryvyng / and of wrecchednes
O drunk man / disfigured is thy face
Soure is thy breth / foule art þu to enbrace
And þurgh þy drunken nose / semeth þy soun
As þough þu seidest ay Sampsoun Sampsoun
And yitte god wote / Sampsou / drank neuer no wyn
Þu fallest / as it were / a stikked swyn
Thy tung is lost / and all þyn honest cure
For drunkenesse / is vꝰerray sepulture
Of mannes witt / and his discrecou
In whom þat drynk hath dominacou
He can no counseill kepe / it is no drede
Now kepe you / from þe white / and from the rede
And namely from þe white wyn / of lepe
That is to sell / in Fisshstrete / or in chepe
This wyn of Spayn crepeth subtelly
In other wynes / growyng fast by
Of which there riseth / soch fumositee
That whan a man hath drunk / draughtes . iij .
And weneth þat he be / at home in Chepe
He is in Spayn / right at the toun of lepe
Nat atte Rochell / ne at Burdeux toun
And þan woll he sey / Sampsou Sampsoun
But herkeneth ordyngs / I you pray
That all þe souꝰerayn actes / dare I say
Of victories / in the old testament
Thurgh verray god / þat is omnipotent
Were don in abstinence / and in prayer
Loketh the bible / and there ye mow it lere
Loke Attilla / the grete Conquerour
Died in his slepe / wtith shame and dishonorur
Bledyng ay at his nose / in dronkennesse
A Capitayn / shold lyve in sobernesse
And ouer all this / aviseth you right wele
What was cōmmaunded / vn to lamwele
Nat Samuell / but Lamwell sey I
Redeth the bible / and fynd it expresly
Of wyn yevyng to hem þtat han Iustice
No more of this / for it may wele suffice
And now þat I haue spoken of glotonye
Now woll I you diffenden hasardye
Hasard is verray moder of lesynges
And of deceit and cursed forswerynges
Blasphemyng of crist manslaughter / and waste also
Of catell / and of tyme / and ferthermo

I was in assye / in a grete Citee

My litle child now woll I fecche the
Whan that the greyn / is from thy tung ytake
Be nat agast / I woll the nat forsake
This holy monk this Abbot hym mene I .
His tung out caught / and toke awey þe greyn
And he yave vp the gost / full softely
And whan this Abbot / hade this wonderꝰer seyn
His salt teres / trikled doun as reyn
And gruff he fell all plat / vpon þe ground
And still he lay / as he hade leyn ybound .
The Couent eke / lay vp on tha pament /
Wepyng and herien cristes moderꝰer dere
And after that they rise / and forth ben went /
And toke awey / this martirꝰer / from his bere
And in a toumbe / of marbell stones clere
Enclosen they / this litle body swete
There he is now / god leue vs for to mete
O yong / Hugh of Lyncoln slayn also
Wtith cursed Iewes / as it is notable
For it is but a litle while a goo
Pray eke for vs / we synfull folk vnstable
That of his mꝰercy / god so mꝰerciable
On vs his grete mꝰercy / multiplie
For the reuꝰerence / of his Moderꝰer Marie / Amen . /
Hic definit fabula Priorisse /

⁊ incipit
ꝓprologus de sir Thopas ꝑper Chaucer narratꝰer
Whan seid was this myracle / euꝰery man
As sobre was / that wonder was to se
Till that our hoost / Iape to began
And than at erst / he loked vp on me /
And seid thus / what man art þu koth he
Thow lokest as þu woldest fynd an hare
For ever vp on the ground I se the stare
Approche nere / and loke vp merely
Now ware you sirs / and let þis man haue place
He in the waste / was shape as wele as .I.
This were a popet / in an arme to enbrace
For ony woman small / and feire of face
Hym semeth elvissh / by his countenaunce
For vn to no wight / doth he daliaunce
Sey þu now somwhat / sen other folk han seid .
Tell vs a tale of merth / and þat anon
Hoste koth he / ne beth nat / euyll appayed .
For other tale certes / kan I none
But of a Ryme / I lerned long agone
Ye / that is gode koth he / now shull we here
Som deyntous thyng / me thynketh / be his chere
Hic definit ꝓprologus de Chaucers
⁊ incipit fabula sua de sirꝰer Thopas
Listeneth lordynges / in gode intent /
And I woll tell verament
Of merth and of solace
All of a kyng was / faire and gent
In bataill / and in turnement
His name was Sir Thopace
Yborn he was / in ferꝰer cuntre
In Flaunders / all by yond þe se
At Poperyng in the place
His fader was / a man full fre
And lord he was / of þat cuntre
As it / was goddes grace
Sirꝰer Thopas wax / a doughti swayn
White was his face / as payndemayn
His lippes rede as nose
His rode is like / Scarlet in greyn
And I you tell / in gode serteyn
He hade a semely nose
His here his berd was like saffrou
That to his girdle / raught adoun
His shone of Cordwane
Of brugges were his hosen broun
His robe was of Syklatoun
That cost many a Iane
He coude hunt at wild dere
And ride an haukyng by Ryvere
Wtith grey goshauke / on honde
There to he was / a grete Archere
Of wrastlyng / was þerꝰer noon his pere
There ony Ram shold stonde
Full many a maide bright in bourꝰer
They mourne / for his ꝑperamourꝰer
Whan hem were bet / to slepe
But he was chaste / and no lecchourꝰer
And swete as is / þe bramble flourꝰer
That bereth the rede hepe
And so it fell / vp on a day
Forsoth as I you tell may
Sir Thopas wold out ride
He worthed on his stede gray
And in his honde / a launce gay
A long swerd by his side
He prikketh thurgh a faire forest /
There in is many / a wild beest /
Ye both Buk and hare
And as he priketh North and Est /
I tell you / hym hade all mest /
Betid a sory care
There spryngen herbes / grete and smale
The licorice / and the Cetuale
And many a clove gillofre
And Nutmuge / to put in ale
Whetherꝰer it / be moist or stale
Or for to leye in Coffre
The briddes song / it is no nay
The sꝑperhauke / and the popingay
That Ioye / it was to here
The thurstell Cok / made eke hir lay
The wode dove / vp on a spray
She song full loude and clere
Sir Thopas fell / in love longyng
All whan he herd þe thrustell syng
And priked as he were wode
His faire stede / in his prikyng
So swatte / that men myght hym wryng
His sides were all blode
Sir Thopas / eke so wery was
For prikkyng / on the soft gras
So fiers was his corage
That doun he leid hym in þtat place
To make his stede som solace
And yave hym gode forage
O seint Marie / benedicitee
What eyleth / þis love at me
To bynd me so sore
Me dremed all / this nyght ꝑperdee
An elf quene / shall my leman be
And slepe vnderꝰer my gore
An elf quene / woll I loue I wis
For in this werld no wōmman is
Worthy to be my make /
In toun
All otherꝰer wommen / I forsake
And to an elf quene / I me take
By dale and eke by doun
In to his sadle / he clom anone
And prikketh ouꝰere stile / and stone
An elf quene for to espye
Till he so long / hath rid and gone
That he fond in a priue wone
The contree of fairie /
so wield
For in that cuntre / was there none
That to hym durst / ride or gone
Neitherꝰer wyf ne child
Till that there cam / a grete geaunt
His name was sirꝰer Olyfaunt /
A ꝑperlious man of dede
He seid child by Termagaunt
But yf þu pryk out / of my haunt
Anone I sle þy stede
wtith mace
Here is the quene of Faireyie
Wtith harp and pype / and Symphonye
Dwellyng in this place
The child seid as mot I the
To morn woll I mete the
Whan I haue myn Armour
And yitte I hope / ꝑper ma fay
Þat þu shalt / wtith þis launce gay
Abye it full soure /
þy Mawe
I shall perce yf I may
Or it be fully pryme of day
For here þu shalt be slawe
Sirꝰer Thopas drow abak full fast
This geaunt / at hym stones cast /
Out of a fell staff slyng
But faire escaped child Thopace
And all it was þurgh goddes grace
And thurgh his fairꝰer beryng
Yitte listeneth lordes to my tale
Meryer þan / the Nyghtyngale
I woll you rowne /
How sirꝰer Thopas / wtith sides smale
Prikyng ouꝰere hill and dale
Is com ayein to towne
His mery men cōmmaunded he
To make hym both game and gle
For nedes most he fight /
Wtith a geaunt / wtith hedes thre
For ꝑperamourꝰer / and iolitee
Of one þat shone full bright /
Do com he seid my mynstrales
And gestours / for to tell tales
Anon / in myn Armyng
Of Romaynes / þat ben riales
Of Popes / and of Cardinales
And eke of loue longyng
They fette hīn first / swete wyn
And mede eke / in a maselyn
And riall spicerye
Of gyngebrede / þtat was full fyn
And licorys and eke comyn
Wtith sugre / that is trie
He did next / his white lere
A cloth of laike / fyn and clere
A breche and eke a shert /
And next his shert / an Aketou
And ouerꝰer that / an habergeoun
For persyng of his hert
And ouerꝰer that / a fyn hauberk /
Was all ywrought of Iewes werk /
Full strong it was of plate
And over that his cote Armourꝰer
As white / as is a lilly flourꝰer
In which he woll debate /
His sheld was all of gold so rede
And there in was / a bores hede
A Charbocle by his side
And there he swore / on ale and brede
How þat þe Geaunt / shold be dede /
Betyde what betide
His Iambyus / were of quyrluby
His swerd shethe / of Ivory
Helme of latou bright /
His sadell was of Rowell bone
His bridle / as þe son shone
Or as the Mone light /
His spere was of fyn Cipres
That bedeth werre / and no þing pees
The hede full sharp yground .
His stede was all Apple gray
It goth an aumble in þe way
Full softly and round /
in londe
Lo lordes myn / here is a fitte
Yf ye woll ony / more of itte
To tell it I woll fonde
Now holdeth yourꝰer mouth ꝑper chitee /
Both knyght / and lady free
Anone I woll you tell /
Men speken / of Romaunces of pris
Of horn child / and of Ipotys
Of Bevys / and Sirꝰer Guy
Of Sirꝰer libeous / and pleyndamours
But Sirꝰer Thopas / he bereth the flour
Of Riall Chiualrye
His gode stede / all he bistrode
And forth vp on / his wey he rode
As spark out of the bronde
Vp on his creste / he bare a Tourꝰer
And there in he stykked a lilly flourꝰer
God sheld his coors from shonde
And for he was a knyght auntrous
He nold slepe in noon hous
But lye in his hode
His bright helme / and his wongerꝰer
And by hym batteth his destrere
Of herbes fyn and gode
Hym self drank water of þe well
As did þe knyght Sirꝰer ꝐPercyuell
So worthy vnder wede /
till on a day
No more of this / for goddes dignytee
Koth ourꝰer hoste / for þu makest me
So wery of þe verray leudenes
That also wisly / god my soule blesse
Myn eres aken / of thy dasfy speche
Now soch a ryme / þe devyll I beteche
This may wele / Ryme dogrell koth he
Why so koth I wolt þu let me /
More of my tale / than another man
Sen that it is þe best ryme I can
By god koth he / for pleinly at a worde
Thy drasty rymyng / is nat worth a torde
Thow dost not elles / but spendest tyme
Sirꝰer at a worde / þu shalt no lenger ryme
Let se / where þu canst tell ought in geest /
Or tell in prose / som what / at the leest /
In which there be som merth / or som doctryne
Gladly koth I / by goddes swete pyne
I woll you tell / a litle thyng in prose
That ought to like you / as I suppose
Orels certes ye be / to Daungerous
It is a morall tale / vꝰertuous
All be it told som tyme / in sondry wise
Of sondry folk / as I shall you devise
As thus / ye wote / that euꝰery Euangelist
That telleth vs þe peyn of Ihu Crist
Ne seith nat all thyng / as his felawe doth
But natheles / his sentence / is all soth /
And all accorden / as in herꝰer sentence
All be there / in herꝰer tellyng / difference
For som of hem sey more / and som sey lesse
Whan they his pitous passiou expresse
I mene of Marke Mathewe / luke and Iohn
But doutles her sentence is all one
Therfore lordyngs / I you beseche
Yf you thynk / I varie / as in my speche
As thus though þat I tell somwhat more
Of ꝓproverbes / þan ye haue herd byfore
Compꝰerhended in this litle tretice here
To enforce wtith theffect / of my matere
And though I nat þe same wordes sey
As ye han herd / yitte to you all I prey
Blameth me nought / for as in my sentence
Shull ye nougher fynd difference
From þe sentence / of þis tretee light /
After the which / þis mery tale I wright /
And therfore herkeneth what þat I shall sey
And let me tell / all my tale I prey
Hic definit fabula de Sir Thopas

div.ab: Incipit fabula de Melibeus

A yong man called Melibeus / myghty and riche / bygate vp on his wyf / þat
called was Prudence / A doughterꝰer / which that called was Sophie /

vp on
a day byfell that he for his disport / is went in to the feldes / hym to pleye /

his wyf and eke his doughterꝰer / hath he laft / wtithin his hous // Of which þe dores / weren
fast yshette /

thre of his old foes / han it espied / and setten ladders / to þe walles of
his hous / and by wyndowes ben entred /

and beten his wyf and wounded his doughtꝰer /
wtith . v . mortall woundes / in . v . places sondrye

this is to seyn / in herꝰer fete / in her hondes /
in her Eres / in hir nose / and in hir mouth / and leften hir for dede / and wenten awey /

Whan Melibeus retorurned was in to his hous / and sawe all this myschief / he like
a mad man / rendyng his clothes / gan to wepe and crie /

Prudence his wyf / as ferforth
as she durst / besought hym / of his wepyng for to stynt /

but nought for thie / He
gan to crie / and wepe / everꝰer lenger the more /

This noble wyf Prudence / remembred
hir / vp on the sentence / of Ovide / in his boke / that cleped is / the remedie of love
Where as he seith /

he is a fole / that destourbeth the moder to wepe / in the deth
of hir child / till she haue wept hirꝰer fill / as for a certein tyme

and þan shall
man do his diligence / wtith amyable wordes / hirꝰer to recomforte / and praye hir of hirꝰer
Wepyng / for to stynt /

For which resou / this noble wyf Prudence / suffred hir hous-
bond / for to wepe and crie / as for a certein space /

And whan she sawe hirꝰer tyme
she seid to hym / in this wise / Allas my lord koth she / why make ye yourꝰer self
for to be like a fole /

for forsoth / it apꝑperteneth nat / to a wise man / to make soch a
sorow /
your doughter wtith þe grace of god / shall warissh and escape /

and all
were it so / þat she right now were dede / ye ne ought nat / as for hirꝰer deth / your
self to destroie /

Senec seith / the wise man / shall nat take / to grete discomforte /
for the deth of his children /

but certes / he shold suffre it in pacience / as wele as he
abideth the deth / of his owen ꝓpropre ꝑpersone /

This Melibeus answerd anon / and seid
what man koth he / shold of his wepyng stynt / that hath so grete a cause / for to
wepe /
Ihu Crist our lord hym self / wept / for the deth / of Lazarus / his frende ~

Prudence answerd / certes wele I wote / attempre wepyng is no thyng defended
to hym that sorowfull is / amonges folk in sorow / but it is rather graunted hym
to wepe /

The Apostell Poule / vn to the Romayns writeth / Man shall reioyce
wtith hem that maken Ioye / and wepen wtith soch folk as wepen /

But though attempre
wepyng be graunted ; outrageous wepyng is diffended /

Mesure of wepyng
shold be considered / after the lore / that techeth vs Senec /

Whan þat thy frende
is dede koth he / let nat thyn yien to moist ben of teres / ne to moch drie / all -
though the teres com to thyn yien / let hem nat fall

And whan þu hast forgone
thy frende / do diligence / to gete ayein anotherꝰer frend / And this is more wisdom
þan for to wepe / for thy frende / which that þu hast lorn / for there in is no bote
And therfore / yf ye gouꝰerne you / by Sapience / put awey sorow / out of your hert

Remembrꝰer yow / that Ihc Syrak seith / A man that is ioyous in hert and glad
it hym conserueth / florisshyng in his age / but sothly / Sorow in hert

sleeth /
Full many a man /

Salamou seith / that right as mothes / in the shepes flees / anoyen
to the clothes / and the smale wormes / to the tree / right so anoyeth sorow to þe hert /

Wherfore vs yght / aswele in the deth of ourꝰer children / as in the losse of ourꝰer gode
temporels / haue pacience /

Remembre you / vp on the pacient Iob / whan he hade lost
his children / and his temꝑperell substaunce / And in his body endured and resceyued
full many a grevous tribulacou / yitte seid he thus
Ourꝰer lord hath yeve / it me /

our
lord hath byraft it me / right as ourꝰer lord hath wold / right so it is done / yblessed
be the name / of ourꝰer lord

To thise forseid thynges answerd Melibeus vn to
his wyf / Prudence all thy wordes koth he ben soth / and there to ꝓprofitable / but
truely my hert is troubled wtith this sorow so greuously / that I note what to done

let call koth Prudence / thy true frendes all / and thy lynage / which that ben
wise / telleth yourꝰer caas / and herkeneth what they seye / in counseillyng and you
governe afterꝰer her sentence /

Salamou seith / werk all thyng by counseill / and
þu shalt neuꝰere repent /

Than by the counseill of his wyf / Prudence / this Melibeus
lete call a grete congregaciou of folk

as Surgeans Phisicians / old folk and yong
and som of his old enemyes / reconsiled as by herꝰer semblaunt to his love / and in
to his grace /

and there wtith all cam some of his neighbours / that dyden hym
reuꝰerence / more for drede / than for love / as it happeth oft

There cam also full
many subtell flaterers / and wise advocates lerned in the lawe /

and whan
thise folk to gederꝰer assembled weren / This Melibeus in sorowfull wise / show-
ed hem his caas /

and by the manerꝰer of his speche / It semed þat in hert he bare
a cruell Ire / redy to do vengeaunce / vp on his foes / and sodenly desired that
the Werre shold begynne /

but natheles / yitte axed he his counseill vp on
this mater /

A Surgean by licence and assent of soch as weren wise vp
roos / and to Melibeus seid as ye mow here /

Sirꝰer koth he as to vs Surgeans
apꝑperteneth / that we do to euꝰery wight / the best that we can / where as we ben
witholde / and to ourꝰer pacience / that we do no damage /

wherfore it happeth
many tyme and oft / that whan twey men han euꝰerycch wounded otherꝰer / O
Surgean heleth hem both /

Wherfore vn to ourꝰer arte it is no ꝑpertinent to norice
Werre / ne ꝑperties to supporte /

but certes as to warisshyng of yourꝰer doughter
all be it so / that she ꝑperliously be wounded / we shull do so ententyf besyness
from day to nyght / that wtith the grace of god she shall be hole and sound
as sone / as it is possible /

Almost right in the same wise / the Phisiciens
answerden / save that they seiden a fewe wordes more /

that right as
maladies ben cured / by her contraries / right so shall man warissh werre
by vengeaunce /

His Neighbours full of vengeaunce / and envye / his /
feyned frendes þat semed reconsailed / his flaters

maden semblant /
of wepyng / and empeired and agregged mochell of this mater /
in preisyng gretely Melibee / of myght / of power / of Richesse / and of /
frendes / despisyng the power of his aduꝰersaries /

and seiden vttrely
that he anone shold wreke hym / of his foes / and begyn werre /

Vp roos þan an ~
Aduocat that was wise / by leve and by counseill of otherꝰer þat weren wise / and
seid /

Lordynges / the nede / for the which / we ben assembled in this place / is full
hevy thyng / and an hye mater /

by cause of the wronge / and of þe wykkednes / þtat
hath be don / and eke by resou / of the grete damages / that in tyme cōmmyng / ben
possible to fallen for the same cause /

and eke by resou / of þe grete richesse and
powerꝰer of the ꝑperties both /

for þe which resons / It were a full grete ꝑperyll
to erren in this mater /

Wherfore Melibeus this is oure sentence / we counseill
you aboue all thyng / that right anone / þu do thy diligence / in kepyng of þy ꝓpropre
ꝑpersone in soch a wise / þat þu ne want none espye ne wacche thy body for to save

And after that / we counseill / that in thyn hous / þu sette suffisaunt garnysou
so that they mow / aswele thy body / as thyn hous defende /

But certes / for to
meve werre / ne sodenly for to do vengeaunce / we mow nat deme / in so litle
tyme that it were ꝓprofitable /

wherfore / we axen leiser and space to haue
delibacou / in this caas to deme /

For the cōmmune ꝓprouerbe seith thus / he that sone
demeth / sone shall repente /

and eke men seyn / þat thylk Iuge is wise / that
sone vnderstondeth / a mater / and Iugeth be leiser /

for all be it so / that all tary-
ing / be a noyfull / all gates it is nat to reprove in Iugement yeving / Ne in ven-
geaunce takyng / whan it is suffisant and resonable /

And þat shewed our
lord by ensaumple / For whan that the womman that was taken in Aduoutrie
was brought in his pꝰersence / to knowe what shold be don wtith hir ꝑpersone / all be
it that he wist wele hym self / what þat he wold answere / yitte ne wold he
nat answere sodenly / but he wold haue delibacou / and in the grounde he wrote
twyes /

and by thise causes / we axen delibaciou / and we shall than by the grace
of god / counseill the thyng that shall be ꝓprofitable /

Vp sterte than þe yong folk
at ones / and the most ꝑpert of that compaignye / han scorned thise old wise men
and by gonnen to make noise / and seiden / That

right so / as while that Iren
is hote / men shold smyte / right so men shold do wreken her wronges / while
that they ben fressh / and newe ; and wtith loude voys they crieden werre / werre /

vp
roos tho one / of thise old wise men / and wtith his honde made countenaunce / þat
men / shold hold hem styll / and yeve hym audience /

Lordynges koth he / þere
is full many a man / that crieth werre werre / þat woteth full litle what
werre amounteth /

Werre at his begynnyng / hath so grete an entryng / and
so large / that euꝰery wight may entre whan hym lyketh / and lightly fynd werrꝰer
But certes to what ende / that shall there of byfall / it is nat light to knowe

For sothely whan that werre is ones bygon / there is full many a child
vnborn of his moder / that shall sterue yong / by cause of that werre / or
lyue in sorow / and dye in wrecchednes /

And therfore / or that / ony werre
be bygon / men most haue counseill and grete delibaciou /

and whan this
old man wende to enforce his tale by resons / well nye all at ones bygon
They to rise / for to breken his tale / and bidden hym full ofte / his wordes for
to abregge /

for sothly / he that precheth to hem / þat listen nat to here his wordes
his sꝰermou hem anoyeth /

For Ihc Syrac seith / that musyk in wepyng / is a-
noyous thyng / this is to seye / asmoch availeth to speke byfore folk / to which
his speche anoyeth / as is to syng byfore hym that wepeth

And whan this wise
man sawe / þat hym lakked audience / all shamefast he sate hym doun ayein

For Salamou seith there as þu ne maist / haue noon audience / enforce the
nat to speke /

I se wele koth this wise man / that the cōmmune ꝓprouerbe is soth ~
that gode counseill wanteth / whan it is most nede /

Yitte had this Melibeus
in his counsaill / many folk / that priuely in his ere counceilled hym certeyn
thyng / and counceilled hym the contrarie in genꝰerall Audience /

Whan Melibeus
hade herde / that the grettest ꝑpertie of his counseill were accorded / that he
shold make werre anoon he consented to her counsaillyng / and fully affer-
med her sentence /

Than Dame Prudence whan that she sawe / how þat hir
housbond shope hym / for to wreke hym on his foos / and to begynne werre
she in full humble wise / whan she sawe hir tyme / seid hym thise wordes

My lorde koth she / I you beseche / as hertly as I dare and can / ne haste you nat
to fast / and for all gwerdons / as yeve me audience /

For Piers Alfonse
seith / who so that doth / to the / outher gode or harme / hast þe nat to quyte

What þough thyn hors / be both foule and lene
Yf he woll sꝰerue the rek nat a bene /
Loke that thyn hert be mery euꝰermoo /
Yis sir koth he / yis hoost so mot I goo /
But I be mery / I wys I woll be blamed
And right anoon his tale he hath attamed
And þus he seid vn to vs euꝰerychone
This swete preest this godely man sir Iohn
Here endeth the ꝓprologe of þe Nonnes preest
and begynneth his tale of þe Cok and þe Hen
A poure widowe / somdele stope in age /
Was whilom dwellyng in a narow cotage
Beside a grove stondyng in a dale
This widow / of which I tell you my tale
Sen thilk day þat she was last a wyf
In pacience ledde a symple lyf
For litle was hir catell / and hir rent
By housbondry / of which as god hir sent
She fonde hir self and eke doughtren two
iij large sowes hade she / and no mo /
Thre keen / and eke a Shepe that hight Mall
Full soty was hir boure / and eke hir hall
In which she ete / full many a sklendre mele
Of poynaunt sauce / knewe she neuer a dele /
No deyntee mossell / passed þurgh hir throte
Hir diette was accordyng / to hir cote
Replexiou ne made hir neuer sike
Attempre diet / was all hir phisike /
And excersice / and hertly suffisaunce /
The goute letted hir nought for to daunce
No wyn drank she / neither white ne rede /
Ne apoplexie shent nat hir hede /
Hir borde was sꝰerued most / wtith white and blak
Mylk and broun brede / in which she fonde no lak
Seynd Bacou and som tyme an eye or tweye
For she was / as it were / a maner deye
A yerd she hade / enclosed all about
Wtith stykkes / and a drie diche wtithout
In which she hade a Cok hight Chauntcleer
In all þat lond / of crowyng / nas his peer
His vois was merier / þan þe mery orgou
On masdaies / þat in chirche goon
Wele sikerer was his crowyng in his logge
Than is a clok or any Abbeyes orlogge
By nature he knewe ecch assenciou
Of the equynoxiall / in þat toun
For whan degrees .xv. were assended.
Than crue he / þat it myght nat be amended
His combe was redder / þan þe fyn corall
And bateld / as it were a Castell wall
His bill was blak and as þe geet it shone
Like asure were his legges / and his tone
His nailes whitter þan þe lilly flour
And like the burned gold was his colour
This gentill Cok hade in his gouꝰernaunce
.vij. hennes for to do all his plesaunce
Which weren his susters / and his ꝑperamorurs
And wonder like to hīn / as of colours
Of which þe fairest hewed on hir throte
Was cleped faire damysell ꝐPertelote /
He fethered hir / an hundred tyme a day
And she hym pleseth all þat euer she may
Curteys she was / discrete and debonair
And compynable / and bare hir self so fair
Sen thilk day / þat she was .vij. nyght old
That truely / she hath / þe hert in hoold
Of Chauntecleer loken in euꝰery lyth
He loued hir so / þat wele was hym þere wtith /
Bot soch a Ioye was it / to here hem syng
Whan þat þe bright son / gan to spryng
In swete accorde / my lief is fair in lond.
For thilk tyme / as I have vnderstond.
Bestes and birdes / kouden speke and syng
And so byfell that in a dawenyng
As Chauntcleer / amonges his wyfes all
Sat on his perche / þat was in þe hall
And next hym sate / þis feir ꝑpertelote
This Chauntcleer gan grone in his throte /
As man þat is in dreme / drecched sore
And whan þat ꝐPertelote / þus herd hym rore /
She was a gaast and seid hert dere
What ayleth you / to grone in this manere /
Ye ben a verre sleper / fye for shame
And he answerd and seid thus / madame
I pray you / þat ye take it nat a greef /
By god / me mette I was in soch a myschief
Right now / that yitte myn hert is sore afright
Now god koth he / my sweven recche aright
And kepe my body / out of foule prisou
Me mette / how þat I romed vp and doun
Wtithin our yerd / where as I sawe a beest
Was like an hound / and wold haue made areest
Vpon my body / and haue hade me dede
His colour was bitwene yelow and rede
And tipped was his taill and both his eres
Wtith blak vnlike þe remaunt of his heres
His snowte was small / wtith glowyng yien tweye
Yitte for his loke / for fere / all most I deye
This caused me / my gronyng doutlees
A voye koth she / fye on you hertlees /
Allas koth she / for by that god above
Now han ye lost myn hert and all my love
I can nat love a coward / by my feith
For certes / what so ony womman seith
We all desiren / yf it myght be
To haue an housbond / hardy wise and fre
And secree / and no nygard ne no fole
Ne hym þat is agast of euꝰery tole
Ne noon auentorur / by þat god above
How durst ye for shame / seye to your love
That ony thyng myght make you aferde
Have ye no mannes hert and have a berde
Allas kon ye be agast / of swevenys
No thing god wote / but vanitee / in sweven is
Swevens ben engendred of replexions
And oft of fume / and of complexions
Whan humorurs ben to habundant in a wight
Certes this dreme / which ye han mette to nyght
Commeth of þe grete suꝑperfluytee
Of your rede Colera pardee
Which causeth folk to dreden in her dremes
Of arowes and of fire / wtith rede lemes /
Of rede bestes / þtat þey woll hem byte
Of Contekke / and of waspes / grete and lite
Right as the humorur / of Malyncolie
Causeth many a man / in slepe to krie
For fere of blak beres / or boles blake
Or els blak devels / þat woll hem take /
Of other humours / coude I tell also
That werken a man in slepe / moch wo
But I woll passe / as lightly / as I can
Lo Catou / which þat was / so wise a man
Seid he nat thus / ne do no force of dremes
Now sir koth she / whan we flee from þise bemes
For goddes love / as take som laxatyf
Vp ꝑperell of my soule / and of my lyf
I counceill you þe best / I woll nat lye
That both of colour / and of malyncolye
Ye purge you / and for ye shull nat tarie
Though in this toun is noon apoticarie
I shall my self / to herbes teche you
That shall be / for your ease / and for yorur prow
And in our yerd the herbes shall I fynd
The which han of her ꝓproprete by kynd .
To purge you byneth and eke aboue
Sir foryete nat this / for goddes love /
Ye ben full Collerik of complexiou
Ware that the son / in his assensiou
Ne fynd you nat reple of humours hote /
And yf it do / I dare wele leye a grote
That ye shull haue / a fever tercian
Or an ague / which þat may be your bane
A day or two / ye shull haue / deiestyfnesse
Of wormes / or ye take your laxatyfnesse
Of laurioll / centaure / or fumeter
Or elles of Elebor / þat groweth there
Of Catapuce / or of gait Rys beries
Of herbe yve growyng in our yerd þere mery is
Pyk hem right as þey owe / and ete hem in
Beth mery housbond for yorur fader and kine
Dredeth no dreme / I can sey you no more
Madame koth he / graunt mꝰercy of yorur lore
But natheles as touching Daun Catou
That hath of wisdom / soch a grete renoun
Though þat he badde / no dremes for to drede
By god men mowen in old bokes rede
Of many a man / more of auctoritee
Than euer Catou was / so mot I the
That all the reuers seyen of his sentence
And han wele founden by exꝑperience
That dremes ben significacions
As wele of ioye as tribulacions
That folk enduren / in þis lyf pꝰersent
There nedeth of þis / make no argument
The verrey proof sheweth it in dede
One of þe grettest auctor / þat men rede
Seith thus þat whilom ij felawes went
On pilgrymage / in full gode intent
And happed so þat þey cam in a toun
Where þere was soch a congregaciou
Of peple / and eke so streite of herbergage
That þey ne found / as moch as a cotage
In which they myght / ylogged be
Wherfore þey must of necessitee
As for þat nyght / deꝑperten companye
And ecch of hem goth / to his hostelrye
And toke his loggyng as it wold fall /
That one of hem / was logged in a stall
Fer in a yerd / wtith oxen of þe plow
That other man / was logged wele ynow
As was his auenture / or his fortune
That vs gouꝰerneth as in commune
And so befell / þat long or it was daye
This man mette in his bed / þere as he lay
How þat his felowe gan vpon hīn call
And seid allas / for in an Oxes stall /
This nyght / I shall be murdred þere I lye
Now help me dere brother or I dye
In all haast com to me he seyde / .
This man out of his slepe / for fere he breid .
But whan þat he was wakned of his slepe
He turned hīn / and toke of þis no kepe
Hym thought his dreme / nat but a vanytee
Thus twyes in his slepe dremed he
And at þe iij . de tyme / yitte his felawe
Cam as hīn þought and seid I am now slawe
Behold my body / woundes depe and wide
Arise vp erely / in þe morn tide
And at þe west gate of þe toun koth he
A Cart full of dung þere shalt þu see
In which my body is hid full priuelee
Do thilk Cart areste boldelye
My gold caused my mordre soth to seyn
And told hīn euꝰery poynt how he was sleyn
Wtith a full pitous face / pale of hewe
And trusteth wele / þis dreme he fonde full true
For on þe morow as sone as it was daye
To his felaws Inne / he toke the waye
And whan he cam to þis Oxes stall
After his felawe / he bigan to call
The hostiller answerd hym anoon
And seid sir / your felawe is agoon
As sone as day / he went out of þe toun
This man gan fallen / in suspeciou
Remembryng on his dremes / þat he mette
And forth he goth no lenger wold he lette
Vn to þe west gate / of þe toun and fonde
A dung cart / for to dung londe
That was arraied in the same wise
As ye han herde þe dede man devise
And wtith an hardy hert he gan to crie
Vengeaunce and Iustice / of þis felonye /
My felawe murthred is / þis same nyght /
And in this cart he lieth / gapyng vp right
I crie out on the mynystres koth he /
That shold kepe and reule þis Citee /
Harrow allas / here lieth my felawe slayn
What shold I more / vn to þis tale sayn
The peple vp stert / and cast þe cart to ground
And in the mydle / of þe dung þey found
The dede man / þat mordred was all newe
O blisfull god / þat art so iust and trewe
Lo how þu / bywreiest mordre all weye
Mordre woll out þat se we / day by day
Mordre is so lothsom / and so abhominable
To god þat is so iust / and resonable
That he ne woll nat suffre it heled be
Though it abide a yere / or . ij . or . iij .
Mordre woll out þis is my conclusiou
And right anone / mynystres of the toun
Han hent þe Carter / and so sore hīn pyned
And eke þe hostiller / so sore engyned
That þey beknewe her wikkednesse anoon
And were an hanged / by þe nek boon
Here mow men se / þat dremes be to drede
And certes in þe same boke / I rede
Right in the next Chapitre after this
I gab nat so have I ioye / or blys /
ij men þat wold han passed ouꝰer þe see
For certein cause / in to fer cuntree
Yf þat the wynd / ne hade ben contrarie
That made hem in a Citee / for to tarie
That stode full mery vp on an hauon side
But on a day / ayeinst the eve tide
The wynd gan chaunge / and blewe right as hem list /
Iolyf and glade / they went vn to her rest
And casten hem full erely for to saile
But to þat o man / fill a grete mꝰeruaile
That one of hem / in slepyng as he laie
Hym mette a wonder dreme ayeinst þe daye
Hym þought / a man stode by his beddes side
And hym commaunded þat he shold abide
And seid hym thus / yf þu to morow wende
Thow shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He woke and toold his felawe / what he mette
As for that tyme / he praied hīn to abide
His felawe þat laye / by his bed side
Gan for to laugh and skorne hīn full fast
No dreme koth he / may so myn hert agast
That I woll let / for to do my thynges /
I set nat a strawe / by my dremynges
For swevenes ben but vanytees and Iapes
Men dreme all daie / of oules and of apes
And eke of many a mase there wtithall
Men dreme of thyng þat neuer was ne shall
But seth I se / þat þu wolt here abide
And þus forsleuth wilfully / þy tide
God wote it reweth me / and haue gode day
And þus he toke his leve / and went his way
But or þat he / hade half his cours ysailed
Not I nat why / ne what myschaunce it eiled
But casuelly / þe shippes botom rent
And ship and man / vnder þe water went
In sight of other shippes / it beside
That wtith hem seiled / at the same tide
And therfore faire ꝐPertelot so dere
By soch ensaumples old / maist þu lere
That no man shold be to reccheles
Of dremes / for I sey þe doutles /
And praid hym his viage / for to lette
That many a dreme / full sore is for to drede
Lo in the lyf / of seint kenhelme I rede
That was kenulphus son / þe noble kyng
Of mertnrike / how kenelme / met a thyng
A litle or he was murdred / on the day
His mordre / in his avisiou he say
His norice hym expounded euꝰerydele
His sweven / and bade hīn kepe hīn wele
From tresou / but he nas but . vij . yere old
And therfore litle tale / hath he told .
Of ony dreme / so holy was his hert /
By god I hade leuer / þan my shert /
That ye hade red his legend / as have I
Dame ꝑpertelote / I sey you truely
Macrobeus / þat writeth þe avisiou
In Affrike / of þe worthy Cypiou
Affermeth dremes / and seith þat þey ben
Warnyng of thynges / þat men after seen
And ferthermore / I pray you loketh wele /
In the old testament / of Danyele
Yf he held dremes / ony vanytee
Rede eke of Ioseph / and þere shull ye see
Where dremes ben somtyme / I sey nat all
Warnyng of thynges þat shull after fall
Loke of Egipte þe kyng Daun Pharao
His baker and his boteller also
Where þey felt none effect in dremes
Who so woll seke actes / of sondrie remes
May rede of dremes / many a wonder thyng
Lo Cresus / which þat was / of lyde þe kyng
Mette he nat that he satte vp on a tree
Which signyfied he shold an hanged be /
Lo here Andremacha / Ectores wyf
That day þat Ector / shold lese his lyf
She dremed on the same nyght byforn
How þat þe lyf / of Ector / shold be lorn
Yf that daye / he went in to bataile
She warned hym / but it myght nat availl
He went for to fight / natheles
But he was slayn anone / of Achilles /
But that tale / is all to long to tell
And eke it is nye day / I may nat dwell
Shortly I sey / as for conclusiou
That I shall have / of þis avisiou
Aduersitee / and I sey ferthermore /
That I ne tell of laxatyues no store
For þey ben venemous / I wote it wele
I hem diffye / I loue hem neuer a dele
Now let vs speke of merth and stynt all this
Madame ꝐPertelote / so haue I ioye or blys
Of o thyng god hath sent me large grace
For whan I see þe beautee / of your face
Ye ben so scarlet rede about your yien
It maketh all my drede for to dyen
For as siker / as Inprincipio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Womman is all my Ioye and blis
And whan I fele a nyght yorur soft side
All be it þat I may nat on you ride
For þat our Perche / is made so narow allas
I am so full of Ioye / and of solas /
That I diffye / both sweven and dreme
And wtith þat worde / he flue doun from þe beme
For it was daye / and eke his hennes all
And wtith a Chuk he gan hem for to call
For he hade found a corne / laye in þe yerd .
Riall he was / he nas no more aferd
He fethered ꝐPertlote / mo þan . xx . tyme
And tradde hir eke as oft or it was pryme /
He loketh / as it were / a grym leoun
And on his toes / he rometh vp and doun
Hym deyned nat to sette / his fete to þe ground
And chukketh / whan he hath a corn yfound .
And to hym rennen þan / his wyfes all
Thus riall / as a prince is / in his hall
Leue I this Chauntcler in his pasture
And after woll I tell his auenture
Whan þat þe moneth in which þe world began
That hight Marche / whan god first maked man
Was complete / and ypassed were also
Seth march began . xxx . tiri dayes and two
Be fell þat Chaunteclere / in all his pride
His wyfes . vij . walkyng hym beside /
Cast vp his yien / to the bright sunne
That in the signe of Taurus hade ron
xx . tiri degrees and one / and somwhat more
He knewe by kynde / and noon oþꝰer lore /
That it was pryme / and krew wtith blisfull steven
The son he seid is clombe vp on heven
Xl . degrees / and one / and more I wys /
Madame ꝑpertelote / my worldes blys
Herkeneth / how thise blisfull birdes syng
And se þe fressh floures / how þey spryng
Full is myn hert / of revell and solace
But sodenly hym fell / a sorowfull caas
For ever þe latter ende of Ioye is woo
God wote / þat worldly Ioye is sone agoo
And yf a Rethor / coude fair endite
He in a Cronycle / saafly / myght it write
As for a souꝰerayn notabilitee
Now euꝰery wise man / let hīn herk me
This storie is all so true / I vndertake
As is the boke / of Launcelot de lake
That wommen hold / in full grete reuꝰerence
Now woll I turne ayein to my sentence
A Colfox / full of slie iniquytee
That in þe grove / hade woned yeres . iij .
By hie ymaginaciou / byfore cast
The same nyght þurghout þe hegge brast
In to þe yerd / þere Chauntecleer þe faire
Was wont and eke his wifes to repaire
And in a bed of wortes still he lay
Till it was passed vndern of þe day
Waityng his tyme / on Chauntecler to fall
As gladly don thise homesides all
That in a waite liggen / to mordre men
O fals murderour / liggyng in þy den
O newe Scariot / newe Gaenylou
Fals dissimilour / O gree Synou
That broughtest Troye / all vtterly to sorow /
O Chauntcleer accursed / by þe morow
That þu in to þe yerde / flaugh from þe bemes
Thow were full wele ywarned by þy dremes
That ylk day / was ꝑperlious / to the
But what that god forwote / mot nedes be /
After thoppynyou / of certein clerkes /
Wtithnes on hym / þat ony ꝑperfite clerk is
That in scole / is grete altercacou
In this mater / and grete disputacou
And hath ben of an . C . Ml men
But I ne can nat / bult it to the bren
As can the holy Doctour Augustyn
Or Boice or the bisshop Bradwardyn
Whether þat goddes worthy forwetyng
Streyneth me nedely / for to do a thyng
Nedely clepe I / symple necessitee /
Or elles yf free choise / be graunted me
To do þat same thyng or do it nought
Though god for wote it or þat it was wrought
Or yf his wetyng / streyneth neuer a dele
But by necessitee / condicionele /
I woll nat have to don of soch matere
My tale is of þe Cok as ye may here
That toke his counceill of his wyf wtith sorow
To walk in the yerd / vp on þat morow
That he hade mette / that dreme / þat I you told .
Wōmmens counceill ben full often cold
Wommans counceill brought vs first to wo
And made Adam / from ꝐPeradys to go
There as he was full mery / and wele at ese
But for I note to whom / it myght displese
Yf I counceill of wommen / wold blame
Passe ouer / for I seid it in my game
Rede Auctours / there þey trete / of soch matere
And what þey seyn of wōmmen / ye may here
Thise ben the Cokkes wordes / and nat myn
I can nat harme / on no womman devyn
Faire in the sonde / to bathe merelye
Lyeth ꝐPertelote / and her susters hir bye
Ayeinst the son / and Chauntecler so fre
Sang merier / þan þe mermaid in the see
For Phisiologus / seith sekerly
How þat þey syng wele and merely
And so byfell / as þat he cast his yie
Among þe wortes / on a boterflie
He was ware of this foxe / þat lay full lowe
No thyng ne list hym þan for to krowe
But cried anone / kok kok / and vp he styrt
As man þat was affraied in his hert
For naturelly / a beest desireth to fle
From his contrarie / yf þat he may it see
Though he neuer erst / hade seen it wtith his yie
This Chauntcler / whan he gan hym espie
He wold have fledde but þtat / þe Fox anoon
Seid / gentill sir allas / whider woll ye goon
Be ye affraied of me / þat am your frend
Now certes / I were wers / than a feend
Yf I to you wold harme do / or velanye
I am nat com yorur counceill to espie
But truely / the cause / of my cōmmyng
Was onely to herk how ye syng
For truely / ye han as mery steven
As ony aungell hath þat is in heven
There wtith ye han / in musik more felyng
Than hade Boice / or ony þat can syng
My lord your fader / god his soule blysse
And eke your moder / of hir gentillesse
Han in myn hous yben / to me grete ease
And certes sir full fayn / wold I you please
But for men speke of syngyng I woll sey
So mot I brouke wele / myn yien twey
Save ye / I herd neuer man so syng
As did your fader / in þe mornyng
Certes it was of hert all þat he song
And for to make his voice þe more strong
He wold so peyne hym þat wtith both his yien
He most wynk so loude he wold crien
And stonde on his typtoon þere wtithall
And strecch forth his nek long and small
And eke he was of soch discresciou
That there nas no man in no regiou
That hym in song / or wisdam myght passe
I have wele redde in daun Burnell þe asse
Among his vers / how þat þere was a Cok
That for a prestes son / yave hym a knok
Vp on his leg / while he was yong and nyce
He made hym for to lese / his benefice
But certes / þere is no comꝑperisou
Bytwene þe wisdom / and discreciou
Of your fader / and of his subteltee
Now syngeth sir / for seint charitee
Let se kon ye / your fader countrefete
This Chauntecler / his wynges gan to bete
As man that coude / his treson nat espie
So was he rauysshed wtith his flaterie
¶Allas ye lordes / many a fals flaterour
Is in your Court and many a losengeour
That plesen you wele more / by my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse vn to you seith
Redeth eccliast of Flaterye
Beth ware ye lordes / of her trecherie
This Chauntcleer stode hie vp on his toos
Strecchyng his /nek and his yien cloos
And gan to crowe loude / for the nones
And Daun Russell þe Fox / styrt vp at ones
And by þe Gargate / hent Chauntclere
And vn to þe wode / on his bak hym bere
For yitte ne was þere no man / þat hīn sewed
O destenye / that may nat ben eschewed
Allas þat Chauntecleer / flee from þe bemes
Allas his wyf / ne rought nat of dremes
And on fridaye / fell all þys meschaunce
O venus þat art goddesse of plesaunce
Sen that thy sꝰeruant was þis Chauntecler
And in thy sꝰeruice / did all his power
More for delite / þan þe world to multeplie
Why woldest þu suffre hi on þy daye to dye
O Gaufreed dere maister souꝰerayne
That whan þy Worthy kyng Richard was slayn
Wtith shote compleyndest his deth so sore
Why ne hade I now / þy science and thy lore
The friday for to chide / as deden ye
For on a fridaye / sothly slayn was he
Than wold I shewe you / how I coude pleyne
For Chauntcleres drede / and for his peyne
Certes soch crie ne lamentaciou
Was neuer of ladies made / whan Ilyou
Was won and Pirrus / wtith his straite swerd .
Whan he hade hent / kyng Pryamus by þe berd .
And slayn hym as seith vs Eneides
As maden all þe hennes in þe clees
Whan þey hade seen of chauntclere þe sight
But souꝰeraynly / Dame ꝐPertelot shright
Full louder þan did / hasdrubales wyf /
Whan þat hir housbond / hade lost his lyf
And þat þe Rōmmaynes / hade brent cartage
She was so full of turment / and of rage
That wilfully in to þe fire she stert
And brent hir self wtith a stedfast hert
O wofull hennes / right so criden ye
As whan þat Nero brent the Citee
Of Rome criden senatours wyfes
For þat her housbondes losten her lyfes
Wtithouten gilt this Nero / hath hem slayn
Now woll I turne vn to my tale agayn
This sely widow / and eke her doughtren two
Herden þise hennes crie / and maken woo
Ant out at þe dores stirt þey anoon
And sawe þe Fox / toward þe grove goon
And bare vp on his bak þe Cok awey
And criden out harrow / and welawey
Ha ha þe fox / and after hīn þey ran
And eke wtith staues many another man
Ran Coll our dog / and Talbot and Gerlond
And malkyn / wtith a distaf / in hir hond
Ran Cow and Calf / and eke þe verray hogges
So ferde þe berkyng of the Dogges /
And shoutyng of þe men / and wommen eke
They Ron so / hem thought her hertes breke
They yelleden / as fendes don / in hell
The dokes kriden / as men wold hem quell
The gees for fere flowen / ouer the trees
Out of the hyve / cam þe swarme of bees /
So hidous was the noise / A benedicitee
Certes he Iak strawe / wtith his meynee
Ne maden neuer shoutes / half so shill
Whan that they wolden / ony flemmyng kyll
As thylk day was made / vp on the fox
Of bras / they broughten bemes and of box
Of horne of bone / in which þey blewe and pouped
And there wtith all they shrikeden / and þey houped
It semed / as that heven shold fall
Now gode men I pray you herkeneth all
Lo how Fortune / turneth sodenly
The hope / and pride eke / of her enemy
¶ This kok that lay / vp on the foxes bak.
In all his drede / vnto the fox he spak
And seid sir / and I were as ye
Yitte wold I seye / as god help me
Turneth ayein / ye proude cherles all
A verray pestilence / vp on yow fall
Now I am com / vn to þe wodes side
Maugre your hede / þe cok shall here abide
I woll hym ete in feith / and þat anoon
The Fox answerd in feyth it shall be doon
And as he spake that worde all sodenly
The Cok brake from his mouth deliuerly
And hie vp on a tre / he flewe anoon
And whan the Fox sawe þat þe Cok was gone
Allas koth he / O Chauntcleer allas
I haue to you koth he ydon trespas
In asmoch as I maked you afferd .
Whan I you hent and brought in to this yerd .
But seth I dyd it / in no wyk intent
Com doun and I shall tell you what I ment
I shall sey soth to you / god help me so
Nay than koth he / I shrewe vs both two
And fyrst I shrewe my self both blode and bones
Yf þu begyle me / ofter tyme than ones ~
Thow shalt no more þurgh þy flaterie
Do me to syng and wynk wtith myn yie
For he þat wynketh / whan he shold se
All wilfully / god let hym neuer the
Nay koth þe Fox / but god yeve hym myschaunce
That so vndescrete is of gouꝰernaunce
That Iangleth whan / he shold hold his pees
Lo what it is / for to be reccheles
And necligent / and trust on flaterie
But ye þat hold this tale of folye
As of a Fox / or of a Cok or hen
Taketh þe moralitee gode men
For seint Poule seith / that all þat writen is
To our doctryne / it is writen ywis /
Taketh þe fruyt / and let þe Chaff bestill
Now gode god / yf þat it be thy will
As seith my lord / so make vs all gode men
And bryng vs / vn to his blisse amen /
Sire Nonnes Preest our hoost seid anoon
Yblessed be thy breche / and euꝰery stoon
This was a mery tale / of Chauntecler
But by my trouth yf þu were seculere
Thow woldest be / a tredefull aright
For yf þu have corage / as þu hast myght
The were nede of hennes / as I wene
Ye mo / than . vij . tymes seventene
Se which brawnes / hath þis gentle preest
So grete a nek / and soch a large breest
He loketh as a Sꝑperhauke / wtith his yien
Hym nedeth nat / his colorur for to dyen
Wtith brasill / ne wtith greyne of portyngale
Now sir faire fall you for your tale
And after þat he / wtith full mery chere
Seid vn to another / as ye shull here
Hic fabula Monialis pꝰersbitꝰeri desunt /

(base) The Ministre and the norice vnto vices
(base) Which that men clepeth in englissh ydelnesse
(base) That porter at the gate is of delices
(base) To eschuen and by hir contrarie hire oppresse
(base) That is to seyn by leueful bisynesse
(base) Wel oghte we to doon al oure entente
(base) Lest that the feend thurgh ydelnesse vs hente
(base) For he that with his thousand cordes slye
(base) Continuelly vs wayteth to biclappe
(base) Whan he may man in ydelnesse espye
(base) He kan so lightly cacche hym in his trappe
(base) Til that a man be hent right by the lappe
(base) He nys nat war the feend hath hym in honde
(base) Wel oghte vs werche and ydelnesse withstonde
(base) And thogh men dradden neuere for to dye
(base) Yet seen men wel by reson doutelees
(base) That ydelnesse is roten slogardye
(base) Of which ther neuere comth no good nencrees
(base) And seen that slouthe hir holdeth in a lees
(base) Oonly for to slepe and ete and drynken
(base) And to deuouren al that othere swynken
(base) And for to putte vs from swich ydelnesse
(base) That cause is of so greet confusioun
(base) I haue here doon my feithful bisynesse
(base) After the legende in translacioun
(base) Right of thy glorious lyf and passioun
(base) Thow with thy gerland wroght of rose and lilie
(base) Thee mene I mayde and martir Seinte Cecilie
(base) And thow that flour of virgines art alle
(base) Of whom that Bernard list so wel to write
(base) To thee at my bigynnyng I first calle
(base) Thow confort of vs wrecches do mendite
(base) Thy maydens deeth that wan thurgh hir merite
(base) The eternal lyf and of the feend victorie
(base) As man may after reden in hir Storie
(base) Thow mayde and moder doghter of thy sone
(base) Thow welle of mercy synful soules cure
(base) In whom that god for bountee chees to wone
(base) Thow humble and heigh ouer euery creature
(base) Thow nobledest so ferforth oure nature

div.l: (base) That no desdaign the makere hadde of kynde
(base) His sone in blood and flessh to clothe and wynde
(base) With Inne the Cloistre blisful of thy sydis
(base) Took mannes shap the eternal loue and pees
(base) That of the tryne compas lord and gyde is
(base) Whom erthe and see and heuene out of relees
(base) Ay heryen and thow virgyne wemmelees
(base) Bar of thy body and dweltest mayde pure
(base) The creatour of euery creature
(base) Assembled is in thee Magnificence
(base) With mercy goodnesse and swich pitee
(base) That thow that art the sonne of excellence
(base) Nat oonly helpest hem that prayen thee
(base) But ofte tyme of thy benygnytee
(base) Ful frely er that men thyn help biseche
(base) Thow goost biforn and art hir lyues leche
(base) Now help thow meke and blisful faire mayde
(base) Me flemed wrecche in this desert of galle
(base) Thynk on the womman Cananee that sayde
(base) That whelpes eten somme of the crommes alle
(base) That from hir lordes table been yfalle
(base) And thogh that I vnworthy sone of Eue
(base) Be synful yet accepte my bileue
(base) And for that feith is deed withouten werkis
(base) So for to werken yif me wit and space
(base) That I be quyt from thennes that moost derk is
(base) O thow that art so fair and ful of grace
(base) Be myn Aduocate in that heighe place
(base) Ther as withouten ende is songe Osanne
(base) Thow cristes moder doghter deere of Anne
(base) And of thy light my soule in prison lighte
(base) That troubled is by the contagioun
(base) Of my body and also by the wighte
(base) Of erthely lust and fals affeccioun
(base) O hauene o refut o sauacioun
(base) Of hem that been in sorwe and in distresse
(base) Now help for to my werk I wol me dresse
(base) Yet praye ich yow that reden that I write
(base) Foryeue me that I do no diligence
(base) This ilke storie subtilly to endite

div.l: (base) For bothe haue I the wordes and sentence
(base) Of hym that at the Seintes reuerence
(base) The storie wroot and folwen hir legende
(base) And pray yow that ye wol my werk amende
(base) First wolde I yow the name of Seinte Cecilie
(base) Expowne as men may in hir storie se
(base) It is to seyn on englissh heuenes lilie
(base) For pure chastnesse of virginitee
(base) Or for she whitnesse hadde of honestee
(base) And grene of conscience and of good fame
(base) The swote sauour lilie was hir name
(base) Or Cecile is to seyn the wey to blynde
(base) For she ensample was by good techynge
(base) Or ellis Cecile as I writen fynde
(base) Is ioyned by a manere conioignynge
(base) Of heuene and lia and here in figurynge
(base) The heuene is set for thoght of holynesse
(base) And lia for hir lastynge bisynesse
(base) Cecile may eek be seyd in this manere
(base) Wantynge of blyndnesse for hir grete light
(base) Of sapience and for hir thewes clere
(base) Or ellis lo this maydenes name bright
(base) Of heuene and leos comth for which by right
(base) Men myghte hire wel the heuene of peple calle
(base) Ensample of goode and wise werkes alle
(base) For leos peple in englissh is to seye
(base) And right as men may in the heuene see
(base) The sonne and moone and sterres euery weye
(base) Right so men goostly in this mayden free
(base) Sayen of feith the magnanymytee
(base) And eek the cleernesse hool of Sapience
(base) And sondry werkes brighte of excellence
(base) And right so as thise Philosophres write
(base) That heuene is swift and round and eek brennynge
(base) Right so was faire Cecile the white
(base) Ful swift and bisy euere in good werkynge
(base) And round and hool in good perseuerynge
(base) And brennyng euere in charite ful brighte
(base) Now haue I yow declared what she highte
(base) This mayde bright Cecilie as hir lyf seith

div.l: (base) Was come of Romayns and of noble kynde
(base) And from hir Cradel vp fostred in the feith
(base) Of crist and baar his gospel in hir mynde
(base) She neuere cessed as I writen fynde
(base) Of hir prayere and god to loue and drede
(base) Bisekyng hym to kepe hir maydenhede
(base) And whan this mayden sholde vn til a man
(base) Ywedded be that was ful yong of age
(base) Which that ycleped was Valerian
(base) And day was comen of hir mariage
(base) She ful deuout and humble in hir corage
(base) Vnder hir robe of gold that sat ful faire
(base) Hadde next hir flessh yclad hire in an haire
(base) And whil that the Organs maden melodie
(base) To god allone in hir herte thus soong she
(base) O lord my soule and eek my body gye
(base) Vnwemmed lest that I confounded be
(base) And for his loue that deyde vpon the tree
(base) Euery seconde and thridde day she faste
(base) Ay biddyng in hir orisons ful faste
(base) The nyght cam and to bedde moste she gon
(base) With hire housbonde as ofte is the manere
(base) And priuely to hym she seyde anon
(base) O swete and wel biloued spouse deere
(base) Ther is a conseil and ye wolde it heere
(base) Which that right fayn I wolde vnto yow seye
(base) So that ye swere ye shul it nat biwreye
(base) Valerian gan faste vnto hir swere
(base) That for no cas ne thyng that myghte be
(base) He sholde neuere mo biwreyen here
(base) And thanne at erst to hym seyde she
(base) I haue an Aungel which that loueth me
(base) That with gret loue wher so I wake or slepe
(base) Is redy ay my body for to kepe
(base) And if that he may feelen out of drede
(base) That ye me touche or loue in vileynye
(base) He right anon wol sleen yow with the dede
(base) And in youre youthe thus ye shullen dye
(base) And if that ye in clene loue me gye
(base) He wol yow loue as me for youre clennesse

div.l: (base) And shewe to yow his ioye and his brightnesse
(base) This Valerian corrected as god wolde
(base) Answerde agayn if I shal trusten thee
(base) Lat me that Aungel seen and hym biholde
(base) And if that it a verray Aungel be
(base) Thanne wol I doon as thow hast prayed me
(base) And if thow loue another man for sothe
(base) Right with this swerd than wol I sle yow bothe
(base) Cecile answerde right in this wise
(base) If that yow list the Aungel shal ye se
(base) So that ye trowe on crist and yow baptise
(base) Goth forth to Via Apia quod she
(base) That fro this town ne stant but Milys thre
(base) And to the poure folkes that ther dwellen
(base) Sey hem right thus as that I shal yow tellen
(base) Telle hem that I Cecile yow to hem sente
(base) To shewen yow the goode Vrban the olde
(base) For secree nedes and for good entente
(base) And whan that ye Seint Vrban han biholde
(base) Telle hym the wordes whiche I to yow tolde
(base) And whan that he hath purged yow fro synne
(base) Thanne shal ye seen that Aungel er we twynne
(base) This Valerian is to the place gon
(base) And right as hym was taught by his lernynge
(base) He foond this holy olde Vrban anon
(base) Among the Seintes buryels lotynge
(base) And he anon withouten tariynge
(base) Dide his message and whan that he it tolde
(base) Vrban for ioye hise handes gan vp holde
(base) The teerys from hise eyen leet he falle
(base) Almyghty lord o Ihu crist quod he
(base) Sowere of chaast conseil hierde of vs alle
(base) The fruyt of thilke seed of chastitee
(base) That thow hast sowe in Cecilie taak to thee
(base) Lo lyk a bisy bee withouten gyle
(base) Thee serueth ay thyn owene thral Cecile
(base) For thilke spouse that she tok but now
(base) Ful lyk a fiers leoun she sendeth heere
(base) As meke as euere was any lamb to yow
(base) And with that word anon ther gan appeere
