div.l: (base) An old man clad in white clothes cleere
(base) That hadde a book with lettre of gold in honde
(base) And gan biforn Valerian to stonde
(base) Valerian as deed fil doun for drede
(base) Whan he hym say and he vp hente hym tho
(base) And on his book right thus he gan to rede
(base) O lord o feith o god withoute mo
(base) O cristendom and fader of all also
(base) Abouen alle and oueral euery where
(base) Thise wordes al with gold ywriten were
(base) Whan this was rad thanne seyde this olde man
(base) Leuestow this thyng or no sey ye or nay
(base) I leue al this thyng quod Valerian
(base) For sother thyng than this I dar wel say
(base) Vnder the heuene no wight thynke may
(base) Tho vanysshed this olde man he nyste where
(base) And pope Vrban hym cristned right there
(base) Valerian goth hom and fynt Cecilie
(base) In with his chambre with an Aungel stonde
(base) This Aungel hadde of Roses and of lilie
(base) Corones two the whiche he bar in honde
(base) And first to Cecile as I vnderstonde
(base) He yaf that oon and after gan he take
(base) That oother to Valerian hir make
(base) With body clene and with vnwemmed thoght
(base) Kepeth ay wel thise corones quod he
(base) Fro Paradys to yow haue I hem broght
(base) Ne neuere mo ne shal they roten be
(base) Ne lese hir swote sauour trusteth me
(base) Ne neuere wight shal seen hem with his eye
(base) But he be chaast and hate vileynye
(base) And thow Valerian for thow so soone
(base) Assentedest to good conseil also
(base) Sey what thee list and thow shalt han thy boone
(base) I haue a brother quod Valerian tho
(base) That in this world I loue no man so
(base) I pray yow that my brother may han grace
(base) To knowe the trouthe as I do in this place
(base) The Aungel seyde god liketh thy requeste
(base) And bothe with the palm of martirdom

div.l: (base) Ye shullen come vnto his blisful feste
(base) And with that word Tiburce his brother coom
(base) And whan that he the sauour vndernoom
(base) Which that the Roses and the lilies caste
(base) With Inne his herte he gan to wondre faste
(base) And seyde I wondre this tyme of the yere
(base) Whennes that swote sauour cometh so
(base) Of Rose and lilies that I smelle heere
(base) For thogh I hadde hem in myne handes two
(base) The sauour myghte in me no depper go
(base) The swete smel that in myn herte I fynde
(base) Hath chaunged me al in another kynde
(base) Valerian seyde two corones han we
(base) Snow white and Rose reed that shynen clere
(base) Which that thyne eyen han no myght to se
(base) And as thow smellest hem thurgh my prayere
(base) So shaltow seen hem leue brother deere
(base) If it so be thow wolt withouten slouthe
(base) Bileue aright and knowen verray trouthe
(base) Tiburce answerde seystow this to me
(base) In soothnesse or in dreem I herkne this
(base) In dremes quod Valerian han we be
(base) Vnto this tyme brother myn ywys
(base) And now at erst in trouthe oure dwellyng is
(base) How wostow this quod Tiburce in what wyse
(base) Quod Valerian that shal I thee deuyse
(base) The Aungel of god hath me the trouthe ytaught
(base) Which thow shalt seen if that thow wolt reneye
(base) The ydoles and be clene and ellis nAught
(base) And of the myracle of thise corones tweye
(base) Seint Ambrose in his preface list to seye
(base) Solempnely this noble doctour deere
(base) Commendeth it and seith in this manere
(base) The palme of martirdom for to receyue
(base) Seinte Cecile fulfild of goddes yifte
(base) The world and eek hir chambre gan she weyue
(base) Witnesse Tiburces and Cecilies shrifte
(base) To whiche god of his bountee wolde shifte
(base) Corones two of floures wel smellynge
(base) And made his Aungel hem the corones brynge

div.l: (base) The mayde hath broght men to blisse aboue
(base) The world hath wist what it is worth certeyn
(base) Deuocion of chastitee to loue
(base) Tho shewed hym Cecile al open and pleyn
(base) That alle ydoles nys but a thyng in veyn
(base) For they been dowmbe and ther to they been deue
(base) And charged hym hise ydoles for to leue
(base) Who so that troweth nat this a beest he is
(base) Quod tho Tiburce if that I shal nat lye
(base) And she gan kisse his brest that herde this
(base) And was ful glad he koude trouthe espye
(base) This day I take thee for myn allye
(base) Seyde this blisful faire mayde deere
(base) And after that she seyde as ye may heere
(base) Lo right so as the loue of Crist quod she
(base) Made me thy brotheres wyf right in that wise
(base) Anon for myn allie heere take I thee
(base) Syn that thow wolt thyne ydoles despise
(base) Go with thy brother now and thee baptise
(base) And make thee clene so that thow mowe biholde
(base) The Aungeles face of which thy brother tolde
(base) Tiburce answerde and seyde brother deere
(base) First tel me whider that I shal and to what man
(base) To whom quod he com forth with right good cheere
(base) I wol thee lede vnto the pope Vrban
(base) Til Vrban brother myn Valerian
(base) Quod tho Tiburce woltow me thider lede
(base) Me thynketh that it were a wonder dede
(base) Ne menestow nat Vrban quod he tho
(base) That is so ofte dampned to be deed
(base) And woneth in halkes alwey to and fro
(base) And dar nat ones putte forth his heed
(base) Men sholde hym brennen in a fyr so reed
(base) If he were founde or that men myghte hym spye
(base) And we also to bere hym compaignye
(base) And whil we seken thilke diuinytee
(base) That is yhyd in heuene priuely
(base) Algate ybrend in this world shul we be
(base) To whom Cecile answerde boldely
(base) Men myghten dreden wel and skilfully

div.l: (base) This lyf to lese myn owene deere brother
(base) If thys were lyuyng oonly and noon oother
(base) But ther is bettre lyf in oother place
(base) That neuere shal be lost ne drede thee noght
(base) Which goddes sone vs tolde thurgh his grace
(base) That fadres sone hath alle thynges wroght
(base) And al that wroght is with a skilful thoght
(base) The goost that fro the fader gan procede
(base) Hath souled hem withouten any drede
(base) By word and by myracle he goddes sone
(base) Whan he was in this world declared heere
(base) That ther was oother lyf ther men may wone
(base) To whom answerde Tiburce o suster deere

div.l: (base) The sergeantz of the town of Rome hem soghte

(base) Almachius that herde of this doynge

div.l: (base) May al the boost of it be leyd ful lowe

(base) Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free

(base) We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde

div.l: (base) Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight

(base) Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me

(base) Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me

(base) Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
(base) That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle

(base) Thise and swiche othere seyde she

div.l: (base) She sat al coold and feeled no wo

(base) Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho

(base) Whan ended was the lyf of seint Cecile
(base) Er we fully hadde ryden fyue myle
(base) At Boghtoun vnder the blee . vs gan atake /
(base) A man that clothed was in clothes blake
(base) And vnder that he hadde a whit surplys
(base) His hakeney that was al pomel grys
(base) So swette that it wonder was to see
(base) It semed he hadde priked myles thre
(base) Aboute the peytrel stood the foom ful hiȝe
(base) He was of fome al flekked as a pye
(base) The hors eek that his ȝoman rood vpon
(base) So swette that vnnethe mighte he gon
(base) A male twyfold on his croper lay
(base) It semed that he caryed lytel aray
(base) Al light for somer rood this worthy man
(base) And in myn herte wondren I bygan
(base) What that he was til that I vnderstood
(base) How that his cloke was sewed to his hood

(base) I demed him som chanoun for to be /
(base) His hat hyng at his bak doun by a las /

(base) His ȝoman eek was ful of curtesye
(base) And sires now in the morwe tyde /
(base) Out of ȝoure ostellerye I sayz ȝou ryde
(base) And warned heer my lord and my souerayn

(base) For his disport he loueth daliaunce
(base) Frend for thy warnyng god ȝiue the good chaunce
(base) Faste haue I priked quod he for ȝoure sake

(base) To ryden in this merye companye

div.l: (base) Sayde oure oost certes it wolde seeme /
(base) Thy lord were wys and so I may wel deme
(base) He is ful iocunde also dar I lay
(base) Kan he ought telle a merye tale or tway
(base) With which he glade may this companye
(base) Who sire my lord ; ȝe ȝe withoute lye /
(base) He can of merthe and eek of Iolite
(base) Nought but ynough also sire trusteth to me
(base) And ȝe him knewe als wel as do I
(base) Ȝe wolde wondre how wel and thriftyly
(base) He couthe werke and that in sondry wyse
(base) He hath take on him many sondry aprise
(base) Which were ful hard for eny that is heere /
(base) To bringe aboute but they of him it lere
(base) As homely as he ryt amonges ȝou
(base) If ȝe him knewe it wolde be ȝoure prow /
(base) Ȝe nolde not forgon his aqueintance
(base) For mochil good I dar leye in balaunce
(base) Al that I haue my possessioun
(base) He is a man of heigh discrecioun
(base) I warne ȝou wel he is a passynge man
(base) Wel quoth oure host I pray the telle me than
(base) Is he a Clerk or noon tell what he is

(base) Seyde the ȝoman and in wordes fewe

(base) I say my lord can such a sotilte

(base) And whan this ȝoman hadde thus y told

(base) This thing is wonder merueylous to me /
(base) Sithens that thi lord is of so heigh prudence /
(base) By cause of which men scholde him reuerence /
(base) That of his worschipe rekketh he so lyte
(base) His ouer sloppe nys nouȝt worth a myte /

div.l: (base) As in effecte to him so mote I go

(base) If that his dede acorde with thy speche

(base) God help me so for he schal neuer y the

(base) He is to wys in faith as I bileeue
(base) And that is ouer doon it nyl not preue

(base) Ther of no fors goode ȝoman quod oure hoost
(base) Sithens of the connyng of thy lord thou woost

(base) Sithens that he is so crafty and so sly

div.l: (base) And borwe gold be it a pound or tuo

div.l: (base) I couthe neuer leue it in no wyse

(base) ¶ Narrat

div.l: (base) Thus was I / ones lerned of a Clerk

(base) ¶ Whan we been there / as we shul excercise
(base) Oure Eluysshe craft / we semen wonder wise

(base) And in an erthen pot put is al

(base) Oure Orpyment . and sublymed Mercurie
(base) Oure grounden litarge eek in the Prfurie

div.l: (base) He hath maad vs spenden muchel good

(base) Supposynge / though we sore smerte

(base) Passe ouer this / I go my tale vn to
(base) Er that the pot be on the fir ydo
(base) Of metals / with a certeyn quantitee
(base) My lord hem tempreth / and no man but he

(base) For as men seyn / he kan doon craftily
(base) Algate I woot wel / he hath swich a name

div.l: (base) Thise Metals / been of so greet violence

(base) And some of hem / synke in to the ground

(base) I trowe he with vs be / that ilke shrewe
(base) In helle / where that he lord is and sire
(base) Nis ther moore wo / ne moore rancour ne Ire
(base) Whan that oure pot is broke / as I haue sayd

(base) ¶ Some seyde / it was along on the fir makyng
(base) Some seyde nay / it was on the blowyng

(base) ¶ Straw quod the thridde / ye been lewed and nyce

(base) ¶ Nay quod the fourthe / stynt and herkne me
(base) By cause oure fir / ne was nat maad of Beech

(base) I kan nat telle / wher on it was along
(base) But wel I woot greet strif vs is among
(base) ¶ What quod my lord / ther is namoore to doone
(base) Of thise perils / I wol be war eft soone
(base) I am right siker that the pot was crased
(base) Be as be may / be ye no thyng amased
(base) As vsage is / lat swepe the floor as swithe
(base) Plukke vp youre hertes / and beeth glad and blithe
(base) ¶ The Mullok / on an heep / sweped was

(base) And sifted / and ypiked many a throwe
(base) ¶ Pardee quod oon / somwhat of oure metal
(base) Yet is ther heere / though that we han nat al
(base) Al though this thyng myshapped haue as now
(base) Another tyme / it may be wel ynow
(base) Vs moste putte / oure good in auenture
(base) A Marchant perdee / may nat ay endure

div.l: (base) Trusteth me wel / in his prosperitee
(base) Somtyme his good / is drenched in the see

(base) ¶ Pees quod my lord / the nexte tyme I shal fonde
(base) To bryngen oure craft / al in another plite
(base) And but I do / lat me han the wite
(base) Ther was defaute in som what wel I woot
(base) ¶ Another seyde / the fir was ouer hoot
(base) And be it hoot or coold / I dar seye this
(base) That we concluden / eueremoore amys
(base) We faille of that / which that we wolden haue
(base) And in oure madnesse / eueremoore we raue
(base) And whan we been / togidres euerichoon
(base) Euery man / semeth a Salomoun

(base) Ne euery appul / that is fair to eye

(base) ¶ Right so / fareth it / amonges vs
(base) He that semeth the wiseste by Ihuns
(base) Is moost fool / whan it comth to the preef
(base) And he that semeth trewest is a theef /
(base) That shul ye knowe / er that I fro yow wende
(base) By that / I of my tale haue maad an ende
(base) Ther was / a Chanoun of Religioun
(base) Amonges vs / wolde infecte al a toun
(base) Thogh it as greet were / as was Nynyuee
(base) Rome / Alisaundre / Troye / and othere three
(base) His sleighte / and his infinit falsnesse

(base) Though that he lyue myghte a thousand yeer
(base) In al this world / of falshede nas his peer
(base) For in hise termes / so he wolde hym wynde
(base) And speke hise wordes / in so sly a kynde
(base) Whanne he comune shal with any wight

(base) But it a feend be / as hym seluen is
(base) Ful many a man / hath he bigiled er this

(base) And yet men ride and goon ful many a Mile

div.l: (base) Hym for to seke / and haue his Aqueyntaunce
(base) Noght knowynge / of his false gouernaunce
(base) And if yow list . to yeue me Audience
(base) I wol it telle heere / in youre presence
(base) ¶ But worshipful Chanons Religious
(base) Ne demeth nat . that I desclaundre your hous
(base) Al though that my tale / of a Chanoun bee

(base) IN Londoun / was a preest Annueleer

(base) And telle forth my tale / of the Chanoun

(base) ¶ This false Chanoun / cam vp on a day
(base) Vn to this preestes chambre / wher he lay
(base) Bisechynge hym / to lene hym a certeyn

div.l: (base) And if so be / that thow me fynde fals

(base) How I kan werken / in Philosophie

(base) ¶ Ye quod the preest . ye sir quod he / and wol ye so ;
(base) Marie / ther of / I pray yow hertely

(base) Quod the Chanoun / and ellis god forbeede
(base) ¶ Loo how this theef koude his seruice beede

(base) Stynketh / as witnessen thise olde wyse

div.l: (base) And that ful soone / I wol it verifie

(base) That euere moore / delit hath and gladnesse
(base) Swiche feendly thoghtes / in his herte impresse
(base) How Cristes peple / he may to meschief brynge
(base) God kepe vs / from his false dissymulynge
(base) ¶ Noght wiste this preest with whom that he delte

(base) O sely preest / o sely Innocent
(base) With coueitise / anon thou shalt be blent

(base) Vnhappy man / anon I wol me hye

(base) As ferforth / as my konnyng may strecche

(base) Sir hoost in feith / and by the heuenes queene

(base) Algates / they bigynnen for to glowe

(base) In my visage / for fumes diuerse
(base) Of metals / whiche ye han herd me reherce

(base) ¶ Sire quod he to the preest lat your man gon

div.l: (base) He bad his seruant . fecchen hym this thyng

(base) And make as good siluer and as fyn

(base) Amonges folk for euere to appeere

(base) Shal make al good / for it is cause of al
(base) My konnyng / which that I to yow shewen shal

(base) And shette the dore / whils we been aboute
(base) Oure pryuetee / that no man vs espie

(base) ¶ Al as he bad / fulfilled was in dede
(base) This ilke seruant anon right out yede
(base) And his Maister / shette the dore anon

(base) ¶ This preest at this cursed Chanons biddyng
(base) Vp on the fir anon sette this thyng

div.l: (base) A poudre noot I wher of that it was

(base) To blynde with the preest . and bad hym hye
(base) The coles / for to couchen al aboue

(base) ¶ Graunt Mercy quod the preest and was ful glad

(base) Her afterward / whiche that he with hym broghte

(base) On his falshede / fayn wolde I me wreke
(base) If I wiste how / but he is heere and there

(base) ¶ But taketh heede / now sires for goddes loue
(base) He took this cole / of which I spak aboue
(base) And in his hand / he baar it pryuely
(base) And whils the preest couched bisily
(base) The coles / as I tolde yow er this
(base) This Chanoun seyde / freend ye doon amys

(base) But soone / I shal amenden it quod he
(base) Now lat me medle ther with / but a while
(base) For of yow / haue I pitee by seint Gile

div.l: (base) And whils that the preest wiped his face

(base) Of the Crosselet / . and blew wel afterward
(base) Til that the coles / gonne faste brenne

(base) And whan this Alkamystre saugh his tyme

(base) And for I woot wel / Ingot haue I noon
(base) Gooth walketh forth and bryng vs a Chalk stoon

(base) That is an Ingot . if I may han hap

(base) Ful of water / and ye shul se wel thanne
(base) How that oure bisynesse / shal thryue and preeue
(base) And yet for ye shul han no mysbileeue
(base) Ne wrong conceite of me / in youre absence

div.l: (base) ¶ He shoop his Ingot in lengthe and eek in breede

(base) This noble craft and this subtiltee

(base) This disciplyne / and this crafty science

div.l: (base) And whil this preest was in his bisynesse

div.l: (base) And caste In poudre / and made the preest to blowe

div.l: (base) And to the Chanoun / thus he spak and seyde

div.l: (base) So ferforth / that vnnethe is ther noon

(base) The cause grettest of swich scarsetee

(base) Philosophres / speken so mystily

(base) A man may lightly lerne / if he haue aught

(base) A mannes myrthe / it wol turne vnto grame
(base) And empten also / grete and heuye purses

(base) Medleth namoore / with that Art I mene

(base) And right as swithe / I wol yow tellen heere

div.l: (base) He seith right thus / with outen any lye

(base) ¶ Telle me the roote / good sire quod he tho

div.l: (base) Noot I nat why that me were leuere slepe

div.l: (base) He hath also to do moore than ynow

div.l: (base) Telle on thy Manciple I the preye

(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun

div.l: (base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel

div.l: (base) What wol ye moore the Crowe anon hym tolde
(base) By sadde toknes and by wordes bolde
(base) How that his wyf hadde doon hire lecherye
(base) Hym to gret shame and to gret vileynye
(base) And tolde hym ofte he say it with hise eyen
(base) This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen
(base) And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo
(base) His bowe he bente and sette ther Inne a flo
(base) And in his Ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to sayn
(base) For sorwe of which he brak his Mynstralcye
(base) Bothe harpe and Lute and Gyterne and Sawtrye
(base) And eek he brak hise arwes and his bowe
(base) And after that thus spak he to the Crowe
(base) Traytour quod he with tonge of Scorpioun
(base) Thow hast me broght to my confusioun
(base) Allas that I was wroght why nere I ded
(base) O deere wyf o gemme of lustihed
(base) That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
(base) Now lystow ded with face pale of hewe
(base) Ful giltlees that dorste I swere ywys
(base) O rakel hand to doon so foule amys
(base) O trouble wit o Ire recchelees
(base) That vnauysed smytest giltlees
(base) O wantrust ful of fals suspecioun
(base) Where was thy wit and thy discrecioun
(base) O euery man be war of rakelnesse
(base) Ne trowe ye no thyng withouten strong witnesse
(base) Smyt nat to soone er that ye witen why
(base) And beth auysed wel and sobrely
(base) Er ye do any execucioun
(base) Vpon youre Ire for suspecioun
(base) Allas a thousand folk hath rakel Ire
(base) Fully fordoon or broght hem in the Myre
(base) Allas for sorwe I wol my seluen sle
(base) And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
(base) I wol thee quyte anon thy false tale
(base) Thow songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale

(base) And eek thy white fetheres euerichon

div.l: (base) Ne neuere in al thy lyf ne shaltow speke
(base) Thus shal men on a traytour ben awreke
(base) Thow and thyn ofspryng euere shul be blake
(base) Ne neuere swete noyse shul ye make
(base) But euere crye agayn tempest and rayn
(base) In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn
(base) And to the Crowe he stirte and that anon
(base) And pulled hise white fetheres euerichon
(base) And made hym blak and refte hym al his song
(base) And eek his speche and out at dore hym slong
(base) Vnto the deuel which I hym bitake
(base) And for this cas ben alle Crowes blake
(base) Lordynges by this ensample I yow preye
(base) Beth war and taketh kepe what I seye
(base) Ne telleth neuere no man in youre lyf
(base) How that another man hath dight his wyf
(base) He wol yow haten mortally certeyn
(base) Daun Salomon as wise clerkes seyn
(base) Techeth a man to kepen his tonge wel
(base) But as I seyde I nam nat textuel
(base) But nathelees thus taughte me my dame
(base) My sone thenk on the Crowe agoddes name
(base) My sone keep wel thy tonge and kepe thy freend
(base) A wikke tonge is worse than a feend
(base) My sone from a feend men may hem blesse
(base) My sone god of his endelees goodnesse
(base) Walled a tonge with teeth and lippes eke
(base) For man sholde hym auyse what he speeke
(base) My sone ful ofte for to muche speche
(base) Hath many a man ben spilt as clerkes teche
(base) But for litel speche auysely
(base) Is no man shent to speke generally
(base) My sone thy tonge sholdestow restreyne
(base) At alle tymes but whan thow doost thy peyne
(base) To speke of god in honour and prayere
(base) The firste vertu sone if thow wolt leere
(base) Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge
(base) Thus lernen children whan that they ben yonge
(base) My sone of muchel spekyng yuele auysed
(base) Ther lasse spekyng hadde ynow suffised

div.l: (base) Comth muchel harm thus was me told and taught
(base) In muchel speche synne wanteth naught
(base) Wostow wher of a rakel tonge serueth
(base) Right as a swerd forkitteth and forkerueth
(base) An arm atwo my deere sone right so
(base) A tonge kitteth frendship al atwo
(base) A Ianglere is to god abhomynable
(base) Rede Salomon so wys and honurable
(base) Rede Dauid in his psalmes rede Senekke
(base) My sone spek noght but with thyn hed thow bekke
(base) Dissimule as thow were deef if that thow heere
(base) A Ianglere speke of perilous matere
(base) The flemyng seith and lerne it if thee leste
(base) That litel Ianglyng causeth muchel reste
(base) My sone if thow no wikked word hast seyd
(base) Thee thar nat drede for to be biwreyd
(base) But he that hath mysseyd I dar wel sayn
(base) He may by no wey clepe his word agayn
(base) Thyng that is sayd is seyd and forth it gooth
(base) Though hym repente or be hym leef or looth
(base) He is his thral to whom that he hath sayd
(base) A tale of which he is now yuele apayd
(base) My sone be war and be noon Auctour newe
(base) Of tidynges wher they ben false or trewe
(base) Wher so thow come amonges heye or lowe
(base) Kepe wel thy tonge and thynk vpon the Crowe
(base) Explicit fabula mancipij
⁊ Incipit prologus Rectoris fabule
By that þe Maunciple / hade his tale ended
The son from þe South lyne / was discended
So lowe that he nas nat to my sight
Degrees . ix . / and . xxty of hight
X . of þe Clok / it was tho as I gesse
For . xj . fote / and litle more or lesse
My shadow was at thilk tyme as there
Of soch fete / as my length parted were
In . vj fete equall of proporciou
There wtith the mones exaltaciou
I mene libra / all wey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a thorpes ende
For which our hoost as he was wont to gye /
As in this caas / our ioly companye
Seid in this wise / lordyngs euꝰerychone
Now lakketh vs no tales moo þan one
Fulfilled is my sentence / and my decree
I trowe þat we han herde in ecch degree
All most fulfilled is / all myn ordenaunce
I pray to god / so yeve hym right gode chaunce
That telleth this tale to vs lustely
Sir preest koth he / art þu a vicary
Or art þow ꝑpersou / sey soth be thy fey
Be what þu be / ne breke þu nat our pley
For euꝰery man save þu hath told his tale
Vnbokle and shewe vs what is in þy male
For truely me thynketh by þy chere
Thow sholdest knytte vp wele a grete matere
Tell vs a fable anon / for goddes bones
This ꝑpersou answerd / all at ones
Thow getest fable noon ytold for me
For Poule þat writeth vn to Tymothe
Repreven hem / þat weyven sothfastnesse
And tellen fables / and soch wrecchednesse
Why shold I sowe draf out of my fyst
Whan I may sowe whete / yf þat me lyst
For which I sey þat yf þu list to here
Moralitee / and vꝰertuous matere
And þan / that ye woll yeve me audience
I woll fayn / at cristes reuerence
Do yow plesaunce leefull as I can
But trusteth wele I am a sothern man
I can nat geest rom ram ruf by lre
Ne god wote / ryme hold I but litle better
And therfore yf þu list I woll nat glose
I woll yow tell a mery tale in prose
To knytte vp all þis feest / and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace witte me sende .
To shewe yow / þe weye in this viage
Of thylk ꝑperfyte glorious pilgrymage
That hight Ierusalem celestiall
And yf ye vouchesauf anoon I shall
Begynne vp on my tale / for which I prey
Tell yorur avice / I can no better sey
But natheles this meditaciou
I put it ay vnder correcciou
Of clerkes for I am nat textuell
I take but þe sentence / trusteth well
Therfore I make a protestaciou
That I woll stond to correcciou
Vp on this worde we han assented sone
For as vs semed it was to done
To enden in som vꝰertuous sentence
And for to yeve hym / space and audience
And bad our hoost he shold to hym sey
That all we / to tell his tale hym prey
Our hoost hade þe wordes / for vs all
Sir prest koth he / now faire yow byfall
Sey what yow list and we woll gladly here
And wtith þat worde / he seid in þis manere
Telleth koth he your meditacou
But hasteth yow / þe son woll adoun
Beth fructuous and þat in litle space
And to do wele / god send yow his grace
Hic desinit prologus Rectoris

div.ab: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. [This line not in the base text]
(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise
(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera
(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne of glorie
(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey of Ierusalem celestial
(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al his herte
(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions or werkynges of penitence
(base) and how manye spices ther ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence
(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne
(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath mysdoon
(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother peyne for hise giltes
(base) and for he shal be verray penitent he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe and to doon satisfaccioun
(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle
(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym oghte repente
(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne may nat auaile
(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe
(base) for as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage
(base) and ther fore repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion
(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey
(base) and Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. (base) Seint Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may nat bigynne the newe clene lyf
(base) for certes if he be baptised with oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray
(base) Another defaute is this that men doon deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme
(base) The thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after hire baptesme fro day to day
(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence of euery day
(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee
(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children and swich manere thyng
(base) Another is whan man hath synned openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to doon open penance
(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in pilgrymage or barefoot
(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely and receyue pryuee penance
(base) Now shaltow vnderstande what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and this stant on iij thynges
(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee
(base) and this is fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge
(base) and agayns thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree
(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth hym in the erthe
(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun
(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem
(base) Of this roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot
(base) the grace of thys Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome and on the peynes of helle
(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. (base) the hete of thys seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable
(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate his synne
(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with oother mete
(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng
(base) but fro that tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable
(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word
(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence
(base) Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

(base) In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule
(base) thanne is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to do penance and neuere moore to do synne
(base) and this sorwe shal ben in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte
(base) first for man hath agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt for he hath agilt his fader celestial

(base) and yet moore sharpe and poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle
(base) The causes that oghten moeuen a man to Contricioun been vj ffirst a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes
(base) but looke that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret shame and sorwe for his gilt for Iob seith Synful men doon werkes worthy of Confessioun
(base) And therfore seith Ezechie I wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn herte
(base) And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god
(base) but for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle
(base) And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng
(base) and yet be ye fouler for youre longe contynuynge in synne and youre synful vsage for which ye been roten in youre synne as a beest in his donge

Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. (base) swiche manere of thoughtes maken a man haue shame of his synne and no delit as god seyth by the prophete Ezechiel
(base) ye shal remembre yow of youre weyes and they shullen displese yow soothly synnes been the weyes that leden folk to helle
(base) The seconde cause that oghte make a man to han desdeyn of synne is this that as seith Seint Peter who so that dooth synne is thral of synne and synne put a man in greet thraldam
(base) And therfore seith the prophete Ezechiel I wente sorweful in desdayn of my self Certes wel oghte a man haue desdayn of synne and with drawe hym fro that thraldom and vileynye
(base) And lo what seith Seneca in this matere he seith thus though I wiste that god neither god ne man ne sholde neuere kNowe it yet wolde Ihaue desdayn for to do synne
(base) And the same Seneca also seith Iam born to gretter thynges than to be thral to my body or than for to maken of my body a thral
(base) ne a fouler thral may no man ne womman make of his body than for to yeue his body to synne
(base) al were it the fouleste cherl or the fouleste womman that lyueth and leest of value yet is he thanne moore foul and moore in seruitute
(base) euere fro the hyer degree that man falleth the moore is he thral and moore to god and to the world vil and abhomynable
(base) O goode god wel oghte man haue greet desdayn of synne sith that thurgh synne ther he was fre Now is he maked bonde
(base) And ther fore seith Seint Augustyn If thow hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne haue thow thanne desdayn that thow thy self sholdest do synne
(base) take reward of thy value that thow ne be to foul to thy self
(base) Allas wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn to ben seruantz and thralles to synne and soore ben ashamed of hem self
